ORDINANCE NO. 1222
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING THE VILLAGE CODE OF RIVERSIDE, ILLINOIS
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE VILLAGE OF RIVERSIDE, ILLINOIS:
SECTION 1: That this Code, consisting of Titles 1 through 10, inclusive, and printed and published in book form, is hereby adopted and enacted as the
"Village Code of Riverside, Illinois 1974" and shall be treated and considered as a new and original comprehensive Code which shall supersede all other
general and permanent ordinances passed by the President and Board of Trustees on or before January 1, 1974.
SECTION 2: All ordinances of a general and permanent nature of the Village of Riverside, Illinois, enacted on final passage on or before January 1, 1974,
and not in such Code, or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are hereby repealed from and after the effective date of such Code,
except as hereinafter provided.
SECTION 3: That the repeal provided for in Section 2 hereof shall not affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or
any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of such Code; nor shall such repeal affect any of the codes or ordinances which are
not contained in such Code and which shall be excluded from inclusion therein and remain in full force as described and provided in Sections 1-2-1
through 1-2-3 of said Code, and in addition such repeal shall not affect ordinances involving lease purchase agreements, motor fuel tax authorizations,
federal revenue sharing expenditures and improvements, flood plain regulations, personnel rules, and ordinances concerning investment of surplus funds
or designating a depository for Village funds.
SECTION 4: Any and all additions or amendments to such Code, when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the President and Board of
Trustees to make the same a part thereof, shall be deemed to be incorporated in such Code so that reference to the "Village Code of Riverside, Illinois
1974" shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments.
SECTION 5: A copy of such Code shall be kept on file in the Office of the Village Clerk, preserved in looseleaf form. It shall be the express duty of the
Village Clerk, or someone authorized by her, to insert in their designated places all amendments or ordinances which indicate the intention of the President
and Board of Trustees to make the same a part of such Code when the same have been printed or reprinted in page form, and to extract from such Code
all provisions which may from time to time be repealed by the President and Board of Trustees. This copy of such Code shall be available for all persons
desiring to examine the same and shall be considered the official Village Code of Riverside, Illinois.
SECTION 6: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of such Code, or to
insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the Village of
Riverside to be misrepresented thereby.
Any person, firm or corporation violating this Section shall be punished as provided in Section 1-4-1 of the Village Code of Riverside, Illinois.
SECTION 7: All Ordinances or parts of Ordinances in conflict herewith are, to the extent of such conflict, hereby repealed.
SECTION 8: This Ordinance and the Code adopted by the same shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage and approval in accordance
with law, as printed and published in book form by order of the President and Board of Trustees.
Title 1
ADMINISTRATIVE
Chapter 1
OFFICIAL VILLAGE CODE
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon adoption by the Board of Trustees, this Village Code is hereby declared to be and shall hereafter constitute the official Village Code of the Village of
Riverside. Any reference made to the number of any Section contained herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same under its appropriate
Chapter and Title heading, and to the general penalty clause relating thereto, as well as to the Section itself, when reference is made to this Village Code
by title in any legal document.
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 38/519
This Village Code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received without further proof in all courts and in all administrative tribunals of
this State as the ordinances of the Village of general and permanent effect.
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this Village Code shall set forth the Title, Chapter and Section number of the Section or Sections to be amended, and this shall
constitute a sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to the amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this Village Code. All
such amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately prepared for insertion in its proper place in each copy of this Village Code. Each such
replacement pages shall be properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of the Village Code within thirty (30) days from the date of its
final passage.
1-1-4: INTERPRETATIONS:
In the determination of the provisions of each Section of this Code, the following rules shall be observed: (1974 Code)
(A) Liberal Construction: All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this official Village Code shall be liberally construed in order
that the true intent and meaning of the Board of Trustees may be fully carried out. (1965 Code, Sec. 1.14)
(B) Intent to Defraud: Whenever an intent to defraud is required in order to constitute an offense, it shall be sufficient if an intent appears to defraud any
person.
(C) Liability of Employers and Agents: When the provisions of any Section of this Village Code prohibits the commission of an act, not only the person
actually doing the prohibited act or omitting the directed act, but also the employer and all other persons concerned with or in aiding or abetting the said
person shall be guilty of the offense described and liable to the penalty set forth.
1-1-5: CODE ALTERATION:
It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface in any way any Section or any page of this Village Code in such a manner
that the meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Replacement pages may be inserted according to the official instructions when so
authorized by the Village Board. The Clerk shall see that the replacement pages are properly inserted in the official copies maintained in the office of the
Clerk.
Any person having in his custody an official copy of this Village Code shall make every effort to maintain said Code in an up to date and efficient manner.
He shall see to the immediate insertion of new or replacement pages when such are delivered to him or made available to him through the office of the
Village Clerk. Said Code Books, while in actual possession of officials and other interested persons, shall be and remain the property of the Village and
shall be returned to the office of the Clerk when directed so to do by order of the Village Board. (1973 Code)
Chapter 2
SAVING CLAUSE
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the Village passed prior to the adoption of this Village Code are hereby repealed, except such as are referred to herein as being
still in force or are by necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to the saving clauses contained herein), from which are excluded the
following ordinances which are not hereby repealed: Tax levy ordinances and ordinances establishing all tax rates; appropriation ordinances; ordinances
relating to boundaries and annexations; franchise ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights to persons or corporations; contract ordinances
and ordinances authorizing the execution of a contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances; ordinances establishing, naming or vacating streets,
alleys or other public places; ordinances fixing the grades of streets and sidewalks; improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances relating to
elections; ordinances relating to the purchase, lease, transfer or acceptance of real estate by or from the Village; the Zoning Ordinance, as amended; the
Plumbing, Electrical, Fire Prevention and Building Codes, as mended, and as adopted herein by reference; the ordinance prohibiting the use of barbed
wire for fences or barriers, approved August 1, 1972, as amended; the ordinance regulating the moving of buildings within the Village limits, approved
June 14, 1914, as amended; all ordinances pertaining to the historic landmark description of the Village; and all other special ordinances and resolutions
and administrative ordinances and regulations not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code.
1-2-2: PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroads or railroad crossings with streets and other public ways, or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public
utilties shall be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this Village Code or by virtue of the preceding Section, excepting as this Village Code may contain
provisions for such matters, in which case this Village Code shall be considered as amending such ordinance or ordinances in respect to such provisions
only.
1-2-3: SEVERABILITY; COURT PROCEEDINGS:
No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former ordinance, whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any offense
committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim arising
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 39/519
under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so
incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform to the
ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as practicable, and further, should any part, section, sentence or clause of this Village Code be
adjudged void and of no effect, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portion of this Village Code.
This Section shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making any new provisions upon the
same subject or in any other ordinance.
Nothing contained in this Chapter shall be construed as abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of the Village herein
repealed and the provisions of all general ordinances contained in this Code shall be deemed to be continuing provisions and not a new enactment of the
same provision; nor shall this Chapter be deemed as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the
liability of any person, firm or corporation, or as waiving any right of the Village under any ordinance or provision thereof in force at the time of the adoption
of this Village Code. (1973 Code)
Chapter 3
DEFINITIONS
1-3-1: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
Whenever any word in any Section of this Village Code importing the plural number is used in describing or referring to an matters, parties or persons, any
single matter, party or person shall be deemed to be included, although distributive words may not have been used.
When any subject matter, party or person is referred to in this Village Code by words importing the singular number only, or the masculine gender, several
matters, parties or persons and females as well as males and bodies corporate shall be deemed to be included; provided, that these rules of construction
shall not be applied to any Section of this Village Code which contains any express provision excluding such construction or where the subject matter or
content may be repugnant thereto. (1973 Code)
1-3-2: GENERAL DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this Code, they shall have the meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such
meaning repugnant thereto:
AGENT: The word "agent" as used in this Code shall mean a person acting on behalf of another.
BOARD: The word "Board", unless otherwise indicated, shall mean the Board of Trustees of the Village of Riverside.
CODE: The word "Code" shall mean this Village Code of the Village of Riverside, and all amendments thereto.
COURT: The word "Court" shall mean the appropriate judicial officer of the Circuit Court.
COUNTY: The word "County" shall mean the County of Cook in the State of Illinois.
EMPLOYEES: Whenever reference is made in this Code to a Village employee by title only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the
Village of Riverside".
FEE: The word "fee" as used in this Code shall mean a sum of money charged by the Village for the carrying on of a business, profession or occupation.
KNOWINGLY: The word "knowingly" imports only a knowledge that the facts exist which bring the act or omission within the provisions of this Code. It
does not require any knowledge of the unlawfulness of such act or omission.
LICENSE: The word "license" as used in this Code shall mean the permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession or occupation.
MISDEMEANOR: The word "misdemeanor" shall mean any offense deemed a violation of the provisions of this Code which is a lesser offense than a
felony as defined by State law.
NEGLIGENT: The word "negligent", as well as "neglect", "negligence" and "negligently" imports a want of such attention to the nature of probable
consequences of the act or omission as a prudent man ordinarily bestows in acting in his own concern.
NUISANCE: The word "nuisance" shall mean anything offensive or obnoxious to the health and welfare of the inhabitants of the Village; or any act or thing
repugnant to or creating a hazard to or having a detrimental effect on the property of another person or to the community.
OCCUPANT: The word "occupant" applied to a building or land shall include any person who occupies the whole or any part of such building or land
whether alone or with others.
OFFENSE: The word "offense" shall mean any act forbidden by any provision of this Code or the omission of any act required by the provisions of this
Code.
OFFICER: Whenever reference is made in this Code to a Village officer by title only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the Village
of Riverside".
OPERATOR: The word "operator" as used in this Code shall mean the person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: The word "owner" applied to a building or land shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant of
the whole or a part, or the holder of any beneficial interest of such building or land.
PERSON: The word "person" shall mean any individual, partnership, corporation, joint stock association or any City or State or any subdivision thereof;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 40/519
and includes any trustee, receiver, assignee or personal representative thereof.
Whenever the word "person" is used in any Section of this Code prescribing a penalty or fine as applied to partnerships or associations, the word shall
include the partners or members thereof, and such word as applied to corporations shall include the officers, agents or employees thereof who are
responsible for any violation of said Section.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: The term "personal property" shall include every description of money, goods, chattels, effects, evidence of rights in action and
all written instruments by which any pecuniary obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged, transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or
diminished and every right or interest therein.
PRESIDENT: The term "President" shall mean the President of the Village of Riverside.
RETAILER: The word "retailer" as used in this Code, unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise,
articles or things in small quantitites direct to the consumer.
STATE: The word "State", unless otherwise indicated, shall mean the State of Illinois.
STREET: The word "street" shall include alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public squares, public places, sidewalks, roads, avenues, parkways and any
designated portion of a road or public right of way.
TENANT: The word "tenant" applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies the whole or any part of such building or land whether
alone or with others.
VILLAGE: The word "Village" shall mean the Village or Riverside, Cook County, Illinois.
WHOLESALER: The words "wholesaler" and "wholesale dealer" as used in this Code, unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate
to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in quantity to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WILFULLY: The word "wilfully" when applied to the intent with which an act is done or omitted, implies simply a purpose or willingness to commit the act or
make the omission referred to. It does not require any intent to violate law, or to injure another, or to acquire an advantage.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: The terms "written" or "in writing" may include printing and any other mode of representing words and letters, but when the
written signature of any person is required by law to an official or public writing or bond required by law, it shall be in the proper handwriting of such
person, or in case he is unable to write, by his proper mark.
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several Sections of this Village Code are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the content of the Section and shall not be
deemed or taken to be titles of such Sections, nor as any part of the Section, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such
Sections, including the catchlines, are amended or re-enacted. (1965 Code, Sec. 1.07; amd. 1974 Code)
Chapter 4
GENERAL PENALTY
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
Except wherein any specific section of this Code provides for a fine in a lesser amount, any person convicted of a violation of any section of this Code shall
be fined a sum of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day that such a violation
continues under this Code shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2154, 6-3-1996)
1-4-2: LICENSE:
When a person is convicted of a violation of any section of this Code, any license previously issued him by the Village may be revoked by the Board of
Trustees. (1974 Code)
1-4-3: APPLICATION OF PENALTY:
The penalty provided in this chapter shall be applicable to every section of this Code the same as though it were a part of each and every separate
section. Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this Code where any duty is prescribed or obligation imposed, or where any act which is of a
continuing nature is forbidden or declared to be unlawful, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon
each day such duty or obligation remains unperformed or such act continues, unless otherwise specifically provided in this Code.
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of this Code, the prosecuting officer may elect under
which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or
permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced.
Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do any act constitutes a breach of any section or provision of this Code and there shall be no fine or
penalty specifically declared for such breach, the provisions of this chapter shall apply and a separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day
during or on which a breach or violation occurs or continues. (1974 Code)
1-4-4: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 41/519
No provisions of this Code designating the duties of any officer or employee shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of the Board of Trustees to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty. (1974 Code)
1-4-5: VILLAGE JAIL:
The room with cells in and adjoining the police station on the first floor of the Village Hall is hereby constituted and established as a Village calaboose or
jail for the Village. (1965 Code § 21.01)
1-4-6: COMPROMISE AND SETTLEMENT; CITATION; VIOLATION NOTICE:
(A) Citation; Use For Certain Violations: Any person accused of violating any of the following designated provisions of this Code may be issued a citation
or, where applicable, an administrative violation notice without the filing of a complaint in court against him for such violation:
Violation of use of Village Seal, Village logos or Village flag as provided in section 1-12-7 of this title.
Violation of Fire Department restrictions as provided in section 2-13-15 of this Code.
Violation of public park and recreation area restrictions as provided in section 2-16-6 of this Code.
Violation of license or permit requirements as provided in section 3-1-8 of this Code.
Violation of alcoholic liquor restrictions as provided in section 3-2-12 of this Code.
Violation of bowling alley rules and regulations as provided in section 3-5-7 of this Code.
Violation of burglar alarm system regulations as provided in section 3-6-17 of this Code.
Violation of catch basin cleaning regulations as provided in section 3-7-6 of this Code.
Violation of Christmas tree sale regulations as provided in section 3-8-7 of this Code.
Violation of solicitation restrictions as provided in section 3-16-8 of this Code.
Violation of building rules and regulations as provided in section 4-1-14 of this Code.
Violation of sign regulations as provided in section 4-3-12 of this Code.
Violation of property maintenance regulations as provided in section 4-11-1 of this Code.
Violation of fire alarm system regulations as provided in section 5-4-5 of this Code.
Violation of public park restrictions as provided in section 6-1-14 of this Code.
Violation of weed growth restrictions as provided in section 6-1-17 of this Code.
Violation of graffiti restrictions as provided in section 6-1-23 of this Code.
Violation of tobacco and e-cigarette sales restrictions as provided in section 6-1-24 of this Code.
Violation of truancy regulations as provided in section 6-1-26 of this Code.
Violation of animal regulations as provided in section 6-2-9 of this Code.
Violation of dog licensing and regulations as provided in section 6-3-15 of this Code.
Violation of curfew regulations as provided in section 6-4-5 of this Code.
Violation of garbage and refuse regulations as provided in section 7-2-11 of this Code.
Violation of open burning regulations as provided in section 7-8-3 of this Code.
Violation of noise regulations as provided in sections 7-10-3 through 7-10-8 of this Code.
Violation of damaging sidewalks restrictions as provided in section 8-2-21 of this Code.
Violation of park and parkway planting restrictions as provided in section 8-5-10 of this Code.
Provided, however, that the use of citations and/or administrative violation notices without the filing of a complaint in court shall not be used for any of
the above listed violations where the person accused of violating such provisions has previously been cited for violating the same provision twice within
the previous twelve (12) months. (Ord. 2161, 9-16-1996; amd. Ord. 2197, 8-18-1997; Ord. 2484, 2-17-2004; Ord. 2501, 6-21-2004; Ord. 2537, 10-3-
2005; Ord. 2767, 5-2-2011; Ord. 2883, 10-15-2015; Ord. 2916, 7-21-2016)
(B) Citation Procedure: In lieu of filing a complaint in court, the proper police officer or other designated officer may employ the following citation procedure
in full settlement, compromise and disposition of any claimed violation of any of the above cited provisions of this Code:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 42/519
1. Said citations shall be in a form suitable for mailing, shall state the specific section of this code that was violated, and shall inform the alleged violator
that he may avoid appearance in court for such violation by payment of the amount specified below in full settlement of his liability for such violation.
2. Payment shall be due on or before a date set forth in the citation and not exceeding thirty (30) days from the date the violation was committed. Such
payment shall be made at the police department during normal business hours, either in person or by mailing the envelope portion of the citation,
and a receipt shall be issued for all such payment so received. The payment so received shall be forwarded to the village treasurer for deposit in the
proper village fund.
3. In the event that no payment is received during the period set forth in the citation or in a subsequent final notice, if one is issued, then the issuing
police officer or other designated officer shall cause a notice to appear to be served upon the alleged violator and shall file a complaint and prosecute
the same in the circuit court of Cook County.
4. Liability of any person for a violation specified in a citation issued pursuant to the provisions of this section may be settled upon payment to the
village of the amount specified for such violation in the following schedule:
(a) Where payment is made on or before the due date set forth in the citation, the amount shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00).
(b) Where payment is made during the additional period set forth in the final notice, the amount shall be fifty dollars ($50.00).
(c) Where payment is not made within the period set forth in subsections (B)4(a) and (B)4(b) of this section, the person or persons liable therefor
shall be subject to a fine as prescribed in section 1-4-1 of this chapter, to be determined by the circuit court of Cook County.
(C) Administrative Violation Notice: Whenever permitted by law, the proper police officer or other designated officer may employ the administrative violation
notice procedure as provided in title 9, chapter 6 of this code rather than the citation procedure with respect to the violations set forth in subsection (A)
of this section, or in other ordinances or regulations of this village. (Ord. 2161, 9-16-1996)
(D) Alternative Citation Procedure For Certain Violations: As an alternative to the citation procedure available under subsection (A) of this section, except
where other code provisions govern, the designated officer may elect to proceed as follows for the citation and prosecution of violations of the village's
property maintenance and building codes:
1. An initial notice of violation shall be sent by certified mail to the taxpayer or owner of record (hereinafter "owner") of property cited for code violations
advising of the specific code violations and allowing the owner thirty (30) days from receipt of the notice to correct the violation(s) or submit to the
officer a plan for compliance. Any such plan submitted is subject to the officer's approval.
2. If the owner fails to respond to the initial notice as required within the specified time period, a warning letter shall be sent to the owner allowing thirty
(30) additional days from receipt of the warning to correct the violation(s).
3. Failure to take appropriate action following the warning will result in the issuance of an initial violation ticket in the fine amount of two hundred fifty
dollars ($250.00). The owner shall have the option of paying the fine or appearing in the circuit court to contest the citation. Payment of the fine shall
not relieve the owner of the duty to correct the violations, and corrective action satisfactory to the officer shall be completed within thirty (30) days
from the date the ticket is issued, or such other later date as the court may order in the event the owner contests the citation.
4. Failure of owner to respond as required to the initial violation ticket shall result in the issuance to owner of a second violation ticket in the fine amount
of five hundred dollars ($500.00). The owner shall have the option of paying the fine or appearing in the circuit court to contest the citation. Payment
of the fine shall not relieve the owner of the duty to correct the violations, and corrective action satisfactory to the officer shall be completed within
thirty (30) days from the date the ticket is issued, or such other later date as the court may order in the event the owner contests the citation.
5. Failure of owner to respond as required to the second violation ticket shall result in the arrest of the owner by means of legal process for the offense
of a misdemeanor pursuant to complaint as provided in section 1-2-1 of the Illinois municipal code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2-1, which
provides for incarceration for a period not to exceed six (6) months.
6. Nothing contained in this section shall be deemed a limitation on the authority of the Village to seek from the court additional fines against owner and
in the maximum amount for each day the cited violations continue, and/or other remedies, all as authorized by law. (Ord. 2412, 6-17-2002)
1-4-7: PUBLIC SERVICE WORK:
The penalty imposed for violations of this Code, or for violations of other ordinances or regulations of this Village not contained in said Code, may include
or consist of a requirement that the violator perform some reasonable public service work such as, but not limited to, the picking up of litter in public parks
or along public roadways in this Village or the maintenance of public facilities within the Village. Such public service work shall be performed under the
supervision of the Department of Public Works, or the Office of the Village Manager or the Police Department. (Ord. 2161, 9-16-1996)
1-4-8: FEES AND COSTS OF COLLECTION:
For those fines and penalties provided for in this chapter, and such other penalties and fines as may be provided for in other chapters of this Code or
ordinances of the Village, any default in the payment of such fines or penalties or any installment of a fine or penalty may be collected by any means
authorized for the collection of monetary judgments. The Village may contract with attorneys and/or private collection agents for the purpose of collecting
any default in payment of any fine or penalty or installment of that fine or penalty authorized or imposed under this Code or ordinances of the Village. Any
fees and/or costs incurred by the Village with respect to attorneys or private collection agents retained by the Village under this section shall be charged to
the party legally responsible for the fine or penalty. (Ord. 2996, 8-2-2018)
Chapter 5
OFFICERS; GENERAL
1-5-1: OFFICERS ENUMERATED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 43/519
In addition to the board of trustees, the officers of the village shall consist of the following:
President Manager Police lieutenant
Clerk Chief of police Police sergeant
Treasurer Fire marshal Police patrolman
Attorney Health officer
together with such other officers as the president and said board may deem expedient from time to time. (1965 Code § 4.01)
1-5-2: ELECTIVE, APPOINTIVE OFFICERS; TERM:
(A) Elective Officers: The president and members of the board of trustees shall be elected in the manner and for the respective terms as provided by law.
(B) Appointive Officers: All appointive officers of the village shall be appointed by the president by and with the advice and consent of the board of
trustees. Their respective terms of office shall be as the president and board of trustees may determine, but shall not extend beyond the end of the
then current fiscal year unless otherwise specifically provided in this code. Vacancies occurring before the end of any term shall be filled as in the case
of the original appointment. In any event, each officer shall serve until his successor shall have been duly appointed and qualified. (Ord. 2811, 2-4-
2013)
1-5-3: OATH OF OFFICE:
All officers, whether elected or appointed, shall, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, take and subscribe to the following oath or
affirmation:
I do solemnly swear (or affirm, as the case may be) that I will support the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois,
and that I will faithfully discharge the duties of the office of , according to the best of my ability.
which oath or affirmation shall be filed in the office of the village clerk. (1965 Code § 4.04)
1-5-4: BONDS; FILING, SCHEDULE:
(A) Every village officer, other than a trustee, who shall be elected or appointed to office shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, execute his
bond, with a corporate surety, to be approved by the president and the board of trustees. This bond shall be payable to the village of Riverside in the
amount provided below and shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance by such officer of the duties of his office and the payment of all public
monies received by him, in accordance with law and the provisions of this code. All such bonds, except that of the clerk, shall be filed with the clerk; the
bond of the clerk being filed with the treasurer.
All premiums charged by the corporate surety on such bonds shall be paid by the village out of its general funds and in no case by the individual officer
furnishing the bond. (1965 Code § 4.05)
(B) The amounts of the official bonds required by subsection (A) of this section shall be as follows:
President $3,000.00
Clerk 1,000.00
Treasurer Statutory amount
Attorney $1,000.00
Manager 1,000.00
Fire marshal 1,000.00
Police chief 2,000.00
(1965 Code § 4.06)
1-5-5: ETHICS STATEMENT; FILING:
Every elected village officer, member of the planning and zoning commission, members of the library board, any village officer or employee whose annual
compensation is at a rate of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) or more, and all such other village officers or employees as may be hereinafter
designated by statute, shall file a verified written statement of economic interests as provided by the Illinois governmental ethics act. (Ord. 2843, 12-19-
2013)
1-5-6: OFFICIAL COMMISSION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 44/519
All officers, elected or appointed, except the president and clerk, shall be commissioned by warrant signed by the president and attested by the clerk under
the corporate seal. The commission shall be substantially the following form:
Official Commission Village of Riverside, Illinois. Greeting: having been duly elected or appointed to the office of in and for the said Village, in the
County of Cook and State of Illinois, for the term from , 19 , to 19 , and until his successor shall have been duly elected or appointed and qualified.
Given under my hand and the Corporate Seal of said Village, on , 19 .
President
Attest:
Village Clerk
(1965 Code § 4.07)
1-5-7: POWERS AND DUTIES:
Every village officer, besides the powers and duties assigned to him by this code, shall also have the further powers and perform the further duties which
usually pertain to his office, and shall be subject to such other rules and regulations as the president and board of trustees may from time to time prescribe
or by ordinance establish. (1965 Code § 4.08)
1-5-8: SALARIES:
The salaries of all officers, employees and appointees of the village shall be in the amounts fixed from time to time by the president and board of trustees
in its budget or by ordinance. (Ord. 2811, 2-4-2013)
1-5-9: MONEY COLLECTED; REPORTS:
Every officer or employee of the village who shall collect money belonging to the village shall each month or as otherwise provided by the president and
board of trustees pay over to the village treasurer such money together with an itemized written report covering his collections for the next preceding
month. (1965 Code § 4.09)
1-5-10: RECORDS; DISPOSITION:
Any person having been an officer of the village shall, within five (5) days after notification and request, deliver to his successor in office all property, books
and effects of every description in his possession belonging to the village and appertaining to his office. (1965 Code § 4.11)
1-5-11: PERMITS IN WRITING:
All permits issued by any officer, pursuant to the provisions of this code shall be in writing, and duplicates thereof shall be kept in permanent form. (1965
Code § 4.12)
1-5-12: INDEMNIFICATION:
If any claim or action is instituted against an officer or employee of the village based on an injury allegedly arising out of an act or omission occurring within
the scope of his or her service or employment as an officer or employee, the village shall do any one or more of the following as appropriate:
(A) Appear and defend against the claim or action;
(B) Indemnify the officer or employee for his or her court costs incurred in the defense of such claim or action;
(C) Pay or indemnify the officer or employee for a judgment based on such claim or action; and/or
(D) Pay or indemnify the officer or employee for a compromise or settlement of such claim or action.
Such indemnification shall not apply to any portion of a judgment representing an award of punitive or exemplary damages. This section shall be
interpreted to the full extent of section 2-302 of the tort immunity act. To the extent authorized by that statute, it shall apply to claims or actions against
former officers and employees. (Ord. 2337, 6-19-2000)
Chapter 6
VILLAGE BOARD OF TRUSTEES
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 45/519
1-6-1: TRUSTEES, ELECTION:
The board of trustees shall consist of the president and six (6) trustees, who shall be elected as provided by law and who shall hold office for a term of four
(4) years each and until their successors are elected and have qualified. (1965 Code § 3.01)
1-6-2: FUNCTIONS:
The board of trustees shall constitute the legislative body of the village government and shall have the powers and perform the duties provided by statute,
the provisions of this code and ordinances of the village. (1965 Code § 3.02)
1-6-3: PRESIDENT:
The president shall preside at all meetings of the board of trustees and at all times when the board meets as a committee of the whole. (1965 Code § 3.03)
1-6-4: MEETINGS:
(A) Regular Meetings: The regular meetings of the board of trustees shall be held on the first and third Thursday of each month. Meetings shall start at
seven o'clock (7:00) P.M., in the village hall unless otherwise ordered by the board. (Ord. 2817, 5-6-2013)
(B) Special Meetings: Special meetings may be called by the president or any three (3) trustees upon at least forty eight (48) hours' notice to all members
and the president. (Ord. 2720, 6-1-2009)
1-6-5: QUORUM:
A majority of the members of the board of trustees, including the president, shall constitute a quorum to do business. A smaller number, however, may
meet and adjourn from time to time. (Ord. 2250, 10-5-1998)
1-6-6: ORDER OF BUSINESS:
The order of business shall be determined by the village president before posting of the agenda. The order may be suspended by a majority of the trustees
present. (Ord. 2817, 5-6-2013)
1-6-7: ROBERT'S RULES OF ORDER:
The president shall decide all questions of order, and the rules of order and parliamentary practice comprised in the current edition of "Robert's Rules Of
Order Revised", shall govern the deliberations of the board of trustees in all cases to which they are applicable and in all cases in which they are not
inconsistent with the rules of the board. (1965 Code § 3.07)
1-6-8: BOARD COMMITTEES AND TRUSTEE ASSIGNMENTS:
(A) Committee Of The Whole: The board of trustees shall meet as a committee of the whole as needed. No final actions shall be taken at a committee of
the whole meeting. (Ord. 2720, 6-1-2009)
(B) Trustee Assignments: Each trustee shall be assigned by the village president to serve as a liaison to subordinate boards, committees, and
commissions as determined by the village president. (Ord. 2817, 5-6-2013)
(C) Special Committees: Special committees shall be appointed by the board of trustees from time to time for any such purpose as the board may deem
necessary. Special committees shall be discharged without formal vote of the board upon acceptance of their final report. (Ord. 2720, 6-1-2009)
Chapter 7
VILLAGE PRESIDENT
1-7-1: ELECTION, TERM OF OFFICE:
The Village President shall be elected as provided by statute for a term of four (4) years. (1965 Code, Sec. 5.01)
1-7-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The President shall be the chief executive officer of the Village and shall have all powers and perform all duties assigned to his office by statute or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 46/519
ordinance. He shall be President of the Board of Trustees and shall exercise general supervision over all executive and administrative offices of the
Village. (1965 Code, Sec. 5.02)
1-7-3: COMMISSIONS, LICENSES, PERMITS, BONDS:
The President shall sign all commissions, licenses, and permits granted by authority of the Board of Trustees. He may revoke said licenses, except as
otherwise provided by law or ordinance, subject to the approval of the Board of Trustees. Except where otherwise expressly provided, the President shall
approve all surety bonds required by this Code. (1965 Code, Sec. 5.03)
Chapter 8
VILLAGE MANAGER
1-8-1: APPOINTMENT; TERM:
(A) The village manager shall be appointed to serve at the pleasure of the president and board of trustees for a term of one year as may be determined at
the time of his appointment. (Ord. 2196, 8-18-1997)
(B) A deputy village manager may be appointed from time to time to act as assistant to the village manager. He shall also act in place of and with the
powers of the village manager, if and when the village manager is absent or incapacitated and if and when the position of village manager is vacant.
(1965 Code § 7.01)
1-8-2: FUNCTIONS AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
(A) The village manager shall exercise general supervision over and be executive manager of all departments and activities of the municipal government
of this village, and shall perform such other duties as may be prescribed by ordinance or directed by the president and board of trustees.
(B) The village manager shall maintain an office in the village hall and shall devote his entire time to the performance of his duties.
(C) He shall render to the several officers of the village, and said officers shall render to him, all such assistance as is possible in the performance of their
respective duties, and all officers and employees of the village shall furnish and disclose to him such oral or written information and material relating to
the affairs of the village as he shall request. (1965 Code § 7.02)
1-8-3: PURCHASING AGENT:
The village manager shall be the purchasing agent for the village, except where specific provision to the contrary is made by statute, or by the president of
the board of trustees. He shall have authority and it shall be his duty, when so authorized by the board of trustees, to purchase all supplies, materials,
equipment, contractual services and insurance needed by the village or any department, board or officer thereof, including authority to purchase personal
property, supplies and services under a joint governmental purchasing program with the state or other governmental units. (Ord. 1418, 1-21-1980)
1-8-4: REQUISITIONS, PURCHASES, CONTRACTS:
(A) Requisitions: No orders for materials or supplies totaling two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) or more shall be purchased by the village
manager unless and until a proper requisition for the same has been filed with him or her by an official authorized to make such requisition. (Ord. 2822,
9-5-2013)
(B) Purchases And Contracts Not Exceeding Twenty Thousand Dollars: The village manager may, in his or her discretion, without previous authorization of
the board of trustees, purchase supplies, materials, or equipment, and may enter into contracts for any work or public improvement, costing not more
than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00). The village manager is further authorized to sign checks on behalf of the village in amounts of no more than
twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) for such purposes.
(C) Emergency Purchases: In case of an emergency arising from unforeseen causes which requires the immediate purchase of supplies, materials or
equipment, or contractual services, the village manager may secure on the open market at the lowest obtainable price any commodities or contractual
services costing more than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) and place an order therefor. In the absence of the village manager, the chief of police
or the fire chief may secure on the open market at the lowest obtainable price any commodities or contractual services costing more than twenty
thousand dollars ($20,000.00) and place an order therefor. Documentation of the emergency and the need for immediate action will be presented to the
board of trustees in a reasonable period of time following resolution of the crisis.
(D) Purchases And Contracts Exceeding Twenty Thousand Dollars: All purchase orders or contracts for supplies, materials, equipment or contractual
services, and all public improvement contracts which are not to be paid for by special assessment or special taxation, involving the expenditure of more
than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), shall be let to the lowest responsible bidder after advertisement for bids as provided in this section, or
without advertising for bids if so authorized by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of all the trustees elected. For all contracts exceeding twenty thousand dollars
($20,000.00) made with a state or local governmental purchasing cooperative, competitive bidding is waived.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 47/519
(E) Public Improvements And Special Assessments: Every contract for any work or public improvement to be paid for, in whole or in part by special
assessment or special taxation, shall be let to the lowest responsible bidder, after advertisement for bids as provided in this section or state statute.
(F) Advertising For Bids:
1. Whenever advertising for bids is required, the village manager shall cause a call for such bids to be published in some newspaper published in the
village or of general circulation within the village, and, if he so elects, such other newspaper of general circulation therein as in his judgment may be
desirable. Such advertisement shall be published once, publication to be not less than ten (10) calendar days prior to the day fixed for opening bids.
2. Where the advertisement is for a public improvement, the published notice need give only a general description of the work to be done or the
materials to be furnished, but detailed drawings, plans, profiles and specifications, as prescribed by the ordinance ordering such improvement, shall
be made and placed on file in the office of the village manager prior to the first publication of such advertisement and shall at all times be open to
public inspection.
3. In such advertisement, the right to reject any or all bids shall be expressly reserved.
(G) Requisites For Bids: In all cases, the bids for doing any work or making any public improvement shall be sealed bids, directed to the village manager,
and may be accompanied by a certified check or bond not to exceed ten percent (10%) of the estimated cost of the improvement or work to be done or
of the materials or supplies to be furnished.
(H) Contracts, Execution: All contracts for work materials or supplies exceeding in amount the sum of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), shall be
executed in writing and shall be signed by the village manager or director of finance on the part of the village, and by the contractor. One executed
copy must be filed in the office of the village manager and the other must be delivered to the contractor. All contracts must be in the names of and run
to the village.
(I) Approval Of Bills: The village manager shall control and direct all expenditures made by the village. The board of trustees usually approves payment of
bills. However, the village manager shall have authority to approve bills of less than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) when prompt payment is
necessary and will prevent interruption in business operations which could be counterproductive or have negative consequences to the village. He shall
have authority to approve bills in amounts greater than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) when the board of trustees has previously approved the
vendor and contract amount. He shall have authority to approve bills in an emergency which could affect the health and welfare of the village and when
prompt payment is necessary to protect the public interest. In months in which the village board holds only one regular meeting, he shall have authority
to approve bills of any amount and direct their payment. He shall, before the same are presented to the board of trustees for subsequent ratification,
certify as to the correctness of all bills. (An acting village manager shall not pay bills until they have been approved by the board of trustees.) (Ord.
2810, 2-4-2013)
1-8-5: GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES:
In general, the village manager shall have, but shall not be limited to, the following other powers and duties:
(A) Subject to limitations prescribed by the board of trustees, or by law, the village manager shall have authority to hire and to discharge all employees and
to fix their compensation.
(B) It shall be the duty of the village manager to prepare and to submit to the board of trustees for its consideration, as soon as practicable after the close
of each fiscal year, a budget containing estimates of revenues and expenses for the ensuing fiscal year, which can serve as a basis for the preparation
of the appropriation ordinance for that year. (1965 Code § 7.07)
(C) He shall act as business manager of the village under the direction of the board of trustees and in cooperation with the village treasurer and clerk. He
shall have supervision over the accounting work of the village, and shall certify as to the correctness of accounts before they are presented to the
board for approval. He shall keep or cause to be kept, full and complete books of account showing the exact condition of the financial affairs of the
village, and shall supervise the keeping of all necessary records to accomplish this to the extent that such supervision is not vested in the treasurer or
clerk by statute or ordinance. (Ord. 2504, 7-19-2004)
(D) He shall attend all regular and special meetings of the board of trustees unless excused by the board.
(E) He shall advise and assist regularly constituted boards and commissions and provide necessary facilities for their operations and purposes as directed
by the board of trustees.
(F) He shall render or cause to be rendered and correlated monthly to the board of trustees, a written report covering the work of each department or
operation of the village under his management and monthly statements showing the exact financial condition of the village as of the end of the
preceding month and a summarized statement of receipts and expenditures.
(G) He shall also, following promptly at the end of each fiscal year of the village, prepare and present to the board a written report summarizing the work
during such fiscal year of each department, office or operation of the village under his management and a financial statement including the same
information for each fiscal year as is required on the monthly financial statement.
(H) He shall from time to time make recommendations to the board of trustees relative to the adoption of such ordinances and resolutions as he may deem
necessary and such reports or recommendations relative to the affairs of the village as he may deem advisable or the board of trustees may request.
(1965 Code § 7.08)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 48/519
(I) 1. The village manager is authorized to revise the annual budget, after its approval, as follows:
(a) To authorize spending within individual line items to exceed budget amounts, provided that spending within the department does not exceed the
budget amount for that department.
(b) To authorize budget transfers between nonpersonnel line items within a department.
(c) To authorize budget transfers between departments within the same fund of less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), provided that such
transfers shall not affect personnel line items.
2. The village board reserves the authority to make all other revisions to the budget, including the following budget revisions:
(a) To authorize any budget transfer affecting a personnel line item.
(b) To authorize any budget transfer between departments in an amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or more.
(c) To authorize any budget transfer or loan between funds.
(d) To authorize any increase or decrease in the total budget for a fund. (Ord. 2380, 10-15-2001)
Chapter 9
VILLAGE CLERK
1-9-1: APPOINTMENT:
The village clerk shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. (Ord. 2522, 1-3-2005)
1-9-2: GENERAL DUTIES:
The village clerk shall attend all meetings of the president and board of trustees and keep a full record of its proceedings in the journal. The record of those
proceedings shall be made available for public inspection at least twenty four (24) hours before the next regularly scheduled meeting of the president and
board of trustees.
In addition, the village clerk shall keep all records, receive, mark and properly file all papers coming into his or her office belonging to the village; grant
certified copies from records or papers of the village, and execute such orders as he or she may receive from the president and board of trustees, and the
village clerk shall perform all such further duties imposed by statute, the provisions of this code or by ordinance of the village, and such other and further
duties as may from time to time be required of the clerk by the board of trustees.
Copies of all papers duly filed in his or her office, and transcripts from the journals and other records and files of his or her office, certified by the village
clerk under the corporate seal, shall be evidence in all courts in like manner as if the originals were produced. (Ord. 2000, 5-4-1992)
1-9-3: COMMUNICATIONS WITH BOARD:
(A) Communications To Board: The clerk shall receive all communications addressed to the board of trustees and shall present and read same at the
meeting of the board next succeeding their receipt by him, unless otherwise ordered by the board. (1965 Code, Sec. 6.03)
(B) Communications From Board: The clerk shall, without delay, deliver to the officers of the village and to all committees of the board of trustees all
resolutions and communications referred to such officers or committees by the board. (1965 Code, Sec. 6.04)
1-9-4: MEETINGS; NOTICES:
The clerk shall issue notices to the members of the board when directed by the president or by that body and, when directed by the chairman thereof, to all
persons whose attendance will be required before any committee, and shall also issue notices of special meetings of the board of trustees. (1965 Code,
Sec. 6.05)
1-9-5: ORDINANCE DUTIES:
(A) Transmittal: The clerk shall, without delay, deliver to the president all ordinances or resolutions passed by the board of trustees which may require
approval or other action by the president, together with all supporting papers. (1965 Code, Sec. 6.06)
(B) Publication: The clerk shall cause ordinances of the village imposing any fine, penalty, imprisonment or forfeiture, or making any appropriation to be
published as required by statute, in a secular newspaper published or having a general circulation within the village, or in pamphlet form. (Ord. 2000, 5-
4-1992)
(C) Record: The clerk shall record, in a book to be kept for that purpose, all ordinances passed by the president and board of trustees; at the foot of the
record of each ordinance so recorded he shall make a memorandum of the date of the passage, approval and of publication, if any, of such ordinances,
which record and memorandum, or certified copy thereof, shall be prima facie evidence of the passage and legal publication of such ordinance for all
purposes whatsoever. (1965 Code § 6.08)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 49/519
1-9-6: NOTIFICATION OF ELECTION OR APPOINTMENT:
The clerk shall, within five (5) days after the result of any election is declared or appointment made, notify all persons elected or appointed to any village
office of their election or appointment. (1965 Code § 6.10)
1-9-7: LICENSES; DUTIES:
(A) Issue; Attestation: The clerk shall sign and issue all licenses and permits, if and as required by the provisions of this code or any other provisions of the
village or as so ordered by the president and board of trustees or other proper officer of the village. (1965 Code § 6.11)
(B) Record: The clerk shall keep a full record of all licenses granted, transferred or revoked by the president and board of trustees, or other village
authority, and if revoked, the cause therefor, with serial numbers thereof and the full name and residence of the applicants for such licenses, and where
bonds are required, the names of the bondsmen or sureties. (1965 Code § 6.12)
1-9-8: OFFICE; SEAL; RECORDS:
The clerk shall keep his office at the village hall, keep the seal of the village and affix the same to all papers requiring the corporate seal. (1965 Code
§ 6.13)
1-9-9: DEPUTY CLERK:
The village clerk may, by and with the consent of the president and board of trustees, appoint a deputy, who in the absence of the clerk in case of sickness
or otherwise, shall be empowered to perform all the duties of said clerk. (1965 Code § 6.15)
1-9-10: SALARY:
The annual compensation for the office of village clerk shall be as established from time to time by the president and board of trustees in its budget or by
ordinance. (Ord. 2811, 2-4-2013)
Chapter 10
VILLAGE TREASURER
1-10-1: APPOINTMENT, TERM:
The Treasurer shall be appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees and shall serve for a term of one year. (1974
Code)
1-10-2: EX OFFICIO COLLECTOR:
The Treasurer shall be, ex officio, Village Collector, but for this service shall receive no additional emolument beyond his compensation as Treasurer.
(1965 Code, Sec. 8.01)
1-10-3: GENERAL DUTIES:
The Treasurer in addition to the duties prescribed by statute, shall have general management and control of all operations of the Finance Department, as
provided in Chapter 12 of Title 2 of this Code, and shall have the following duties, functions and responsibilities:
Administrative analysis
Administration of purchasing for all departments
Authorized agent or treasurer of subsidiary agencies and special funds of the Village
Custodian of all financial and general records of the Village.
General accounting
Personnel administration
Preparation and maintenance of inventory of real and personal property and the value and insurance coverage thereon
Preparation of financial reports and statements
Special assessment administration and accounting
Supervision of Village Treasury
Supervision of expenditures
The Treasurer shall also have all other duties, powers, functions and responsibilities, whether similar to or dissimilar from those above specifically
mentioned, which, by existing ordinances, are expressed as given to the Village Treasurer. (1965 Code, Sec. 8.02)
1-10-4: REPORTS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 50/519
(A) Monthly Reports: The Treasurer shall, at the end of every month, and more often if required by the President and Board of Trustees, make a report to
the said Board of Trustees, containing a full and detailed account of all receipts and expenditures of each fund and account of the Village, as shown by
his books for the preceding calendar month, in accordance with statutory provisions therefor.
(B) Annual Reports: Within six (6) months following the end of each fiscal year, the Treasurer shall complete and file with the Village Clerk all annual
financial reports of all Village receipts and expenditures and of his transactions as Treasurer during the preceding fiscal year, in accordance with the
statutory provisions pertaining thereto. Upon receipt of said annual report, and not later than ten (10) days thereafter, the Village Clerk shall cause the
same to be published at least once in a newspaper published and having a general circulation within the Village. (Ord. 1991, 4-6-92)
1-10-5: DEPUTY TREASURER:
The Village Treasurer may, by and with the consent of the President and the Board of Trustees, appoint a deputy who shall assist the Treasurer, and who,
in the absence of said Treasurer in case of sickness or otherwise, shall be empowered to perform all of the duties of Village Treasurer. (Ord. 1095, 7-15-
68)
1-10-6: INVESTMENTS:
The Village Treasurer shall be responsible for and is hereby authorized to invest the public funds and the surplus funds of this Village in accordance with
and in compliance with the statutory provisions and restrictions pertaining to such investments. (Ord. 1962, 11-18-91)
Chapter 11
VILLAGE ATTORNEY
1-11-1: APPOINTMENT, TERM:
The Village Attorney shall be appointed by the President by and with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, for a term of one year. (1965 Code,
Sec. 9.01)
1-11-2: DUTIES:
The Village Attorney shall have all of the powers and perform all of the duties now or hereafter provided by law or by the ordinances of the Village. Among
other things, it shall be his duty:
(A) To attend all meetings of the Board of Trustees and to give oral or written opinions on all legal questions submitted to him by the President or Board of
Trustees;
(B) To draft all ordinances, bonds, contracts, conveyances and other written instruments required by the Board or by other administrative bodies in the
transaction of Village business;
(C) To prosecute or defend all suits for or in behalf of the Village, or any official of the Village in his official character subject to the order and direction of
the President and Board of Trustees;
(D) To give the necessary attention to all proceedings before the Illinois Commerce Commission, and before other administrative and regulatory bodies, in
which the Village may be a party or be directly interested;
(E) To prosecute all cases brought before the court for any Village ordinance when directed by the President or Board of Trustees, or in an emergency, by
the Chief of Police;
(F) To superintend all proceedings in reference to the levying and collection of the general taxes of the Village;
(G) To keep in suitable books provided for that purpose a docket of all suits or proceedings prosecuted or defended by him in which the Village is an
interested party;
(H) To act as the attorney for the Board of Local Improvements and attend all meetings of said Board, to prepare or supervise the preparation of all
necessary instruments, resolutions, notices, recommendations, estimates, all contracts and contractor's bonds in connection with any proposed local
improvement. He shall institute all court proceedings in connection with the levying of special assessments or special tax proceedings for all local
improvements and prosecute said proceedings to their conclusion. (1965 Code, Sec. 9.02)
1-11-3: SPECIAL COUNSEL:
Nothing in this Code contained shall be construed as prohibiting the Board of Trustees from employing special counsel to represent the Village from time
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 51/519
to time, or for paying such compensation to such special counsel as the said Board of Trustees may from time to time determine. (1965 Code, Sec. 9.03)
Chapter 12
OFFICIAL VILLAGE DESIGNS
1-12-1: OFFICIAL VILLAGE SEAL:
The official Corporate Seal of the Village shall be circular in form and shall have on the outer circle the legend "The Village of Riverside, Incorporated July
A.D. 1875" and in the center the motto "Villae in Silvis". The following is a facsimile of said seal:
(1965 Code §§ 2.01, 2.02)
1-12-2: CUSTODY AND USE OF SEAL:
The seal shall be and remain in the custody of the Village Clerk, to be used by him in all cases provided for by any provision of this Code or other
ordinance of the Village or by laws of the State, and in all such other cases whereby the laws and customs of any state or nation the use of the seal
becomes necessary. (1965 Code § 2.03)
1-12-3: RESERVED:
(Ord. 2916, 7-21-2016)
1-12-4: OFFICIAL TIME; APPLICATION:
(A) Official time within the Village for the transaction of all Village business shall be Central Standard Time for the period between and including the last
Sunday in October to the first Sunday in the following April, and Central Daylight Savings Time during the remainder of the year.
(B) All proceedings of the President and Board of Trustees and all business of the Village shall be regulated by the time herein established, and when by
ordinance, resolution or action of any Municipal officer or body an act must be performed at or within a prescribed time, it shall be performed according
to the official time herein prescribed. (Ord. 2116, 4-10-1995)
1-12-5: OFFICIAL LOGOS:
The official logos of the Village shall be as set forth below:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 52/519
The logos shall be available for general use on stationery, publications and other documents issued by the Village, and for such other uses as authorized
by the Board of Trustees or Village Manager. A style guide relative to the logos shall be kept on file in the Office of the Village Clerk. (Ord. 2916, 7-21-
2016)
1-12-6: OFFICIAL FLAG:
The official flag of this Village shall be that certain flag design prepared and recommended by the Flag Committee established in 2005, which flag contains
a sketch of the historic water tower with the following text emblazoned in a circle around the tower "Illinois, Villae in Silvis, 1875". (Ord. 2543, 12-19-2005)
1-12-7: PENALTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to make any use or publication of the official Village Seal, Village logos, or Village flag design without first obtaining
authorization and approval of the President and Board of Trustees. Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall, upon conviction, be subject to
the penalty as provided for by section 1-4-1 of this title, and each day that such violation continues shall be considered to be a separate offense. In lieu of
filing a complaint in court, the proper police officer or other designated officer may employ the compromise and settlement procedure as provided in
section 1-4-6 of this title in full settlement, compromise and disposition of any claimed violation of this section. (Ord. 2537, 10-3-2005; amd. Ord. 2916, 7-
21-2016)

The regular election for Village officials shall be held on the third Tuesday of April of every odd numbered year, and every two (2) years thereafter.

The manner of calling, conducting, voting at, canvassing and contesting Village elections shall be the same, as nearly as may be, as that set out in "The

Chapter 14
WORKING CASH FUND
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 54/519
1-14-1: ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND:
There is hereby established in the Village of Riverside, Cook County, Illinois, a Fund which shall be known as the "Working Cash Fund" and which Fund
shall be used for the purpose of enabling the Village to have in its Treasury at all times sufficient money to meet demands therein for ordinary and
necessary expenditures for all general and special corporate purposes.
1-14-2: BONDS:
For the purpose of creating such Working Cash Fund, the President and Board of Trustees of the Village may incur an indebtedness and issue bonds
therefor, in an amount or amounts not exceeding in the aggregate seven hundred thousand dollars ($700,000.00); which bonds shall bear interest at a rate
of not more than seven percent (7%) annually and shall mature within twenty (20) years from the date thereof. Such bonds shall be issued by Ordinance
setting forth the terms thereof which shall be operative and valid without submission thereof to the electors of the Village for approval in accordance with
the requirements of Sections 8-4-1 and 8-4-2, Chapter 24, Illinois Revised Statutes.
1-14-3: SPECIAL TAX:
For the pupose of providing money for such Working Cash Fund, the President and Board of Trustees of the Village shall have power to levy, annually,
upon all the taxable property in the Village, a special tax which shall be known as the "Working Cash Fund Tax," which tax shall not exceed the rate of fivehundredths
percent (.05%) upon the value, as assessed and equalized by the Department of Local Government Affairs of all taxable property in this
Village. (Ord. 1242; 9-16-74)
Chapter 15
SPECIAL TAXES
1-15-1: MUNICIPAL AUDITING TAX:
There is hereby authorized and established within the Village of Riverside, a special tax which shall be known as the"Municipal auditing tax" which shall be
levied annually upon all the taxable property of this Village, as equalized and assessed by the Illinois Department of Local Government Affairs, at the rate
on the dollar which will produce a sum sufficient to meet the cost of obtaining the annual Municipal audit of the funds and accounts of this Village pursuant
to the provisions of "The Illinois Municipal Auditing Law". Such Municipal auditing tax shall be held in a special fund and shall be used for no other purpose
than the payment of expenses occasioned by the annual Municipal audit.
The amount deemed necessary to obtain an annual audit of the funds and accounts of this Village shall be included in the annual appropriation ordinance
adopted for each fiscal year, commencing with Ordinance No. 1284, heretofore adopted and published on July 30, 1976, as the Annual Appropriation
Ordinance for the fiscal year commencing May 1, 1976; and the Municipal auditing tax necessary to be levied annually to meet the said cost of the
Municipal audit shall be set forth in the tax levy ordinance for each year in question, commencing with Ordinance No. 1286 adopted August 16, 1976, as
the Tax Levy Ordinance for the fiscal year beginning May 1, 1976.
The Village Clerk is authorized and directed to file a certified copy of this Ordinance in the office of the County Clerk of Cook County, Illinois. (Ord. 1287, 9-
20-76)
1-15-2: LIABILITY INSURANCE TAX:
There is hereby authorized and established within the Village of Riverside, a special tax which shall be known as the "liability insurance tax" which shall be
levied annually at a rate that will produce a sum which will be sufficient to pay the cost of purchasing liability insurance to insure the Village against any
loss or liability which may be imposed pursuant to the "Local Governmental and Governmental Employees Tort Immunity Act".1 Such tax shall be levied
and collected in like manner with the other general taxes of the Village and shall be exclusive and in addition to the amount of tax that the Village is now or
may hereafter be authorized to levy for general purposes.
The amount deemed necessary to produce an amount sufficient to pay the cost of purchasing such insurance for this Village shall be included in the
annual appropriation ordinance adopted for each fiscal year, commencing with Ordinance No. 1284, heretofore adopted and published on July 30, 1976,
as the Annual Appropriation Ordinance for the fiscal year commencing May 1, 1976; and the liability insurance tax necessary to be levied annually to meet
the cost of such Municipal insurance shall be set forth in the tax levy ordinance for each year in question, commencing with Ordinance No. 1286 adopted
August 16, 1976, as the Tax Levy Ordinance for the fiscal year beginning May 1, 1976.
This Village Clerk is authorized and directed to file a certified copy of this Ordinance in the office of the County Clerk of Cook County, Illinois. (Ord. 1288,
9-20-76)
Chapter 16
MUNICIPAL PUBLIC WORKS PROJECTS
1-16-1: CONSTRUCTION WORKERS, PREVAILING WAGE RATE:
To the extent and as required by "an act regulating wages of laborers, mechanics and other workers employed in any public works by the state, county, city
or any public body or any political subdivision or by anyone under contract for public works", approved June 26, 1941, as amended, the general prevailing
rate of wages in this locality for laborers, mechanics and other workers engaged in the construction of public works coming under the jurisdiction of this
village is hereby ascertained to be the same as the prevailing rate of wages for construction work in Cook County as determined by the department of
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 55/519
labor of the state of Illinois as of May 1, 2010, a copy of that determination being attached as exhibit A to the ordinance codified herein and incorporated
herein. As required by said act, any and all revisions of the prevailing rate of wages by the department of labor of the state of Illinois shall supersede the
department's June determination and apply to any and all public works construction undertaken by the village. The definition of any terms appearing in the
ordinance codified herein which are also used in aforesaid act shall be the same as in said act.
Nothing herein contained shall be construed to apply said general prevailing rate of wages as herein ascertained to any work or employment except public
works construction of this village to the extent required by the aforesaid act.
The village clerk shall publicly post or keep available for inspection by any interested party in the main office of this village, this determination or any
revisions of such prevailing rate of wage. A copy of this determination or of the current revised determination of prevailing rate of wages then in effect shall
be attached to all contract specifications.
The village clerk shall mail a copy of this determination to any employer, and to any association of employers and to any person or association of
employees who have filed their names and addresses, requesting copies of any determination stating the particular rates and the particular class of
workmen whose wages will be affected by such rates. (Ord. 2744, 5-17-2010)
1-16-2: CONTRACTOR REQUIREMENTS:
All construction contracts entered into with the village and all other contracts entered into by and between any person for the construction or installation of
public improvements, including streets, sidewalks, curb and gutters, water mains, sanitary and storm sewers, streetlights, water reservoirs, drainage
retention or detention areas, public buildings, water hydrants, park and parkway tree removal or replacement, and any other improvement for public use
shall, as a minimum contain the following contractor requirements:
(A) The contractor shall file a copy of the project plans and specifications with the village manager.
(B) The contractor shall obtain and keep in effect throughout the contract period a performance and a labor and material bond in the contract amount.
(C) The contractor shall furnish a one year maintenance bond in an amount determined by the village to ensure the timely repair or replacement of faulty
workmanship or materials.
(D) The contractor shall maintain in force throughout the contract period public liability insurance in an amount sufficient to protect the contractor and the
village against risks of damage or injury (including death) to persons or property wherever located, resulting from any action or operation under the
contract or in connection with the work. The limits of liability shall not be less than two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for injury to one
person or a maximum sum of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for personal injuries in any one accident, and not less than two hundred
thousand dollars ($200,000.00) for damage to property in any one occurrence. Such insurance shall be issued by a company authorized to do business
in the state, and such insurance shall further provide that it shall not be canceled unless ten (10) days' advance notice in writing to the village shall be
made. A copy of the insurance policy or a certificate thereof shall be filed with the village manager.
(E) The contractor shall maintain in force throughout the contract period automobile liability insurance covering all owned or rented vehicles and moving
equipment used in connection with the work, and insuring the contractor and the Village for all damages or personal injury growing out of such use in
the maximum limit of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) in any one occurrence, and for all damages to personal property in the maximum
limit of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for any one occurrence. Such insurance shall be issued by a company authorized to do business
in the State, and such insurance shall provide that it shall not be canceled unless ten (10) days' advance notice in writing to the Village shall be made.
A copy of the insurance policy or a certificate thereof, shall be filed with the Village Manager.
(F) The contractor shall maintain in force throughout the contract period workmen's compensation and employer's liability insurance in an amount sufficient
to protect the contractor and the Village from any liability or damage for injury (including death) to any of the contractor's employees, including any
