2. Perform such other duties or acts as may reasonably be required and as directed by the hearing officer or ordinance enforcement administrator.
(Ord. 2830, 11-7-2013)
1-23-7: HEARING PROCEDURES NOT EXCLUSIVE:
This chapter does not preclude the village from using any other lawful methods to enforce the provisions of its municipal ordinances, including its building
code. (Ord. 2830, 11-7-2013)
1-23-8: CODE ENFORCEMENT PROCEDURES:
(A) When a full time, part time or auxiliary police officer, community service officer, code enforcement officer or inspector, or other individual specifically
authorized by any village official or village department to issue a municipal ordinance violation notice finds a municipal ordinance violation to exist, he
or she shall note the violation on a multiple copy violation notice and report form that shall include, but shall not be limited to:
1. The name and address of the party violating the ordinance, if known, or the property owner for a building code violation;
2. The type and nature of the violation;
3. The date and time the violation was observed;
4. The names of the witnesses of the violation;
5. The fine and penalty which may be assessed for late payment;
6. The signature and identification number of the person issuing the notice;
7. The legal authority and jurisdiction under which the hearing is to be held and the penalties for failure to appear at the hearing; and
8. In the case of a building code violation or other property related violation, the address of the property where the violation is observed.
(B) The correctness of facts contained in any ordinance violation notice shall be verified by the person issuing the notice by:
1. Signing his/her name to the notice at the time of issuance; or
2. In the case of a notice produced by a computer, signing a single certificate, to be kept by the ordinance enforcement administrator, attesting to the
correctness of all notices produced by the computer while under his/her control.
(C) The violation report form shall be forwarded to the ordinance enforcement department where a docket number shall be stamped on all copies of the
report and a hearing date shall be noted in the blank spaces provided for that purpose on the form.
(D) The hearing date shall not be less than thirty (30) nor more than forty (40) days after the violation is reported.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 72/519
(E) One copy of the violation report form shall be maintained in the files of the ordinance enforcement department and shall be part of the record of
hearing.
(F) One copy of the report form shall be returned to the individual representing the village in the case so that he or she may prepare evidence of the
municipal ordinance violation for presentation at the hearing on the date indicated.
(G) One copy of the report form shall be served by first class mail to the alleged violator along with a summons commanding the alleged violator to appear
at the hearing.
(H) In the case of a building code violation only, if the village has an ordinance requiring property owners, meaning the legal or beneficial owner(s) of a
structure, to register with it, service may be made on the owner by mailing the report and summons to the property owner's address registered with the
village.
(I) In the case of a building code violation only, if the name of the property owner cannot be ascertained or if service on the owner cannot be made by mail,
service may be made on the owner by posting or nailing a copy of the violation report form on the front door of the structure where the violation is
found, not less than twenty (20) days before the hearing is scheduled.
(J) Any municipal ordinance violation notice issued, signed and served in accordance herewith or a copy of the notice, shall be prima facie correct and
shall be prima facie evidence of the correctness of the facts shown on the notice and shall be admissible in any subsequent administrative or legal
proceeding. (Ord. 2830, 11-7-2013)
1-23-9: RETALIATION AGAINST OCCUPANTS PROHIBITED:
In the case of a building code violation only, no action for eviction, abatement of a nuisance, forcible entry and detainer or other similar proceeding shall be
threatened or instituted against an occupant of a dwelling solely because such occupant agrees to testify or testifies at a building code violation hearing.
(Ord. 2830, 11-7-2013)
1-23-10: SUBPOENAS:
At any time prior to the hearing date, the hearing officer assigned to hear the case may, at the request of either party, direct witnesses to appear and give
testimony at the hearing. (Ord. 2830, 11-7-2013)
1-23-11: REPRESENTATION AT MUNICIPAL ORDINANCE VIOLATION HEARINGS:
The case for the village may be presented by an attorney designated by the village or by any other village employee, except that the case for the village
shall not be presented by an employee of the ordinance enforcement department. The case for the alleged violator may be presented by the alleged
violator, his or her attorney, or any other agent or representative of the alleged violator. (Ord. 2830, 11-7-2013)
1-23-12: CONTINUANCES:
No continuances shall be authorized by the hearing officer in proceedings under this section except in cases where a continuance is absolutely necessary
to protect the rights of the alleged violator. Lack of preparation shall not be grounds for a continuance. Any continuance authorized by a hearing officer
under this section shall not exceed twenty five (25) days. (Ord. 2830, 11-7-2013)
1-23-13: HEARING:
At the hearing, the hearing officer shall preside, hear testimony and accept any evidence relevant to the existence or nonexistence of a municipal
ordinance violation. (Ord. 2830, 11-7-2013)
1-23-14: EVIDENCE:
With regard to testimony heard and evidence presented, the strict rules of evidence applicable to judicial proceedings shall not apply to hearings
authorized by this chapter. (Ord. 2830, 11-7-2013)
1-23-15: DEFENSES TO BUILDING CODE VIOLATIONS:
In the case of a building code violation only, it shall be a defense to a building code violation charge under this section if the owner, his attorney, or any
other agent or representative proves to the hearing officer's satisfaction that:
(A) The building code violation alleged in the notice does not in fact exist, or at the time of the hearing the violation has been remedied or removed;
(B) The building code violation has been caused by the current property occupants and that in spite of reasonable attempts by the property owner to
maintain the dwelling free of such violations, the current occupants continue to cause the building code violations; or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 73/519
(C) An occupant or resident of the dwelling has refused entry to the owner or his agent to all or a part of the dwelling for the purpose of correcting the
building code violation. (Ord. 2830, 11-7-2013)
1-23-16: DEFAULT:
(A) If on the dates set for the hearing the alleged violator or his or her attorney or designee fails to appear, the hearing officer may find the alleged violator
in default and shall proceed with the hearing and accept evidence relevant to the existence of a municipal ordinance violation.
(B) Upon finding the alleged violator in default, the ordinance enforcement administrator shall send or cause to be sent notices by first class mail, postage
prepaid to the violators who received the notice of an ordinance violation. Service of notices sent in accordance herewith shall be complete as of the
date of deposit in the United States mail. (Ord. 2830, 11-7-2013)
1-23-17: FINDINGS, DECISION AND ORDER:
(A) At the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall make a determination on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing as to whether or
not a municipal ordinance violation exists.
(B) The determination shall be in writing and shall be designated as findings, decision and order.
(C) The findings, decision and order shall include:
1. The hearing officer's findings of fact;
2. Decision of whether or not a municipal ordinance violation exists based upon the findings of fact;
3. An order that states the sanction, which may include an order to correct the violation, or dismisses the case if a violation is not proved;
4. In the case of a municipal ordinance violation other than a building code violation, if a violation is proved, a monetary sanction shall not exceed the
amount provided for in section 1-2-1 of the Illinois municipal code5, currently seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00); and
5. In the case of a building code violation, if a violation is proved, the order may impose the sanctions that are provided in the building code for the
violation proved.
(D) A copy of any findings, decisions, or orders shall be served on the alleged violator within five (5) days after it is issued.
(E) Service shall be via first class mail.
(F) Payment of any penalty or fine and the disposition of any fine money shall be in the manner as set forth in the village code. (Ord. 2830, 11-7-2013)
1-23-18: ORDER AND SANCTION ATTACH TO PROPERTY:
In the case of a building code violation only, the order to correct a building code violation and the sanctions imposed by the village as the result of a finding
of a building code violation under this section shall attach to the property as well as to the property owner so that a finding of a building code violation
against one owner cannot be avoided by conveying or transferring the property to another owner. Any subsequent transferee or owner of property takes
subject to the findings, decision and order of a hearing officer under this section. (Ord. 2830, 11-7-2013)
1-23-19: ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW:
The findings, decision and order of the hearing officer shall be subject to review in the circuit court of Cook County. The provisions of the administrative
review law6 and the rules adopted pursuant thereto, shall apply to and govern every action for the judicial review of the findings, decisions, and order of a
hearing officer under this chapter. (Ord. 2830, 11-7-2013)
1-23-20: JUDGMENT ON FINDINGS, DECISION AND ORDER:
(A) Any fine, other sanction, or costs imposed, or part of any fine, other sanction or costs imposed, remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of, or the failure
to exhaust, judicial review procedures under the administrative review law7 shall be a debt due and owing the village and, as such, may be collected in
accordance with applicable law.
(B) After expiration of the period within which judicial review under the administrative review law8 may be sought for a final determination of the municipal
ordinance violation, the village may commence a proceeding in the circuit court of Cook County for the purpose of obtaining a judgment on the findings,
decision and order. Nothing in this section shall prevent the village from consolidating multiple findings, decisions, and orders against a person in such
a proceeding.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 74/519
(C) Upon commencement of the action, the village shall file a certified copy of the findings, decision, and order, which shall be accompanied by a
certification that recites facts sufficient to show that the findings, decision, and order was issued in accordance with this section and the applicable
municipal ordinances.
(D) Service of the summons and a copy of the petition may be by any method provided for by section 2-203 of the code of civil procedure9, or by certified
mail, return receipt requested, provided that the total amount of fines, other sanctions, and costs imposed by the findings, decision, and order does not
exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00).
(E) If the court is satisfied that the findings, decision and order was entered in accordance with the requirements of this section and the applicable
municipal ordinances and that the alleged violator had an opportunity for a hearing under this section and for judicial review as provided in this section:
1. The court shall render judgment in favor of the village and against the violator for the amount indicated in the findings, decision, and order, plus
costs. The judgment shall have the same effect and may be enforced in the same manner as other judgments for the recovery of money.
2. The court may also issue any other orders and injunctions that are requested by the village to enforce the order of the hearing officer to correct a
municipal ordinance violation. (Ord. 2830, 11-7-2013)
1-23-21: IMPACT ON OTHER ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION SYSTEMS:
This section shall not affect the validity of any other systems of administrative adjudication authorized by state law and adopted by the village, including,
but not limited to, the system of adjudication for village vehicular standing, parking compliance regulations, vehicle license or wheel tax violations, and
related vehicular compliance related violations set forth in title 9, chapter 6 of this code. (Ord. 2830, 11-7-2013)
Title 2
DEPARTMENTS, BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
Chapter 1
DEPARTMENTS, BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES; GENERAL
2-1-1: DEPARTMENTS CREATED:
In addition to the Board of Trustees and the officers named in title 1, chapter 5 of this Code, the administrative services of the Village shall be organized
into the following departments:
Building
Finance
Fire/Rescue and Emergency Services
Health
Parks and Recreation
Police
Public Works
Water (1965 Code § 10.01; amd. Ord. 2207, 11-17-1997; Ord. 2501, 6-21-2004)
2-1-2: DEPARTMENT ORGANIZATION AND FUNCTIONS:
The departments shall be so organized into divisions as to comprise and include all of the administrative and service functions of the Village and the
Village Manager, with the consent of the Board of Trustees, shall have authority to allocate to the said departments such functions for administrative
purposes. (1965 Code § 10.02)
2-1-3: BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES CREATED:
In addition to the departments named above, there shall be the following boards, commissions and committees:
Board of Fire and Police Commissioners
Board of Health
Board of Local Improvements
Economic Development Commission
Emergency Management Services and Disaster Agency
Foreign Fire Insurance Tax Board
Landscape Advisory Commission
Parks and Recreation Board
Planning and Zoning Commission
Public Library Board
Riverside Cable Commission
Riverside Civic Center Authority
Riverside Historical Commission
Riverside Preservation Commission
Safe Environment Commission
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 75/519
Safety Commission
Zoning Board of Appeals (Ord. 2843, 12-19-2013; amd. Ord. 2872, 4-16-2015)
2-1-4: APPOINTMENT; TERMS; VACANCIES:
Except as otherwise provided herein, all members of boards, commissions and committees shall be appointed by the President by and with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees. Members of the Public Library Board shall be elected as provided in chapter 18 of this title, and members of the Foreign
Fire Insurance Tax Board shall be elected as provided in title 3, chapter 12 of this Code. The respective terms of office of such members shall be as
provided in the respective chapter pertaining thereto. The Chair of all boards, commissions, and committees other than the Public Library Board and
Foreign Fire Insurance Tax Board shall be appointed by the President for one year terms commencing June 1 of each year. The President may remove the
Chair and appoint a new Chair at any time prior to the end of the one year term with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. Vacancies occurring
before the end of a term shall be filled as in the case of the original appointment. In this regard any appointed member of a board, commission or
committee who is absent from fifty percent (50%) of the regularly scheduled meetings held during a year without formal approval of such board,
commission or committee shall be considered to have resigned and the President, upon written notice thereof by the particular board, commission or
committee, shall appoint a new member to fill such vacancy. Each member shall serve until his successor shall have been duly appointed and qualified.
(Ord. 2968, 10-5-2017)
2-1-5: COMPENSATION; REMOVAL FROM OFFICE; OATH:
(A) Compensation: Members of boards, commissions and committees shall serve without compensation. (1965 Code § 18.03)
(B) Removal From Office: The President and Board of Trustees may remove from office any member of any board, commission or committee, at any time,
for cause after a public hearing. (1965 Code § 18.04)
(C) Oath Of Office; Commission: Each member of a board, commission or committee, except members of the Emergency Management Services and
Disaster Agency, shall, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, take and subscribe to oath of office provided for Village officers
provided in title 1, chapter 5 of this Code. All members of the Emergency Services and Disaster Agency shall subscribe to the oath prescribed in
section 2-10-5 of this title. Each member shall be commissioned by a warrant signed by the President and attested by the Clerk under the Corporate
Seal, in the form provided in title 1, chapter 5 of this Code. (1965 Code § 18.05; amd. Ord. 1856, 6-5-1989)
2-1-6: POWERS AND DUTIES:
Each board and commission shall be so organized and have such powers and duties as are required or provided by statute and the provisions of this
Code. (1965 Code § 18.06)

BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS

The board of local improvements shall consist of the village president, who shall be president of the board, and all of the members of the board of trustees.
(1965 Code, Sec. 18.01F)
2-5-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board of local improvements shall have the powers and shall perform the duties prescribed by the statutes of the state of Illinois, the provisions of this
code and other ordinances of the village. (1965 Code, Sec. 18.02F)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 76/519
Chapter 6
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
2-6-1: COMPOSITION:
The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners of the Village shall be composed of three (3) members. (1965 Code, Sec. 18.01D)
2-6-2: APPOINTMENT, TERMS, QUALIFICATIONS, BOND, VACANCY:
The members of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall be appointed by the President of the Village with the consent of the Board of Trustees,
and each member shall serve for a term of three (3) years and until their respective successors are appointed and have qualified. Vacancies on the Board
shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The President of the Village shall, however, make no appointment pursuant to this Section
within thirty (30) days before the expiration of his term of office. Members shall be subject to removal for cause as prescribed by Statute.
Each member of the said Board shall possess the qualifications required of other officers of the Municipality, and in addition no such member shall hold a
lucrative office under the United States, State of Illinois or any political subdivision thereof, or a municipality; nor shall any such member be related, either
by blood or marriage up to the degree of first cousin, to any elected official of this Village.
The members of the said Board shall be considered officers of the Village and each member, before entering upon the duties of his office, shall take and
file an oath of office, shall execute and file a fidelity bond with a corporate surety approved by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village in an
amount made payable to the Village in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), and shall execute and file an affidavit of national or state political
party affiliation, which political party affiliations shall be considered in making appointments to the Board. All such filing requirements shall be
accomplished in the office of the Village Clerk. (Ord. 1261; 4-21-75)
2-6-3: COMPENSATION, RULES, POWERS AND DUTIES:
The members of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall serve without compensation. A majority of the members shall constitute a quorum for
the transaction of business. Said Board shall elect the necessary officers and make rules to carry out the purposes of Section 10-2.1-1 et seq of the Illinois
Municipal Code dealing with the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, as amended, and for appointments and removals in accordance with its
provisions, and shall have and exercise all powers and perform all duties and obligations conferred or imposed on said Board by said Statute. (1965 Code,
Sec. 18.03D)
Chapter 7
BUILDING DEPARTMENT
2-7-1: COMPOSITION:
The Building Department shall consist of the Village Manager, who shall be head of the Department and such other inspectors and assistants as the
President and Board of Trustees shall from time to time provide. (1965 Code, Sec. 16.01)
2-7-2: FUNCTIONS AND DUTIES:
Subject to the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the Village, this Department shall take charge of and be responsible for the following:
(A) The inspection and supervision of the erection, construction, alteration, repair, demolition and removal of all buildings, walls, structures or portions
thereof or accessories thereto within the Village;
(B) The inspection and supervision of all electrical construction, plumbing, refrigeration, air conditioning installations, all signs, fences, walls, swimming
pools and all other construction subject to the provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the Village;
(C) The examination of plans and specifications submitted for building permit purposes;
(D) The examination of plans and inspection of premises necessary to secure compliance with the zoning provisions of the Village;
(F) The keeping of an accurate record and file of all permits issued and make such reports of the transactions of the Department as the Village Manager
shall direct;
(F) The performance of such other duties as are assigned to it by the Village Manager. (1965 Code, Sec. 16.02)
2-7-3: POWERS OF VILLAGE MANAGER:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 77/519
(A) Right Of Entry: The Village Manager and his duly authorized inspectors and agents shall have the right to enter any building, whether completed or in
process of construction, alteration or repair for the purpose of determining whether the same is being constructed, altered or repaired or used in
accordance with the ordinances of the Village. (1965 Code, Sec. 16.03)
(B) Stop Orders: The Village Manager and his duly authorized inspectors shall have power to stop work on any building, structure or appurtenance thereto
when such work is being done without a permit or is being done in violation of any provision of any Village ordinance or of any order of the Board of
Trustees. (1965 Code, Sec. 16.05)
(C) Revocation Of Permits: The Village Manager, with the approval of the Village President, may revoke the permit for the erection, alteration, repair or
demolition of any building, structure or appurtenance thereto if the owner or other person in possession or charge of the same shall refuse to comply
with the conditions of any stop order. (1965 Code, Sec. 16.06)
2-7-4: HINDERING INSPECTORS:
Any person hindering, resisting or attempting to resist any Village inspector in the performance of his duty shall be charged with hindering or opposing a
Village officer; and the person so convicted of such offense shall be subject to the penalty provided in Section 1-4-1 of this Code. (1965 Code, Sec. 16.04)
