Chapter 18
PUBLIC LIBRARY BOARD
2-18-1: ESTABLISHMENT; NAME:
There is hereby established a public library for the use of the inhabitants of the Village, which shall be known as the Riverside Public Library. (1965 Code,
sec. 18.01J)
2-18-2: BOARD OF DIRECTORS:
The public library shall be under the supervision and management of a board of seven (7) directors, to be elected in accordance with the provisions of
Illinois Revised Statutes, chapter 81, relating to public libraries. The directors so elected shall have all the powers, authority and duties conferred by law.
(1965 Code, sec. 18.02J)
2-18-3: INJURING PROPERTY:
(A) Injuring Books: It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully or maliciously cut, write upon, injure, deface, tear or destroy any book, newspaper, plate,
picture, engraving or statue belonging to, in the possession of or under the control of the public library. (1965 Code, sec. 18.03J)
(B) Injuring Furniture: It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully or maliciously commit any injury upon the grounds, buildings, furniture or fixtures or
other property belonging to or under the control of the public library. (1965 Code, sec. 18.04J)
2-18-4: FAILURE TO RETURN BOOKS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to return any book belonging to the Riverside Public Library, according
to the requirements of the bylaws duly made and adopted by the directors of such library for the government thereof. (1965 Code, sec. 18.05J)
2-18-5: SPECIAL RESERVE FUND:
(A) Fund Established: There is hereby established a fund which shall be designated as the "Special Reserve Fund" for the Riverside Public Library; said
Fund to be used for the purchase of sites and buildings, for the construction and equipment of buildings, for the rental and repair of buildings acquired
for library purposes, and for planned or emergency repairs and alterations of library buildings and equipment.
(B) Monies in Fund: There may be accumulated and set apart in said Fund, such amount of the unexpended balances of the proceeds annually received
from taxes levied and collected for public library purposes, not in excess of statutory limits.
(C) Plan For Fund Expenditures: The Board of Trustees of the Riverside Public Library shall adopt a plan or plans pertaining to the use and expenditure of
amounts accumulated and set apart in the Special Reserve Fund, which plan shall be adopted within two (2) years from the effective date of this
Section; and shall further include within its annual appropriation requests to this Board, such amount as is to be accumulated and set apart for the
Special Reserve Fund. (Ord. 1808, 6-20-88)
Chapter 19
PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT
2-19-1: ADMINISTRATION:
The Village Manager shall be the administrative head of the Public Works Department and its functions and duties shall be performed under his direction
and supervision. (1965 Code, Sec. 14.01)
2-19-2: DEPARTMENT FUNCTIONS, DUTIES:
Subject to the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the Village, this Department shall take charge of, be responsible for and supervise the
construction, operation, repair, alteration or extenion of the following:
(A) Streets, roads, highways and alleys;
(B) Parking lots, parking meters, traffic signs;
(C) Parks, parkways, public grounds, sidewalks;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 92/519
(D) Public buildings, structures and appurtenances;
(E) Sewers, connections thereto, drains;
(F) Garbage collection and refuse dump sites;
(G) Public improvements made by the Village or other public agencies, special assessment projects;
(H) Central garage and service facilities for storing and maintaining equipment for all departments;
(I) Other functions and duties directed from time to time by the Village Board. (1965 Code, Sec. 14.02)
2-19-3: RECORDS, REPORTS, OTHER DUTIES:
In connection with the execution of the functions enumerated in Section 2-20-2 above, the Public Works Department shall
(A) Maintain complete and systematic records of all transactions of this Department;
(B) Carefully preserve all engineering field notes, subdivision plats, grades, bench marks, maps, plans, profiles, papers, books made by him or others in
connection with all proposed or completed improvements and arrange and index the same for ready reference;
(C) Make and keep in its office a complete and up-to-date atlas of all sewers and water mains and the location of connections thereto; keep an up-to-date
official map of the Village and atlases of street lighting facilities and public utility and all other underground installations located in public streets and
places;
(D) Prepare and keep on file record maps, surveys and plats of all Village owned land, easements and rights of way and up-to-date plans of all public
buildings and facilities;
(E) Maintain an up-to-date inventory of all equipment, tools and supplies allocated to this Department; and
(F) Prepare maps, plans, specifications, estimates, budgets and procedures for any improvement, program or project requested by the Village Manager or
Board of Trustees. (1965 Code, Sec. 14.03)
Chapter 20
RIVERSIDE HISTORICAL COMMISSION
2-20-1: COMPOSITION OF COMMISSION:
There is hereby created in the village, the Riverside historical commission, consisting of seven (7) members, all of whom shall be residents of the village.
The commission shall serve in an advisory capacity to the president and board of trustees on all matters of historical interest within the village. (Ord. 2846,
1-16-2014)
2-20-2: APPOINTMENT AND TERM OF OFFICE:
The members of the commission shall be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, each to serve for a term of three
(3) years expiring June 1. (Ord. 2846, 1-16-2014)
2-20-3: RULES AND MEETINGS:
The commission, upon its appointment, shall meet and adopt rules of procedure for governing itself, not inconsistent with the provisions of this code or the
laws of the state of Illinois, and may, subject to an appropriation therefor, employ clerical assistance and may accept and expend money, gifts or donations
in carrying out its purposes and duties. The commission shall adopt a schedule of meetings and shall meet in accordance with such schedule and at all
other times when called to meeting by the president and board of trustees, or by the chairman of the commission or by two (2) of its members. A majority
of the members of the commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. (Ord. 2846, 1-16-2014)
2-20-4: DUTIES:
The commission shall have the following duties and responsibilities:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 93/519
(A) To operate and maintain the Riverside Museum, to adopt rules and regulations governing the hours when the museum shall be open to the public and
pertaining to all other activities conducted within the museum, and to maintain and supervise a volunteer staff in the operation of the museum.
(B) To receive, identify, store, exhibit and adopt all other measures deemed necessary to preserve historical records, and materials loaned, given or
otherwise acquired by the commission or by the village and pertaining to local, state, or federal history.
(C) To provide authentication of historical data submitted to the commission by local residents or organizations.
(D) To study all aspects of federal and state grant in aid and other funding sources and programs pertaining to collections management, conservation, and
storage; exhibition programming and organization; publications pertaining to the history of Riverside, its historical structures, areas, and landmarks; and
other areas pertaining to the operation and maintenance of a public museum and archive.
(E) To prepare an appropriate official history of the village, and to update and maintain said history from time to time, and to prepare and disseminate other
pamphlets or articles pertaining to historical subjects.
(F) To study and recommend to the president and board of trustees all measures dealing with the maintenance and preservation of areas and structures
having historical significance to this village.
(G) To perform all other functions so delegated to it by the president and board of trustees. (Ord. 2846, 1-16-2014)
2-20-5: ANNUAL REPORT; BUDGET:
The commission shall annually submit on or before May 30 of each year a written report of its activities during the preceding fiscal year. Said report shall
include therein a budget outlining the financial needs of the commission and all sources of anticipated income and expenses for the ensuing fiscal year.
(Ord. 2846, 1-16-2014)
Chapter 21
SAFETY COMMISSION
2-21-1: COMPOSITION, TERM:
The safety commission shall consist of the village manager and five (5) residents of the village. The members of the commission shall serve until the
second Monday in May following their appointment and until their successors have been appointed and qualified. (1965 Code § 18.01K)
2-21-2: ORGANIZATION AND RULES:
The chairman of the safety commission shall be designated by the president. The commission shall elect its own secretary and adopt its own rules of
procedure. (1965 Code § 18.02K)
2-21-3: DUTIES:
The safety commission shall study and report to the board from time to time on traffic and other hazards to public safety and on methods of eliminating
said hazards. (1965 Code § 18.03K)
Chapter 22
WATER DEPARTMENT
2-22-1: FUNCTION:
The Water Department shall be charged with the duty of administering and enforcing the provisions of this Code relating to the water system of this Village.
(1965 Code, Sec. 15.01)
2-22-2: ADMINISTRATION:
The Village Manager shall be the administrative head of the Water Department and its powers and duties shall be performed under his direction and
supervision. He shall have authority to prescribe such standards as may be reasonably required to insure compliance with the provisions of this Code.
(1965 Code, Sec. 15.02)
2-22-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 94/519
The Water Department shall have direct charge and control of the maintenance and operation of the system of water mains, water service pipes, pumping
stations, wells, tanks, reservoirs, grounds, buildings and appurtenances thereto and the distribution of water thereby as provided in this Code, and shall be
responsible for the efficient operation of the system and compliance with the State and Village Health Department standards governing the quality of water
distributed. (1965 Code, Sec. 15.03)
The Water Department shall enforce all ordinances, rules and regulations relating to the operation and use of the Village water plant and the services
supplied therefrom, including but without limitation thereto, all ordinances, rules and regulations governing the supply of water furnished to the Village by
the City of Chicago and the rules of the State agencies regulating the sanitation of water supplies and distribution systems, and shall also perform the
following duties; together with such other duties as may be required by the President and Board of Trustees from time to time:
(A) It shall keep a complete and accurate record of all taps inserted or connections made, their exact location, their number and size, and the location of
the curb cock or shut off boxes.
(B) It shall make or direct all repairs to the mains and appurtenances and to the service pipes between the main and the street side of the curb cock or
shut off valve and all turning on or shutting off of water supplied to such services.
(C) It shall cause the installation, testing and repair of water meters and the making of periodical readings of meters and the keeping of accurate records of
such readings and repairs.
(D) It shall supervise the operation, maintenance and repair of the gas and electric street lighting systems, the electric traffic signal installation and the
repair of parking meters. It shall perform such other duties as may be prescribed by the Village Manager or the Board of Trustees. (1965 Code, Sec.
15.04 and 15.05)
2-22-4: REPORTS:
(A) The Village Manager shall make a written report to the Board of Trustees each month, giving a summary of all operations of the Department during the
preceding month and such recommendations as he may deem necessary for the efficient operation of the water system or other function under its
jursidiction.
(B) The Village Manager shall keep accurate daily records of the quantity of water supplied from various sources and the amount of water distributed
together with such other records as are necessary for the efficient control of the operation functions of the Department. (1965 Code, Sec. 15.06)
Chapter 23
RIVERSIDE CIVIC CENTER AUTHORITY
2-23-1: COMPOSITION, TERM, COMPENSATION:
The Riverside Civic Center Authority shall be comprised of a Board of seven (7) members who shall be the duly elected President and members of the
Board of Trustees of the Village. The terms of Board members shall coincide with their respective terms of office as elected Village officials, and they shall
hold office until their respective successors have been elected and qualified. The Board members shall serve without compensation, but shall be
reimbursed for actual expenses incurred by them in the performance of their duties. No Board member shall have any private financial interest, profit or
benefit in any contract, work or business of the Authority, or in the sale or lease of any property to or from the Authority.
2-23-2: OFFICERS; OATH; RULES; MEETINGS:
Before entering upon the duties of office, each Board member shall take and subscribe the constitutional oath of office and shall file it in the office of the
Secretary of State. The officers of the Board shall consist of the Village President who shall serve as chairman of the Board, and a secretary and a
treasurer appointed by the Board, who need not be members of the Board, and who shall hold their respective offices during the pleasure of the Board. As
soon as practicable after organizing itself the Board shall adopt such bylaws and regulations as it deems proper to govern its proceedings. Four (4)
members of the Board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. All actions of the Board shall be by ordinance or by resolution and the
affirmative vote of at least four (4) members shall be necessary for the adoption thereof. The Board shall hold regular meetings at least once in each
calendar month at a date and time to be fixed by the Board. Meetings shall be held in the Council Room of the Village Hall, unless the Board shall
designate another meeting place.
2-23-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Riverside Civic Center Authority Board shall have and shall exercise all of the powers and duties conferred by statute, including the power to sue and
be sued in its corporate name; the power to acquire, by purchase, gift or eminent domain, and to own, construct, and lease civic centers, cultural facilities
and office buildings, including grounds for parking areas and other accessory uses; the power to plan for, design, improve, extend, repair, reconstruct,
regulate, operate, equip and maintain said civic center, cultural facilities and office buildings, and grounds pertaining thereto; the power to plan, sponsor,
hold, arrange and finance various civic, cultural, and educational exhibits, shows and events, using said centers, cultural facilities, office buildings and
grounds; the power to fix and collect rents, fees, and charges for the use of such civic center, cultural facilities, office buildings and grounds, or for the
admission to said shows, exhibits and events sponsored by the Authority; the power to enter into contracts to carry out the various powers, duties, objects
and purposes of the Authority; the power to acquire and accept by purchase, lease, gift or otherwise any property or rights useful for its purposes, from any
person, organization or unit of government, or the State of Illinois, and the power to apply for and accept grants, matching grants, loans, or appropriations
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 95/519
from the State of Illinois or any instrumentality thereof, and from the Federal government or any instrumentality thereof; and the power to borrow money for
the purpose of carrying out and performing the duties and exercising the powers of the Authority, and to issue and dispose of interest bearing revenue
bonds or interest bearing revenue refunding bonds to evidence the Authority's obligation to repay such money as is borrowed.
It shall be the duty of the Authority to promote, operate and maintain a community civic center and exhibitions, conventions, theatrical, sports and cultural
activities from time to time within the Village and to arrange, finance, construct, equip, and maintain a community civic center combining auditorium,
recreational and office uses for such purposes. As an integral part of said duties, the Authority shall have the right to lease office space and air space over
and appurtenant to such community civic center structure.
2-23-4: SECRETARY AND TREASURER; OATH; BOND; DUTIES:
Before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, both the secretary and the treasurer appointed by the Board shall take and subscribe the
constitutional oath of office, and shall file it in the principal office of the Authority. In addition, the treasurer shall execute a faithful performance bond with
corporate sureties to be approved by the Board, which bond shall be payable to the Authority in whatever penal sum the Board may require. The obligation
of the sureties shall not extend to any loss sustained by the insolvency, failure or closing of any National or State bank wherein the treasurer has deposited
funds, if the bank has been approved by the Board as a depository of these funds.
The secretary shall be responsible to attend all meetings of the Board and shall take and keep the minutes thereof. The secretary shall be the custodian of
all ordinances, resolutions and proceedings of the Authority and all documents and records in the possession of the secretary shall be public records and
open to public inspection, except such documents and records as shall be kept or prepared by the Board for use in negotiations, actions or proceedings to
which the Authority is a party. The secretary shall be the custodian of the seal of the Authority if any, and shall attest to all documents and affix said seal
where so directed by the Board or otherwise by statute.
The treasurer shall be responsible for depositing all funds received in the name of the Authority and for payment of all bills or invoices approved and
directed to be paid by the Board. All funds received by the treasurer shall be deposited in the name of the Authority in a depository bank designated by the
Board, and said funds shall be withdrawn or paid out by check or draft upon the bank signed by the treasurer and countersigned by the chairman of the
Board. The Board may designate any of its members to affix the signature of the chairman and another to affix the signature of the treasurer to any check
or draft for payment of salaries, wages and for payment of any other obligation for not more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). The
Authority shall not incur any obligation for payment of salaries, office or administrative expenses except in the amount of funds which will be available to it
when such obligations become payable. The treasurer shall prepare all reports regarding the financial condition of the Authority as may be directed by the
Board.
2-23-5: GENERAL MANAGER:
The Board may appoint a general manager to hold office during the pleasure of the Board at a compensation which shall be fixed by the Board. Such
general manager shall manage the properties and business of the Authority and the employees thereof, subject to the general control of the Board, and
shall direct the enforcement of all ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations of the Board, and shall perform such other duties as may be prescribed
from time to time by the Board. In addition, the Board may appoint such additional officers or employees as they deem necessary, and shall define their
duties, fix their compensation, and require bonds of such of them as the Board may designate.
2-23-6: CONTRACTS; ADVERTISEMENT FOR BIDS:
All contracts for the sale of property valued at more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) or for a concession in or lease of property,
including air rights, of the Authority for a term exceeding one year, shall be awarded to the highest responsible bidder, after advertising for bids. All
construction contracts and contracts for supplies, materials, equipment and services, when the expense thereof will exceed two thousand five hundred
dollars ($2,500.00), shall be let to the lowest responsible bidder, after advertising for bids, excepting: (1) When repair parts, accessories, equipment or
services are required for equipment or services previously furnished or contracted for; (2) When the nature of the services required is such that competitive
bidding is not in the best interest of the public, including, professional services; and (3) When expenses are for required utility uses.
All contracts involving less than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) shall similarly be let by competitive bidding to the lowest responsible bidder
whenever possible, and in any event, in a manner calculated to ensure the best interests of the public. Competitive bidding is not required for the lease of
real estate or buildings owned or controlled by the Authority. The Board is empowered to offer such leases upon such terms as it deems advisable.
Advertisement for bids shall be published at least twice in a newspaper published and of general circulation within the Village, with the last publication to
be at least ten (10) calendar days before the time of receiving bids. Such advertisement shall also be posted on the bulletin board in the hallway of the
administrative offices of the Village in the Village Hall, Riverside, Illinois. Said advertisement shall state the time and place for receiving and opening bids,
and shall describe the character of the proposed contract in sufficient detail or otherwise shall advise as to where plans and specifications on file regarding
said contract may be reviewed, so as to fully advise prospective bidders of their obligations and to ensure free and open competitive bidding. Each bidder
shall be required to accompany the bid with a good faith bid deposit in an amount fixed by the Board before advertising for bids, and where required by the
Board a faithful performance bond with surety or sureties satisfactory to the Board and other adequate insurance shall be required in reasonable amounts
to be fixed by the Board before advertising for bids. All bids in response to advertisement shall be sealed and shall be publicly opened by the Board, and
bidders are entitled to be present in person, or by representatives at such time as the bids are publicly opened. All bids shall be placed on file and shall be
open to public inspection. All bids shall be void if there is any disclosure of the terms of any bid made or permitted to be made by the Board or any
member thereof before the time fixed for opening of bids. The Board shall have the right to reject all bids and to readvertise therefor. If, after any such
advertisement, no responsible or satisfactory bid within the terms of the advertisement shall be received, the Board may award such contract without
competitive bidding; provided, that it shall not be less advantageous to the Authority than any valid bid received pursuant to advertisement.
The contract shall be awarded to the successful bidder as promptly as possible after the opening of bids. In determining the responsibility of any bidder,
the Board may take into account past dealings with the bidder, the bidder's experience, adequacy of equipment, and ability to complete performance within
the time set, and other factors besides financial responsibility; but in no case shall any contract be awarded to other than the highest bidder (in the case of
a sale, concession or lease) or to the lowest bidder (in the case of a purchase or expenditure) unless so authorized or approved by a vote of at least five
(5) members of the Board, and unless such action is accompanied by a statement in writing setting forth the reasons for not awarding the contract to the
highest or lowest bidder, as the case may be, which statement shall be kept on file and open to public inspection in the administrative offices of the Village
in the Village Hall, Riverside, Illinois.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 96/519
No Board member, officer or employee of the Authority or any relative of any Board member, officer or employee shall be interested directly or indirectly in
any contract for construction or maintenance work or for the delivery of materials, supplies or equipment. (Ord. 1872, 11-6-89)
Chapter 24
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
2-24-1: COMPOSITION OF COMMISSION:
The economic development commission shall be composed of seven (7) resident citizens, to be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of
the board of trustees. Members shall be residents within the community with an interest and background in economic development, business, and/or
marketing. (Ord. 2846, 1-16-2014)
2-24-2: TERM OF OFFICE:
Terms of the members of the economic development commission shall be for three (3) years expiring June 1. (Ord. 2846, 1-16-2014)
2-24-3: OFFICERS, RULES AND MEETINGS:
The commission, upon its appointment, shall meet and adopt rules of procedure for conducting its meetings and carrying out its activities in furtherance of
the duties and purposes of the commission. The commission shall adopt a schedule of meetings and shall meet in accordance with such schedule and at
all other times when called to meeting by the president and board of trustees, or by the chairperson of the commission, or by two (2) of its members. A
majority of the members of the commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. Copies of the minutes of all meetings of the
commission and other reports of its activities shall be furnished to the village board on a regular basis. (Ord. 2846, 1-16-2014)
2-24-4: DUTIES:
(A) To examine the retail businesses and the business districts within the village and to determine the best uses for retail spaces.
(B) To prepare and recommend to the village board a plan accomplishing the two (2) goals of encouraging commercial development within the village and
improving the village's tax base and sales tax revenue.
(C) To serve as the primary business conduit for the village by encouraging residents and nonresidents to shop in Riverside, and to develop plans for
attracting business and patrons to the village through use of fairs, exhibitions, advertising, external improvements to the business districts, and other
activities.
(D) To prepare and recommend to the village board, from time to time, ordinance changes involving zoning, parking restrictions, licensing, or other
changes which will enhance or otherwise benefit the commercial districts and activities within the village.
(E) To work closely with the chamber of commerce to coordinate cooperative ventures and activities to benefit the business districts and commercial
activities within the village.
(F) To undertake such further studies and projects regarding economic development within the village as may be referred to it, from time to time, by the
village board. (Ord. 2846, 1-16-2014)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 2905 - CABLE COMMISSION. Go to new ordinance.

Chapter 26
SAFE ENVIRONMENT COMMISSION
2-26-1: CREATION OF COMMISSION:
There is hereby created the Safe Environment Commission, which shall be advisory to the Village Board. (Ord. 2236, 8-17-1998)
2-26-2: MISSION AND PURPOSE:
It shall be the mission and purpose of the Safe Environment Commission to work in partnership with citizens and Village officials to identify needs for
improved safety and, based on those needs, to develop and implement programs that maintain a safe environment and improve the health and welfare of
our community. (Ord. 2236, 8-17-1998)
2-26-3: COMMISSION MEMBERSHIP:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 98/519
(A) Appointment: The commission shall consist of seven (7) members appointed by the Village President, by and with the advice and consent of the Board
of Trustees, to serve without compensation.
(B) Terms: In general, each member shall serve for a term of four (4) years. The initial term of all original members shall commence upon appointment. In
order that the terms shall be staggered, the Village President shall designate two (2) original members whose initial terms shall end on December 31,
2000; two (2) original members whose initial terms shall end on December 31, 2001; and three (3) original members whose initial terms shall end on

8-17-1998)

(F) Secretary: The commission shall elect one of the members of the commission to be Secretary. The Secretary shall be elected annually in January of
each year. (Ord. 2968, 10-5-2017)

Title 3
BUSINESS REGULATIONS
Chapter 1
LICENSES AND PERMITS
3-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 99/519
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter:
FOOD DEALER: Any business operating in Riverside regulated by title 7 of this code that is subject to a health inspection, including food related
businesses, or such other fee as is currently charged to the village and published by the village.
LICENSE: A privilege granted by the village, after the fulfillment of all conditions precedent that are expressly provided herein, to engage in a business or a
commercial enterprise or activity. Whenever the term "business" is used it shall include any commercial enterprise or establishment or any activity licensed
or permitted under this title. Every license granted by the village pursuant to this title, and every renewal thereof, shall be purely a privilege, shall not
constitute property, and shall not otherwise be construed in any manner to create any other right to or interest in such license.
OWNER: Any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, trust, or any other legal entity having sufficient proprietary interest in any establishment
to maintain and manage its operation.
PERMIT: A privilege granted by the village, after the fulfillment of all conditions precedent that are expressly provided herein, to conduct a specific activity,
usually of commercial nature and for a shorter time period than allowed under a license, or for a temporary period.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, trust or any other legal entity. (Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-1-2: REQUIRED:
(A) It shall be unlawful for any person in this village to engage in any trade or business, or engage in any activity, or do anything, for any period of time at
any time, for which a license or permit is required by this code, without procuring the required license or permit. Persons operating under an existing
license or permit shall be considered to be in violation of this section upon a failure to submit a required fee, application or other materials required by
the village for renewal within thirty (30) days after expiration of the existing license or permit.
(B) A license shall be required for each separate business or commercial activity for which a license is required if more than one such activity is conducted
within any one establishment or on any one premises. The test to determine whether one or more than one business, activity or occupation is being
conducted within the village shall depend on the formalities of ownership of the business, activity, or occupation. When a licensable activity is operated
at more than one location, a separate license shall be required for each location, irrespective of ownership considerations. If all buildings containing the
principal or accessory uses are connected or are located on the same lot or parcel, and are operated and managed by the same person or owner, and
are an establishment with the same zoning code use classification, then the business, activity, or occupation shall require only one license. (Ord. 2895,
1-21-2016)
3-1-3: PROCEDURE FOR OBTAINING AND RENEWING; DEBTS TO VILLAGE:
(A) The procedure for obtaining a license or permit for any purpose, including form of application and qualifications of applicant, and the effective date and
conditions of issuance, shall be as prescribed by the particular ordinance or code provision requiring such license or permit, except that, unless
otherwise specified in such ordinance or code provision, the fee for such license or permit and the date of expiration thereof, if any, shall be as set forth
in section 3-1-6 of this chapter. Renewals of licenses and permits shall be subject to the same requirements and standards as are applicable to initial
licenses and permits, and according to administrative procedures established by the village.
(B) No person who is in default to the village regarding payment of water and sewer charges, special taxes or assessments, parking and other village
violation citations or judgments, motor vehicle tax, or any other taxes or fees that are due and unpaid by such person to the village shall be eligible to
obtain a license or permit. (Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-1-4: ASSIGNMENT AND TRANSFER:
(A) A license or permit shall be purely a personal privilege, good for not to exceed the designated expiration, unless sooner revoked as in this chapter
provided, and shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable,
voluntarily or involuntarily, or subject to being otherwise encumbered.
(B) Such license or permit shall cease upon the death, insolvency or bankruptcy of the licensee or permittee ("event") and shall not descend by the laws of
testate or intestate devolution, provided that executors or administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee or permittee, the trustee of any
insolvent or bankrupt licensee or permittee, or any other legal successor to the licensed or permitted business, may request the village for an extension
of the license or permit for its remaining term. Such request shall be in writing and directed to the village manager, and shall include information as to
the specific event and any related court pleadings and orders, and the qualifications of the proposed successor to operate the licensed business or
activity.
(C) The village manager shall have the authority to grant or deny the extension of the license or permit for its remaining term to the proposed successor
upon reasonable terms and conditions, based upon applicable village code licensing standards, and an assessment of the experience, moral character
and reputation of the proposed successor. The village manager shall advise the proposed successor within thirty (30) days of receipt of notice of the
denial or grant of extension, and of any conditions attached to the grant of extension.
(D) During the period from the event to the receipt of the village manager's notice of the grant or denial of extension, in order to protect the viability of the
business entity, the licensed or permitted business or activity may continue in operation for such temporary period. Upon receipt of a denial of
extension, the license or permit shall be considered as terminated, and the person(s) having responsibility for the business or commercial operations or
otherwise operating the business shall immediately cease operations and close the business.
(E) Any denial of extension shall be deemed final and not subject to appeal to the village, provided, however, that any person having an ownership interest
in the business or commercial activity may submit an original application for a business license or permit in his or her own name. (Ord. 2506, 8-16-
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 100/519
2004)
3-1-5: SUSPENSION, REVOCATION, NONRENEWAL, OR DENIAL:
(A) Except where otherwise specifically provided for, any license or permit may be suspended up to sixty (60) calendar days per incident, or may be
revoked by the village manager, or his or her designee, following notice and a hearing pursuant to this section, if it is determined that the licensee or
permittee has:
1. Failed to comply continuously with all conditions of license approval; or
2. Operated the business, activity or occupation in violation of any federal, state, village or other local law, ordinance, rule or regulation relating to the
license or permit, the licensed or permitted activity or occupation, or the licensed or permitted premises, including the requirements of this code; or
3. Conducted any activities directly related to business, activity or occupation, in a manner substantially adverse to the best interests of the village,
village residents, or the customers or clients of the business, activity or occupation, or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or a
menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public; or
4. Maintained any licensed or permitted premises in a manner in violation of the license or permit, the village's property maintenance code, or of any
other federal, state, village or other local law, ordinance, rule or regulation related to maintenance or condition or use of the premises; or
5. Made any false, fraudulent or misleading material statement on the application for a license or permit, or to village officials; or
6. Been found guilty of perpetrating a fraud upon any person, whether or not such fraud was perpetrated in the course of conducting any business in
the village; or
7. Suffered a revocation or refusal to issue or renew a license or permit applicable to conduct of the business, activity or occupation or a substantially
similar business, activity or occupation by any federal, state, municipality or licensing authority; or
8. Failed to pay any taxes, fees, penalties or fines owed to the village, including, but not limited to, bills for water or sewer or garbage service; or
9. Committed an act considered home repair fraud as defined in 815 Illinois Compiled Statutes 515/3 and 515/5; or
10. Failed to obtain or retain a required village license or permit or approval, operated without a required village permit or license following expiration of
a previous permit or license, or failed to obtain or retain a required state of Illinois license, permit, retail sales tax number, or other required approval;
or
11. Refused to permit any authorized inspector to take adequate samples or to make inspections, or has interfered with any village employee, agent or
official in the performance of his or her duties, including those duties and inspections conducted pursuant to section 3-1-10 of this chapter. In order to
suspend or revoke a license or permit for cause pursuant to this section based on a refusal to permit the taking of samples or to make inspections,
there must have been a written demand by the village on the licensee, or on the person in charge of the licensed premises, stating that the
inspection or sample is desired; or
12. Been convicted of any felony as defined in section 2-7 of the Illinois criminal code of 20121, or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude.
(B) A suspension, revocation, nonrenewal or denial of a license or permit shall not preclude prosecution and imposition of any other penalties provided for
the violation of applicable ordinances of the village, including the issuance of ordinance violations and/or the imposition of monetary penalties as
specified elsewhere in this code.
(C) When the conduct or operation of any business, activity or occupation, whether or not licensed or permitted, shall pose a clear and present danger to
the public health, safety or general welfare, the village manager, or his or her designee, shall have the authority to summarily order the cessation of
business and the closing of the premises, and the suspension of any valid license or permit for a period not to exceed ten (10) calendar days. Within
five (5) calendar days after he or she has so acted, the village manager or his or her designee shall call a hearing for the purpose of determining
whether or not the license or permit should be further suspended or revoked.
(D) Except where otherwise specifically provided for, licenses or permits issued under the ordinances of the village relative to the operation of a business
may be suspended or revoked after notice and hearing before the village manager or his or her designee in accordance with the following procedures:
1. Notice of the hearing for the suspension or revocation shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the contemplated action and
the date, time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be personally served or sent certified mail or overnight delivery to the licensee at the
licensee's last known address listed on the most recent application for a license at least five (5) calendar days prior to the date set for hearing.
2. The Director of Community Development, or his or her designee, shall present the Village's case. The license or permit holder shall have the right to
appear in person and be represented by legal counsel at such hearing. The licensee or permittee shall be afforded an opportunity to present
evidence and cross examine witnesses.
3. The Village Manager, or his or her designee, shall not be bound by common law or statutory rules of evidence or by technical or formal rules of
procedure, but shall conduct hearings in such manner as seems best calculated to result in substantial justice.
4. Following the conclusion of the hearing, the Village Manager, or his or her designee, shall issue a written decision and findings of fact and shall mail
the same to the applicant or license or permit holder. The written decision shall state that the applicant or license or permit holder may seek judicial
review of the decision pursuant to a writ of certiorari. The decision and findings of fact shall be mailed within seven (7) business days following the
conclusion of the hearing.
5. A court reporter, audio recording, or other method of creating a verbatim record of proceedings will be provided by the Village for all hearings held
pursuant to this chapter. The cost associated with the court reporter and/or the preparation of a transcript of the hearing shall be the responsibility of
the licensee or permittee.
6. Appeals of any final determination of the Village Manager or his or her designee following a hearing held pursuant to this section may be sought by
seeking a writ of certiorari from the Circuit Court of Cook County according to applicable law.

(E) Initial applications for a license, or for renewal of a license, may, in addition to any other grounds stated elsewhere in this Code, be denied by the
Village for any of the reasons set forth in subsection (A) of this section, or for other good cause. Any person aggrieved by the action of any Village
official in denying an application for a license or permit relative to operation of a business, whether for renewal or on initial application, or refusing to
accept a certificate of registration, shall have the right to a hearing before the Village Manager, or his or her designee, provided a written request is filed
with the Village Clerk within ten (10) calendar days after he or she is notified that the license or permit has been denied or the certificate of registration
will not be issued. The hearing provided shall follow the procedures set forth in subsections (D)2 through (D)6 of this section.
(F) Any contractor who is found by the Village Manager or his or her designee to have performed work within the Village without obtaining a required
license or permit on two (2) or more occasions during a thirty six (36) month period shall be subject to an automatic revocation of their business
license, if any, and shall be ineligible to obtain a business license, obtain permits, perform work or otherwise conduct business within the Village for a
period of two (2) years from the date of such finding. Penalties for contractors who perform work on a landmark structure or property without a permit
are in section 11-1-3-4 of this Code. (Ord. 2895, 1-21-2016)
3-1-6: FEES, TERMS AND EXPIRATION DATES:
There shall be added a processing fee in the amount provided in section 2-12-8 of this Code for every license or permit fee paid by check which is
returned for insufficient funds, or for any other reason which requires additional processing by the Village in order for said payment to be collectible. In
addition, a late fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be included in any fee amount whenever a required fee is paid more than two (2) weeks after the due date
or the renewal date.
Unless otherwise provided by ordinance applying particularly to the issuance of any license or permit, the maximum license or permit period, if any, the
expiration date and the fees for such license or permit shall be as set forth in the following tables, with the following exceptions: If the maximum period of
any license or permit is one year and the expiration date of the license or permit is six (6) months or less after the application date therefor, only one-half
(1/2) of the stipulated annual fee, or such smaller amount as may be specified below, shall be required. (Ord. 2648, 11-19-2007)

3-1-7: WORK OR OPERATION OF BUSINESS WITHOUT LICENSE OR PERMIT; DOUBLE FEE; AUTOMATIC SUSPENSION OF
CONTRACTORS:
(A) In the event that any installation, construction, erection or alteration work for which a license or permit is required by this Code, is started or proceeded
with prior to obtaining such license or permit, or any business or commercial activity regulated by the Village is conducted or operated without the
owner obtaining a license or permit as required under this Code, the fees specified in section 3-1-6 of this chapter, or elsewhere in this Code with
respect to said license or permit, shall be doubled, but the payment of such double fee shall not relieve any person from fully complying with the
requirements of this Code and the execution of the work nor from other penalties prescribed herein.
(B) Persons who conduct business or operate without obtaining a required license or permit may, in addition to the double fee set forth in subsection (A) of
this section, be subject to the suspension, revocation, denial or nonrenewal procedures set forth in section 3-1-5 of this chapter. Persons operating
under an existing license or permit shall be considered to be conducting business or operating without a required license or permit in violation of
section 3-1-2 of this chapter upon a failure to submit a required fee, application or other materials required by the Village for renewal within thirty (30)
days after expiration of the existing license or permit.
(C) Any contractor who is found by the Village Manager or his or her designee to have performed work within the Village without obtaining a required
license or permit on two (2) or more occasions during a thirty six (36) month period shall be subject to an automatic revocation of their business
license, if any, and shall be ineligible to obtain a business license, obtain permits, perform work or otherwise conduct business within the Village for a
period of two (2) years from the date of such finding. Penalties for contractors who perform work on a landmark structure or property without a permit
are in section 11-1-3-4 of this Code. (Ord. 2895, 1-21-2016)
3-1-8: PENALTY:
In addition to all other penalties provided in this Code, any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be subject to the penalty
as provided for in section 1-4-1 of this Code for each offense, and each day that such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2506,
8-16-2004)
3-1-9: POSTING:
Every person conducting a licensed or permitted business, activity, or occupation shall keep the applicable license or permit posted or displayed in a

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 103/519
prominent place on the business premises, licensed vehicle or licensed machine at all times. No license or permit that is not currently in full force and
effect shall be posted or displayed. (Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-1-10: REGULATORY INSPECTIONS:
(A) Village Inspections Authorized: Subject to constitutional limitations, every licensee or permittee shall permit authorized Village officials to enter the
business, activity, or occupational premises, including those areas of the premises not open to the general public, for the purpose of conducting
inspections to determine compliance with regulations applicable under the Village Building, Fire, Health, and other codes and ordinances and for the
purpose of taking necessary samples of any commodity or material to determine whether the licensee or permittee has complied with all applicable
regulatory requirements.
(B) Village Manager Responsibility: The Village Manager shall determine whether a licensee or permittee is complying with all applicable regulatory
requirements during the period of the license or permit. The Village Manager may authorize other Village personnel or agent authorized by the Village
board to make whatever inspections of the premises of a licensed or permitted business, activity, or occupation are reasonably necessary to secure
compliance with any code or ordinance provision, or to detect violations thereof, or to protect the public health and safety.
(C) Licensee Responsibility: The licensee, or the person in charge of the licensed premises, shall admit the authorized Village inspector into the premises
for the purpose of making inspection at any time during business hours or at any other reasonable hour upon reasonable notice to such person.
Whenever an analysis of any commodity or material is reasonably necessary to secure conformance with any code or ordinance provision or to detect
violations thereof, the licensee whose business is governed by such provisions shall give to any authorized Village officer or employee requesting the
same, sufficient samples of such material or commodity for such analysis. (Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-1-11: VENDING MACHINES:
(A) It shall be unlawful for any person to own, use, possess or place any merchandise vending machine anywhere within the corporate boundaries of
Riverside without having first obtained a license from the Village. Any vending machine containing and dispensing food products of any kind shall be
subject to the regulations set forth in title 7 of this Code, in addition to the provisions of this title, and shall be located within a building.
(B) Any vending machine license shall be prominently displayed on the machine. (Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-1-12: MOBILE FOOD UNITS:
(A) A "mobile food unit" is any vehicle, including a cart, designed to store and carry food for direct sales from the truck or other vehicle to the public for
consumption, provided that units for the direct sales of ice cream and other frozen dessert products, commonly known as ice cream trucks, shall be
strictly prohibited from operating in the Village, except pursuant to special permit for Village sponsored or approved special events.
(B) It shall be unlawful for any person to use or permit the use of any mobile food unit within the Village without having first obtained a license or permit
from the Village as required by this Code, nor shall any person use or permit the use of any mobile food unit within the Village in violation of this section
or in violation of the provisions of title 7 of this Code pertaining to food service and food sanitation, or inconsistent with the provisions of section 6-1-22
of this Code pertaining to peddlers. Where a conflict exists between any provision in this section and title 7 of this Code, food service and retail food
establishment regulations, the title 7 regulations shall apply.
(C) Mobile food units shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
(D) It is unlawful to permit stale food, decaying matter or any other waste material or product to accumulate in or on any mobile food unit while it is used for
such vending purposes.
(E) If unwrapped foodstuffs are carried on the mobile food unit for sale to the public, such goods shall be carried in a compartment or section of the
vehicle, which is screened or otherwise protected from dirt and insects.
(F) If perishable food is carried on the mobile food unit for sale to the public, such food shall be carried only within properly maintained and refrigerated or
heated receptacles.
(G) It is the duty of the Health Officer to make, or cause to be made, such inspections as may be necessary to ensure compliance with this section and
with the health and sanitation provisions of this Code pertaining to food service and food establishments.
(H) It is unlawful for any person to use or permit the use of any mobile food unit within the Village unless a license or permit has first been obtained.
(I) Any person desiring a license or permit as required in this section or by this Code shall file an application therefor with the Village Clerk. Such
application shall cite the name, address of and contact information for the owner of the vehicle or vehicles in question, the nature of the goods carried
on the vehicle, and the name, address of and contact information for the owner of the business if different from the owner of the vehicle(s). (Ord. 2506,
8-16-2004)

Chapter 2
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR
3-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter:
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Any malt, vinous, mixed or fermented liquor suitable for beverage purposes containing more than one-half of one percent (0.5%) of
alcohol by volume.
APPLICANT: Any person, firm, partnership or organization making application for a local retailer's liquor license as provided in this chapter.
BEER: A beverage obtained by alcoholic fermentation of an infusion or concoction of barley, or other grain, malt and hops in water, and includes among
other things, beer, ale, stout, lager beer, porter and the like.
BOTTLE: Wherever the verb "bottle" is used herein in connection with such alcoholic liquor, it shall refer to and include the packing thereof in bottles or
other containers for sale at retail.
BREWPUB: A full service restaurant that also serves alcoholic beverages, and which includes the on-site manufacture, storage and retail sale of beer for
consumption on or off the designated premises. A brewpub may also offer for sale at retail, for use and consumption on the licensed premises, any
alcoholic liquor purchased from a licensed distributor or importing distributor.
CRAFT BEER: A beer made by an American craft brewer that: a) has an annual production of six million (6,000,000) barrels of beer or less (beer
production is attributed to the rules of alternating proprietorships); b) less than twenty five percent (25%) of the craft brewery is owned or controlled (or
equivalent economic interest) by a beverage alcohol industry member that is not itself a craft brewer; and c) has a majority of its total beverage alcohol
volume in beers whose flavor derives from traditional or innovative brewing ingredients and their fermentation. Flavored malt beverages are not considered
craft beers.
CRAFT DISTILLERY: A facility for on site production and storage of alcoholic liquor beverages, including specifically spirits and wine, in quantities not to
exceed the number of gallons authorized for production each year by a craft distillery and limited wine manufacturer in the Liquor Control Act of 1934, and
which includes an accessory tasting room and/or retail outlet at which customers may consume and/or purchase products manufactured on site for on or
off premises consumption and purchase related sales items. Sales of food and nonalcoholic beverages are permitted, but the sale or consumption of
alcoholic liquor manufactured outside of the facility is prohibited.
LICENSE: The word "license" or "liquor license" shall include and refer to that specific grant of a privilege authorizing a license to sell or offer for sale
alcoholic liquor at retail only in the manner set forth in the wording of the license classification itself as well as in compliance with the rules and regulations
set forth in this chapter.
LICENSEE: That person granted the privilege by the Corporate Authorities of this Village to engage in the retail sale of alcoholic liquor.
MICROBREWERY: A facility for on site production and storage of craft beer in quantities no less than one hundred (100) barrels per year and no more
than fifteen thousand (15,000) barrels per year, that may include an accessory taproom and/or retail outlet where customers may consume and/or
purchase products manufactured on site for consumption either on site or off site and also purchase related sales items. Sales of food, craft beers, craft
cider and wine manufactured off site, and nonalcoholic beverages are permitted, but sales of any other alcoholic beverages manufactured off site are
prohibited. Sales of craft beer manufactured on site must constitute at least fifty percent (50%) of all craft beer sales annually. Sales of craft beer
manufactured on site may also be made to importing distributors or distributors in accordance with the Liquor Control Act of 1934.
ORIGINAL CONTAINER: Any bottle, flask, jug, can, barrel, keg, hogshead, container, or other receptacle whatsoever, used, corked or capped, sealed and
labeled by the manufacturer of alcoholic liquor to contain and to convey any alcoholic liquor.
PERSON: A natural person or persons, firm or corporation.
RESTAURANT: Any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are served, and which offers
patrons a luncheon and/or dinner menu.
SELL, SALE: Wherever the word "sell" or the noun "sale" is used herein with respect to such alcoholic liquor, it shall include and refer to the transfer, barter
or exchange thereof in any manner or by any means whatsoever and includes all sales made by any person, whether principal proprietor, agent, servant or
employee.
WINE: Any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of the natural contents of fruits or vegetables containing sugar. (Ord. 1490, 1-18-1982; amd.
Ord. 2389, 12-19-2001; Ord. 2778, 10-17-2011; Ord. 2908, 5-5-2016; Ord. 2930, 11-3-2016)
3-2-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person either directly or indirectly shall sell any alcoholic liquor at retail within the Village except as provided in this chapter and without securing a
license and complying with the provisions hereof. (Ord. 1490, 1-18-1982)
3-2-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; BOND; INSURANCE:
(A) Application for a local retailer's liquor license shall be made to the Village President as Local Liquor Control Commissioner, which application shall be
in writing, upon forms provided by the Village Manager and signed by the applicant, if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof, if a
corporation, verified by oath or affidavit, and shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each
applicant and/or individual required to be identified in the application to defray the costs of investigation by the Chief of Police. The application shall
contain the following information: (Ord. 2298, 11-15-1999)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 105/519
1. The name, address and date of birth of the applicant in the case of an individual; in the case of a copartnership, the names, addresses and dates of
birth, of the persons entitled to share in the profits thereof, and the date of the formation of the copartnership; and in the case of a corporation, the
names and addresses of the officers and directors, and (if an aggregate of more than 5 percent of the stock of such corporation is owned by 1
person or his nominee) the name and address of such stockholder and his nominee.
2. The citizenship of the applicant, place of birth, age, marital status, length of time as a Riverside resident, and if a naturalized citizen, the time and
place of such naturalization.
3. The character of business of the applicant; and in the case of a corporation, the objects for which it was formed.
4. The length of time said applicant has been in business of that character, the character or type of business of the applicant heretofore; and in the
case of a corporation, the date and state of incorporation, and if incorporated in a state other than Illinois, the date qualified under the business
corporation act to do business in Illinois.
5. The location and description of the premises or place of business which is to be operated under such license, and the name and address of the
landlord if the premises are leased.
6. A statement whether the applicant is an elected public official; and whether any other person, directly or indirectly in the applicant's place of business
is an elected public official.
7. A statement, in the case of the renewal of a license, whether the applicant made any political contributions within the past two (2) years and the
particulars thereof.
8. A statement whether applicant holds any law enforcement office; and if so, what title.
9. A statement whether the applicant possesses a current federal wagering or gambling device stamp; and if so, the reasons therefor.
10. A statement that the applicant has never been convicted of a felony and is otherwise not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or
thing contained in this chapter, the laws of the state or the ordinances of this village.
11. A statement as to the applicant's current state liquor license number, if any.
12. A statement whether the applicant has made application for a similar or other license on premises other than those described in this application and
the disposition of such application.
13. A statement whether a previous license by any state or subdivision thereof, or by the federal government has been revoked and the reasons
therefor.
14. A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of the state or of the United States or any ordinance of the village in the conduct of
applicant's place of business.
15. The name, address and date of birth, of the manager or agent of the applicant in charge of premises.
16. A statement as to dramshop insurance coverage on applicant or if not owner of premises, dramshop insurance coverage on owner of premises
thereof.
(B) Such application may require the applicant to furnish other reasonable information as may be determined by the local liquor control commissioner.
(C) Before any license shall be issued to the applicant:
1. The applicant shall furnish the village a surety bond in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) acceptable to the village. Such bond shall
provide against any violation by the principal, his agents, or employees, of any of the terms of this chapter, as amended, or any ordinances, rules and
regulations now in force or which may hereafter be in force in said village affecting the operation of his business. (Ord. 1490, 1-18-1982)
2. The applicant shall submit to the Riverside police department the names of all bartenders, managers, all principals, the applicant himself (in the case
of an individual), all partners, and (in the case of a corporation), all officers, and all stockholders owning an aggregate of more than five percent (5%)
of the stock of such corporation. In addition, the applicant may also be required to submit the fingerprints of some or all of those individuals in order
that the Riverside police department may perform adequate investigation of such persons to enable the local liquor control commissioner to ascertain
that issuance of any such license will comply with the statutes of the state and all applicable ordinances of the village. (Ord. 2685, 10-20-2008)
3. The applicant shall obtain and furnish the village proof of dramshop insurance covering the licensed premises in the maximum insurance coverage
limit so as to insure, protect and save harmless the applicant, the owner or lessee of the premises, and the person making liquor sales on the
premises and the village from all financial loss, damage, harm or liability growing out of the sale of alcoholic liquor pursuant to a liquor license issued
to the applicant. (Ord. 1490, 1-18-1982)
4. The applicant shall obtain the proper business license from the village and shall keep the same in force throughout the full term of any license issued
pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2143, 3-4-1996)
(D) Upon issuance of any license, the licensee thereof shall keep the information contained on this application current by furnishing the local liquor control
commissioner with such information within thirty (30) days of any change in status regarding ownership, residence, management and/or surety bond.
(Ord. 1490, 1-18-1982)
3-2-4: RESTRICTIONS ON ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
(A) No liquor license shall be issued to:
1. A person who is not a resident of the village.
2. A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community in which he resides.
