https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 106/519
3. A person who is not a citizen of the United States.
4. A person who has been convicted of a gambling offense or felony under any federal or state law.
5. A person who has been convicted of being the keeper of or keeping a house of ill fame.
6. A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality.
7. A person whose license under this chapter or under the state liquor law has been revoked for cause.
8. A person who at the time of application for renewal of any license issued hereunder would not be eligible for such license upon a first application.
9. A copartnership, unless all of the members of such copartnership shall be qualified to obtain a license.
10. A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%) of
the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residence within the
Village.
11. A corporation unless it is incorporated in Illinois, or unless it is a foreign corporation which is qualified under the Illinois Business Corporation Act to
transact business in Illinois.
12. A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent, unless said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required
of the licensee.
13. A person who has been convicted of a violation of any Federal or State law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor, or
who shall have forfeited his bond to appear in court in answer to charges for any such violation.
14. A person who is not the owner or does not beneficially own the premises for which a license is sought, or does not have a lease thereon for the full
period for which the license is to be issued.
15. Any law enforcing public official, the Village President, and any member of the Board of Trustees, and no such official shall be interested in any
way, either directly or indirectly in the manufacture, sale or distribution of alcoholic liquors.
16. A person, association or corporation not eligible for or not possessing a State retail liquor dealer's license.
17. A person, copartnership (or any of the partners thereof) or corporation (by any officer, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder owning more
than 20 percent of the stock of such corporation) possessing a current Federal gaming device or wagering stamp, and any premises for which a
current Federal gaming device or wagering stamp has been issued. (Ord. 1490, 1-18-1982)
18. A person, copartnership or corporation which does not hold the proper business license, or which suffers such business license to be suspended,
revoked or not renewed at the time of application, during the issuance period, or at the time of renewal of any license issued hereunder. (Ord. 2143,
3-4-1996)
3-2-5: CLASSES OF LICENSES; PERMITS:
(A) Except as may be provided for the issuance of certain permits under the terms of subsection (B) of this Section, every person engaged in the retail sale
of alcoholic liquor in the Village shall first have obtained a suitable liquor license authorizing the specific type and character of such alcoholic liquor sale
as may be contemplated in such retail business. Such licenses shall be divided into the following classifications:
CLASS A license, which shall authorize the licensee to sell and offer for sale at retail in the premises specified in such license, beer and wine in the
original container only and not for consumption on the premises where sold. (Ord. 1490, 1-18-1982)
CLASS A-1 license, which shall permit the retail sale of alcoholic liquor in sealed packages but not for consumption on the premises where sold.
Holders of Class A-1 licenses shall be permitted to conduct alcoholic liquor sampling or tasting promotions upon the licensed premises; provided,
that no charge shall be made therefor. (Ord. 2299, 11-15-1999)
CLASS B-SPECIAL license, which shall authorize the licensee to sell and offer for sale at retail in the premises specified in such license, beer, wine
and alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises at the facilities of the Chicago Zoological Society on land owned by the Forest Preserve
District of Cook County, under the following conditions:
1. Sales and consumption of beer and wine shall be restricted to the Oak Grove Picnic Area, the Safari Stop Restaurant and outside adjacent area
and the patio area located in the Bear Gardens.
2. Sales and consumption of beer, wine and alcoholic liquor shall be restricted to private catered or special events. These events are not restricted
by area.
3. Persons under twenty one (21) years of age will not be allowed in the above designated serving areas unless accompanied by an adult, parent
or guardian.
4. No alcoholic beverages shall be removed from the above designated serving areas.
5. Adequate security personnel shall be stationed within each of the above designated serving areas to ensure compliance with the conditions
herein established. (Ord. 2283, 5-17-1999)
CLASS C license, which shall authorize the licensee to sell, in restaurants only, as specified in the license, beer and wine for consumption on the
premises where sold, and when provided as part of the service of a complete meal to patrons seated at a table or booth in the restaurant. No such
license shall be granted to or retained by any establishment in which the facilities for food preparation and service are not primarily those for a
"restaurant", as defined in this chapter. Beer and wine may be sold only during that period when complete meals are being prepared and offered to
patrons, and service of such beer and wine shall be provided at tables only by employees of the restaurant serving as waiters or waitresses. There
shall be no internal signage or display of beer and wine in bottles within the restaurant premises, nor shall there be any outside signage to indicate
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 107/519
that beer and wine is sold on the premises. (Ord. 1692, 4-21-1986)
CLASS D license, which shall authorize the licensee to sell, in bowling alleys licensed under this Code and containing six (6) or less bowling lanes as
specified in the license, alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises where sold. Alcoholic liquors may be sold only to patrons of the bowling
alley or when food service is provided. Only employees of the licensed establishment shall provide service of such alcoholic liquors. There shall be
no outside signage to indicate that alcoholic liquors are sold on the premises. (Ord. 2483, 2-2-2004)
CLASS E license, which shall authorize the licensee to sell, in restaurants only, as specified in the license, alcoholic liquors for consumption on the
premises where sold. No such license shall be granted to or retained by any establishment in which the facilities for food preparation and service are
not primarily those for a "restaurant", as defined in this chapter. There shall be no internal fixed signage within the restaurant premises, nor shall
there be any outside signage to indicate that alcoholic liquors are sold on the premises.
CLASS E-1 add-on license, which shall authorize a Class E licensee to sell and offer for sale at retail in the premises specified in such license,
alcoholic liquor in original sealed containers for off-premises consumption, and to make off-premises delivery of alcoholic liquor sold at retail in
original sealed containers, subject to the following requirements:
1. Other than single representative samples, floor displays of alcoholic liquor offered for sale pursuant to a Class E-1 license are prohibited;
2. All off-premises deliveries shall be made by BASSET trained agents or employees of the licensee who are eighteen (18) years of age or older;
3. The agent or employee delivering the alcoholic liquor off-premises shall confirm that the recipient is over twenty one (21) years of age prior to
delivering the alcoholic liquor, and shall require the signature of the recipient to confirm the same;
4. Off-premises deliveries of alcoholic liquor shall only be made when accompanying a delivery order for food; and
5. All payment for the alcoholic liquor being delivered off-premises must be made in advance; no payment or orders may be made at the delivery
location.
CLASS P brewpub license, which shall authorize the on-site manufacture and storage of beer at a designated premises and the making of sales to
importing distributors and distributors, as well as the direct retail sale to nonlicensee consumers for consumption off the designated premises in
sealed containers or on the designated premises through a full-service restaurant, all in conformance with State law. The number of gallons of beer
sold by a brewpub each year for off-premises consumption shall not exceed the number of gallons authorized for sale each year by a brewpub in the
Liquor Control Act of 19341. Class P licensees must have at least one (1) BASSET certified site manager on premises whenever offering alcohol for
sale. Every Class P licensee must have a valid brewpub license from the State of Illinois. A brewpub may also offer for sale at retail, for use and
consumption on the licensed premises, any alcoholic liquor purchased from a licensed distributor or importing distributor. (Ord. 2930, 11-3-2016)
CLASS Q microbrewery license, which shall authorize the on site manufacture and storage of craft beer at a designated premises and the making of
sales to importing distributors and distributors, as well as the direct retail sale to nonlicensee consumers for consumption off site in sealed containers
or on the designated premises in an accessory taproom. The number of gallons of beer sold by a microbrewery each year for off premises
consumption shall not exceed the number of gallons authorized for sale each year by a brewpub as defined in the Liquor Control Act of 1934. Class
Q licensees must have at least one (1) BASSET certified site manager on premises whenever offering alcohol for sale. Every Class Q licensee must
have a valid brewpub license from the State of Illinois. (Ord. 2908, 5-5-2016)
CLASS W-1 wine bar license, which shall authorize wine by the glass for consumption with and without food on the premises or sale of wine by the
bottle for consumption on or off the premises. Wine sales shall be limited to those hours when food service is available. Only employees of the
licensed establishment shall provide service of such alcoholic liquors. (Ord. 2525, 3-21-2005)
CLASS X craft distillery license, which shall authorize the on site production and storage of alcoholic liquor beverages, including specifically spirits
and wine, in quantities not to exceed the number of gallons authorized for production each year by a craft distillery and limited wine manufacturer in
the Liquor Control Act of 19342, for sale by the bottle for off premises consumption or by the glass for consumption in an accessory tasting room or
retail outlet. A tasting room or retail outlet allows patrons to taste samples of products manufactured on site, and to purchase products by the glass
or bottle for either on site or off premises consumption, and to purchase related sales items. Sales of alcohol manufactured outside the site are
prohibited. Class X licensees must have at least one (1) BASSET certified site manager on premises whenever offering tasting samples of alcohol.
Every Class X licensee must have a valid craft distiller license, and, if applicable, a limited wine manufacturer's license, from the State of Illinois.
Sales of food and nonalcoholic beverages are permitted, but the sale or consumption of alcoholic liquor manufactured outside of the facility is
prohibited. (Ord. 2908, 5-5-2016)
(B) A daily permit may be granted by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner to any of the seven (7) established church organizations upon the written
request of said organization, which shall authorize the permittee to sell or serve alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises where sold, under the
following conditions:
1. Sales or serving of alcoholic liquor shall be limited to periods when groups are assembled on church premises or at an approved public site solely for
the promotion of some common object or church sponsored function other than the sale or consumption of alcoholic liquor.
2. Sales and consumption of alcoholic liquor shall be limited to a continuous period of time not exceeding eight (8) hours.
3. Permit holders must obtain dramshop insurance as heretofore required for license applicants.
(C) A special permit may be granted by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner to any established church, social, civic or fraternal organization or other
recognized association or affiliated group, upon the written request of said church, organization, association or group, which shall authorize the
permittee to sell or serve alcoholic liquor for consumption within any public building or at an approved public site owned by the Village, or other
governmental entity, under the following conditions:
1. Sales or serving of alcoholic liquor shall be limited to periods when the church, organization, association or group is assembled within the public
building or at an approved public site solely for the promotion of some common object or function other than the sale or consumption of alcoholic
liquor which shall be incidental thereto.
2. Sales and consumption of alcoholic liquor shall be limited to a continuous period of time not exceeding eight (8) hours.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 108/519
3. No more than six (6) such special permits shall be issued to any one (1) church, organization, association or group during the period of one (1) year.
4. Permit holders must obtain the approval of the Village and/or the other governmental entity owning, or having control or supervision over the public
building or approved public site, and shall abide by such other rules and regulations as are established by the Village and/or other governmental
entity for the use of such public building or approved public site.
5. Permit holders must obtain dramshop insurance as heretofore required for license applicants. (Ord. 2507, 8-16-2004, eff. 8-20-2004)

3-2-7: LICENSE TERM; RENEWAL:
(A) Each license shall commence on May 1 and shall terminate on April 30 next following the date of issuance.
(B) Any licensee may renew his license at the expiration thereof, provided that he is then qualified to receive a license and the premises for which such
renewal license is sought is suitable for that purpose; provided further, that the renewal privilege herein provided for shall not be construed as a vested
right which shall in any case prevent the Local Liquor Control Commissioner from decreasing the number of licenses to be issued within his jurisdiction.
(Ord. 1490, 1-18-1982)
3-2-8: NUMBER OF LICENSES:
(A) Number Of Licenses; Increase And Decrease: The Board of Trustees shall determine, by ordinance, the number of licenses that are available in each
classification. A liquor license may be issued to an applicant by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner only after such license has been created by the
Board of Trustees. Neither the Commissioner nor any other person or entity may issue liquor licenses in a number that is in excess of the number
authorized for each classification by the Board of Trustees. An up to date schedule of the authorized number of licenses available in each classification
shall be maintained by, and available from, the Village Clerk. When a liquor license expires and is not renewed or is revoked or terminated, the number
of authorized licenses in a particular class shall automatically be reduced by the total number of nonrenewed, revoked or terminated licenses. The
Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall notify, in writing, the Village Clerk and Board of Trustees of the revocation or termination of any authorized
license within seven (7) days of such occurrence.
(B) Cessation Of Business: When a licensee, for a period of thirty (30) continuous days, ceases to sell alcoholic liquors or to engage in some other activity
required for that class of liquor license, that license shall automatically terminate and the number of licenses available in that class shall immediately
and automatically be reduced by one (1). For purposes of this section, "ceases to sell alcoholic beverages" shall mean any failure to make alcoholic
liquor of the kind permitted by the specific license available to the public at the licensed premises. This shall include failure for any reason, except for
periods during which the liquor license of the premises was suspended for cause by order of the Local Liquor Control Commissioner of the Village or,
following written notice to the Local Liquor Control Commissioner in advance of the closing, the closing of the premises for remodeling or repairs for
which proper permits have been obtained and work is taking place. (Ord. 2773, 5-6-2011)

3-2-10: TRANSFER OF LICENSE:
(A) Personal Privilege: A license shall be purely a personal privilege, good for not to exceed one (1) year after issuance, unless sooner revoked as in this
chapter provided, and shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution, nor shall it be alienable or
transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily, or subject to being otherwise encumbered or liened.
(B) No Vested Right: Nothing contained in this chapter or section shall create any vested or property right in any liquor license in any person whatsoever,
nor shall it limit or restrict the right of the Village to at any time amend or repeal this chapter.
(C) Death Or Bankruptcy: A license shall cease upon the death, insolvency or bankruptcy of the licensee or, when issued to a partnership, the death of a
partner of a licensee, and shall not descend by the laws of testate or intestate devolution, provided that executors or administrators of the estate of any
deceased licensee or partner of a licensee, and the trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when such estate consists in part of alcoholic liquor
may, upon written notice to the Local Liquor Control Commissioner, continue the business of the sale of alcoholic liquor under the order of the
appropriate court, and may exercise the privileges of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee after the death of decedent, or such insolvency, or
bankruptcy until the expiration of such license, but not longer than six (6) months after the death, bankruptcy or insolvency of such licensee or partner
of a licensee. If a corporation to whom a license has been issued is ordered into receivership or files for bankruptcy, the receiver or trustee may
continue the operation of the business under the existing license under order of the appropriate court until the expiration of such license, but not longer
than six (6) months after the date of appointment of a receiver or trustee, whichever comes first. At the time of expiration of the license or passage of
six (6) months following death, bankruptcy or appointment of a receiver or trustee as specified in this subsection, the liquor license shall automatically
terminate and the number of available licenses in that classification shall automatically and immediately be reduced by one (1).
(D) Changes In Ownership:
1. When the licensee is a partnership, limited liability company or a corporation whose stock is not publicly traded on a recognized stock exchange, the
license shall terminate whenever fifty percent (50%) or more of the ownership interest therein changes from that shown on the original license
application, except as provided for in this subsection. Prior to a transfer of fifty percent (50%) or more of the ownership, the partnership, limited
liability company or corporation, through its officers/members/partners, shall submit a complete application and the required fees for the issuance of
a new license, as provided herein, and said application is subject to approval by the Board of the Trustees and the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner, in their sole discretion, and such approval is necessary for the new ownership to sell and/or serve alcoholic beverages. In the event
that the transfer of ownership occurs prior to the approval of the application, the new corporate ownership shall be prohibited from selling and/or
serving alcoholic beverages at the applied for location until the application is approved by the Board of Trustees and the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner and all required fees for the liquor license have been paid to the Village.
2. When the licensee is a corporation whose stock is publicly traded on a recognized stock exchange, the license shall automatically terminate
whenever fifty percent (50%) or more of the membership of the Board of Directors of the corporation changes from that shown on the original license
application, or whenever one (1) person who was not shown as an owner of fifty percent (50%) or more of the ownership interest in the publicly
traded corporation at the time of the original liquor license application, becomes an owner of a fifty percent (50%) or more ownership interest in the
publicly traded corporation. In such event, the corporation, through its officers/Board of Directors, must make application for the issuance of a new
license as provided in this chapter.
3. When the licensee is a partnership, limited liability company or corporation, no change in ownership from that shown on the original application
involving the addition of a new partner or member of such partnership or limited liability company or a new shareholder who will own in the aggregate
more than five percent (5%) of the stock of such corporation shall be effective until such proposed change in ownership has first been reported in
writing to the Local Liquor Control Commissioner and the Commissioner finds that the proposed new partner(s) or shareholder(s) is/are not ineligible
under the provisions of this chapter and so advises the licensee in writing. Any change in ownership without complying with the terms hereof shall
constitute grounds for a fine and/or the suspension or revocation of the liquor license issued to such partnership or corporation.
4. When the licensee is a partnership, limited liability company or corporation whose stock is not publicly traded on a recognized stock exchange, no
change in ownership from that shown on the original application involving the withdrawal of any partner, manager or shareholder shall be made
without reporting such change in ownership in writing to the Local Liquor Control Commissioner within ten (10) days of any such change in
ownership. Any such change in ownership made without complying with the terms hereof shall constitute grounds for a fine and/or the suspension or
revocation of the liquor license issued to such partnership, limited liability company or corporation.
(E) Termination Upon Transfer: Upon the alienation, sale, transfer, assignment or donation of the business that underlies the license to any third party or
person other than the licensee or as otherwise authorized by this section, the liquor license shall automatically terminate and the number of available
licenses in that classification shall automatically and immediately be reduced by one. (Ord. 2773, 5-6-2011)
3-2-11: CHANGE OF LOCATION:
A liquor license shall permit the sale of alcoholic liquor only on the premises described in the application and license. Such location may be changed only
upon a written permission to make such change issued by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner. No change of location shall be permitted unless the
proposed new location is a proper one for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor under the laws of this State and this chapter and the ordinances of the Village.
(Ord. 1490, 1-18-1982)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 111/519
3-2-12: REGULATIONS AND RESTRICTIONS:
(A) No Manufacturing Or Bottling: Except for alcoholic liquor manufactured by a licensed craft distillery, or beer manufactured by a licensed brewpub or
microbrewery, no alcoholic liquor intended for sale shall be manufactured or bottled within the Village. (Ord. 2908, 5-5-2016)
(B) No Sale Or Consumption On Unlicensed Premises: No liquor shall be sold, offered for sale, kept for sale, displayed or advertised for sale at retail or
delivered to any person purchasing same at retail except at a location, place or premises described in a retail liquor license or permit. It shall be
unlawful for anyone not having a license or permit providing for consumption on the premises where sold, to offer for sale, sell or donate any alcoholic
beverage for consumption on any premises open to the general public, or to permit the same to be consumed where sold or donated. (Ord. 1490, 1-18-
1982)
(C) No Possession Or Consumption In Public Places: No person shall open any container of alcoholic liquor, or have in his possession any open container
of alcoholic liquor, or consume any alcoholic liquor in or upon any street, park, public way, public sidewalk, public parking lot or public school, or in any
public building owned by the Village or other governmental entity unless a special permit has been obtained as otherwise provided for in this chapter
for use of such public building.
(D) No Sale In Public Buildings: No alcoholic liquor shall be sold or delivered in any public building owned by or under the control of the Village or other
governmental entity except pursuant to the issuance of a special permit as herein provided for in this chapter. (Ord. 2143, 2-4-1996)
(E) No Sale Or Delivery To Minors And Intoxicated Persons: No person shall sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor to any person under the age of twenty one
(21) years except in the performance of a religious ceremony or service, or sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor to any intoxicated person or to any
person known to be a habitual drunkard, or insane, or mentally ill. Nor shall any owner, lessee or occupant of any premises located within this Village
knowingly allow any person under the age of twenty one (21) to possess, dispense or consume alcoholic liquor on said premises, except where
pursuant to a religious service or ceremony in an established church or where said owner, lessee or occupant is the parent of such minor and is
exercising direct supervision and approval over the possession, dispensing or consumption of alcoholic liquor by the minor in the privacy of the minor's
home. (Ord. 1527, 2-21-1983)
(F) No Advertising: No sign or advertisement of any alcoholic liquor shall be placed upon or outside any building in the Village, except as herein provided
for in title 4, chapter 3, "Signs", of this Code, with respect to the retail sale of alcoholic liquor by a holder of a Class A, C or E liquor license in this
Village. (Ord. 2998, 8-16-2018)
(G) No Peddling: No person shall peddle alcoholic liquor in the Village.
(H) No Purchase, Sale And/Or Use Or Consumption By Minors: No person under the age of twenty one (21) years shall purchase, sell, accept a gift or
delivery of or have in his possession any alcoholic liquor, nor consume the same in this Village except where pursuant to a religious service or
ceremony in an established church or under direct parental supervision and approval in the privacy of a home.
(I) No Sales Near Churches, Schools Or School Supply Stores: Except as herein provided for permitted church sponsored functions, no person shall sell at
retail, and no liquor license shall be issued, for the sale of alcoholic liquor within one hundred feet (100') of any church or school or for the sale of any
alcoholic liquor at any store or other place of business where the majority of customers are minors of school age or where the principal business
transacted consists of schoolbooks, school supplies, food, lunches or drinks for such minors. (Ord. 1490, 1-18-1982)
(J) BASSET Training: The licensee, each on site manager and all sales, waitstaff and other employees engaged in the selling, serving or delivery of
alcoholic beverages to customers, guests or patrons, for consumption on or off the premises, shall take and successfully complete a Beverage Alcohol
Sellers and Servers Education and Training (BASSET) Program that has been certified by the State of Illinois. A copy of the BASSET course
completion certificate(s) for each such person shall be made available at all times at the licensed premises for inspection by the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner, or his or her designee. (Ord. 2930, 11-3-2016)
3-2-13: POSTING LICENSE:
Every person listed to sell alcoholic liquor shall post his license in a conspicuous place in his place of business. (Ord. 1490, 1-18-1982)
3-2-14: VIOLATION A NUISANCE:
All places within the Village wherein any alcoholic liquor is or shall be sold or consumed in violation of the provisions of this chapter are hereby declared to
be nuisances and may be abated as such by the Police Department or at suit of the Village or any citizen thereof, notwithstanding any penalty or other
remedy in this Code provided. (Ord. 1490, 1-18-1982)
3-2-15: PENALTY:
(A) Suspension Or Revocation Of License: The Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall have the power to suspend or revoke any liquor license issued
under the provisions of this chapter for cause, or if he or she determines that the licensee shall have violated any of the provisions of this Code, any of
the statutes of the State or any other valid ordinance or resolution enacted by the Board of Trustees of the Village. However, no such license shall be
revoked or suspended except after the holding of a public hearing by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner pursuant to the provisions of section 7-5
of the Liquor Control Act of 19343.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 112/519
(B) Fine Imposed: In addition, the Local Liquor Control Commissioner, if he or she finds it to be in the public good, may, after a public hearing, fine the
licensee in an amount not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for the first violation of this chapter within a twelve (12) month period, one
thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for a second violation within a twelve (12) month period, and two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00)
for a third or subsequent violation within a twelve (12) month period. Each day on which a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation. No
more than fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) in fines may be imposed against any licensee during the period of the license.
(C) Penalty Options: Based upon the evidence at hearing, the Local Liquor Control Commissioner may enter an order:
1. Revoking the licensee's license; or
2. Suspending the licensee's license; or
3. Suspending the licensee's license and fining the licensee as provided above; or
4. Fining the licensee as provided in subsection (B) of this section.
Upon revocation of a licensee's license, the number of available licenses in that classification as authorized by the Board of Trustees shall
automatically and immediately be reduced by one (1), and no license shall thereafter be granted to such licensee.
(D) Appeals: All appeals from orders of the Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall be limited to a review of the official record of proceedings of such
Local Liquor Control Commissioner as provided for in Liquor Control Act of 1934, section 7-94. Within five (5) days after the notice of an appeal has
been filed with the State Liquor Control Commission, a certified official record of the proceedings for the Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall be
filed with the State of Illinois Liquor Control Commission; provided, however, that the appellant licensee pays for the cost of the transcript as provided
by section 7-9 of the Liquor Control Act of 19345.
(E) Criminal Penalties: Nothing in this chapter shall act to bar the imposition of any applicable criminal penalties, including incarceration, provided for
pursuant to State Statute. (Ord. 2773, 5-6-2011)
3-2-16: SALE BY PRESCRIPTION:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the sale of alcoholic liquor by any apothecary or druggist upon a written order or prescription signed by a
physician regularly licensed and practicing his profession, provided such order or prescription shall be retained and kept on file by such druggist or
apothecary open to the inspection of the Local Liquor Control Commission and Chief of Police of the Village. (Ord. 1490, 1-18-1982)
3-2-17: STATE AND FEDERAL REGULATIONS:
In addition to the requirements of this chapter, no person shall sell alcoholic liquor within the Village without complying with the provisions of the statutes of
the State and of the United States, if any, with respect to such sale. (Ord. 1490, 1-18-1982)
3-2-18: LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER; DEPUTY COMMISSIONER:
The Village President shall be the Local Liquor Control Commissioner and shall be charged with the administration of the provisions of this chapter and of
the appropriate provisions of the Liquor Control Act6 and of the appropriate Federal regulations pertaining to alcoholic liquor. The Village President may
appoint a Deputy Liquor Commissioner to exercise and carry out the powers and duties of a Liquor Control Commissioner. (Ord. 1490, 1-18-1982)
Chapter 3
AUCTIONS, AUCTIONEERS AND ESTATE SALES
3-3-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No personal property, goods, wares or merchandise shall be sold at an auction or estate sale in the village except in compliance with the provisions of this
chapter, and it shall be unlawful to sell, or cause or permit to be sold at an auction or estate sale, any personal property, goods, wares or merchandise in
this village unless such sale is conducted by an individual who has obtained a village license and who holds a valid and current license from the state.
(Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-3-2: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
The village manager is hereby authorized to issue and renew an auction or estate sale license for a period as set forth in section 3-1-6 of this title to any
individual applying therefor on an application form provided by said village manager, together with payment of the license fees and filing of surety bond
hereinafter provided in this chapter. (Ord. 2199, 9-15-1997; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-3-3: FORM OF APPLICATION:
The form of application for an auction or estate sale license shall require the following information and supporting documentation:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 113/519
(A) The name and residence address of the applicant.
(B) The business address of and contact information for the applicant.
(C) A statement as to whether or not the applicant holds or has held an auctioneer's license or a license to conduct estate sales from any state,
municipality or other licensing authority; a list of such licenses, if any, including the time, place and by whom issued; a statement as to whether any
state, municipality or other licensing authority has ever refused to issue or to renew such license, or has ever revoked the same, together with a
statement as to the reasons therefor; and a statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of burglary, theft, housebreaking,
robbery or any other crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude.
Every application shall be accompanied by a photograph of the applicant taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of the filing of the
application. In addition, the applicant shall attach to the application a copy of his or her current state of Illinois auctioneer license. All applications shall be
referred to the chief of police for such investigation of the applicant's moral character and reputation as he deems necessary for the protection of the public
good. The police chief shall conduct his investigation within a reasonable time, and shall report his findings to the village manager. (Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-3-4: LICENSE FEES:
The fees for an auction, or auctioneer, or estate sale license shall be as set forth in section 3-1-6 of this title. (Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-3-5: BOND REQUIRED:
Every applicant for an auction or estate sale license shall file with the village manager a surety bond running to the village in the amount of one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00), with surety acceptable to and approved by the president of the board of trustees, and conditioned upon the applicant's compliance
with all the provisions of this code and the statutes of the state regulating and concerning auctions, auctioneers, and estate sales, and further that such
applicant will render true and strict accounts of all his sales to the person employing him to make the same, and will not practice any fraud or deceit upon
bidders or purchasers of property from him at any auction or estate sale, and will pay all damages which may be sustained by any person by reason of any
fraud, deceit, negligence or other unlawful act on the part of the applicant in the conduct of any auction or estate sale or in the exercise of the calling of
auctioneer. A liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the state which conforms to the above requirements
may be permitted by the president of the board of trustees in lieu of a surety bond. (Ord. 2199, 9-15-1997)
3-3-6: RESTRICTIONS:
(A) Auctions And Estate Sales Prohibited On Streets, Sidewalks And Public Property: It shall be unlawful to conduct an auction or estate sale of personal
property, goods, wares or merchandise on any of the streets, sidewalks, parkways, parks or other public property of the village.
(B) Night Auctions And Estate Sales Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to offer for sale at auction or to sell at auction or estate sale any personal property,
goods, wares or merchandise between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) P.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. (Ord. 2199, 9-15-1997)
3-3-7: JUDICIAL SALES EXEMPTED:
The provisions of this chapter shall not be applicable to auction or estate sales conducted by trustees or referees in bankruptcy, or by executors,
administrators or guardians of an estate, or by receivers or other public officials acting under judicial process; nor shall the provisions of this chapter be
applicable to sales of real property. In addition, all exemptions listed in section 10-1 of the auction license act, 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 407/5-1 et
seq., shall pertain to auction activities conducted in the village. (Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-3-8: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
In addition to revocation for noncompliance with any provisions of this chapter or any other provisions of this code, all in accordance with section 3-1-5 of
this title, an auction or estate sale license may be suspended or revoked, or an application for issuance or renewal of such license may be refused in
accordance with the procedures set forth in section 3-1-5 of this title where it is determined:
(A) That the applicant or license holder is not an individual of good character and reputation; or
(B) That the application of the applicant or license holder contains any false, fraudulent, or misleading material statement; or
(C) That the applicant or license holder has made any false, fraudulent, or misleading material statement in the course of conducting an auction or estate
sale or in offering for sale any personal property, goods, wares or merchandise in the village; or
(D) That the applicant or license holder has perpetrated a fraud upon any person whether or not such fraud was perpetrated in the conduct of an auction or
estate sale in the village; or
(E) That the applicant or license holder has violated any of the statutes of the state relating to auction, auctioneers, or estate sales, including pertinent
provisions of the uniform commercial code; or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 114/519
(F) That the applicant has been convicted of any felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or
(G) That the applicant or license holder has conducted an auction or estate sale or offered for sale, any personal property, goods, wares or merchandise in
the village in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the
public; or
(H) That the applicant or license holder has violated the provisions of this code or any other ordinances of the village. (Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
Chapter 4
BARBERSHOPS AND HAIR SALONS
3-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
BARBERSHOP: Any establishment where the practice of barbering is accomplished, and shall include any establishment commonly known and identified
as a beauty shop, salon, beauty salon, hair salon, day spa, and spa. Any one or any combination of the following practices constitutes the "practice of
barbering": to shave or trim the beard or cut the hair; to style, arrange, dress, curl, wave, straighten, clean, singe, epilate, depilate, shampoo, marcel,
chemically restructure, bleach, tint, color or similarly work upon the hair of any person; to give facial or scalp massages or treatments with oils, creams or
other preparations either by hand or by mechanical appliances. (Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-4-2: LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
(A) State Certificate Of Registration: No person shall establish, maintain, or operate a barbershop in the village without first having obtained a certificate of
registration issued by the Illinois department of professional responsibility pursuant to the Illinois barber, cosmetology, esthetics, and nail technology act
of 1985, 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 410/1-1 et seq.
(B) Village License: No person shall sell or hold for sale or resale at retail any products within a barbershop in the village without first having obtained a
license therefor, which license must be renewed each year by payment of the annual license fee hereinafter provided. (Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-4-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for said license shall be made in writing to the village manager on provided forms. The applicant shall attach to the application a copy of the
certificate of registration for the location for which a license is sought, and shall maintain said certificate in good standing with the department of
professional regulation. (Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
Chapter 5
BOWLING ALLEYS
3-5-1: DEFINITION:
The words "bowling alley" wherever used in this chapter shall be held to include bowling alleys, pin and ball alleys, box ball alleys, skee ball alleys and all
alleys of similar character. (1965 Code, Sec. 53.01; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-5-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct any bowling alley within the village without first obtaining a license therefor as herein provided. (1965 Code, Sec. 53.02; amd.
Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-5-3: APPLICATION, INVESTIGATION, ISSUANCE:
Any person desiring to conduct any bowling alley within this village shall make application therefor in writing to the village manager, which application shall
state the name, residence, citizenship and employment or business of the applicant during the previous five (5) years, whether or not the applicant was
ever convicted of a felony or misdemeanor and whether or not the applicant owns real estate and the value thereof. Such applicant shall also give
reference to three (3) householders in this village. Such application shall be referred to the chief of police for investigation as to the moral status of the
applicant and the moral conditions surrounding the proposed location of the bowling alley, who shall transmit to the village president the result of his
investigation. If the president is satisfied that the applicant is responsible and of good moral character and if the applicant furnishes the required frontage
consents as herein provided and the location of the proposed bowling alley does not conflict with the provisions of this or any other provisions of this code,
the president shall approve such application and a license shall thereupon be issued to the applicant by the village manager, upon payment by the
applicant of the license fee provided for herein. (1965 Code, Sec. 53.03; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-5-4: LICENSE FEES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 115/519
The fees for licenses issued herein shall be as set forth in section 3-1-6 of this title. (1965 Code, Sec. 53.04; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-5-5: LICENSE TRANSFER:
No license granted under the provisions of this chapter shall be assigned or transferred to any other person nor shall any such license authorize any
person other than the licensee named therein to do business or act under such license unless the transferee of such license shall be approved by the
village president. (1965 Code, Sec. 53.05; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-5-6: RESTRICTION ON LOCATION:
No bowling alley shall be located upon any lot or parcel of land which abuts upon or is situated within one hundred feet (100') of any private property
zoned in an A or B residence district by the zoning provisions of this code and not separated from such private property by any street or railway right of
way. (1965 Code, Sec. 53.06; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-5-7: OPERATING RULES AND REGULATIONS:
(A) No person shall keep open or operate any bowling alley between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight and nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. (1965 Code,
Sec. 53.07; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
(B) Except as provided otherwise in chapter 2 of this title, no bowling alley shall be conducted upon any premises where beer or other alcoholic liquor is
sold or consumed. (Ord. 1802, 5-16-1988; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
(C) No gambling shall be permitted upon any premises upon which a bowling alley is conducted. (1965 Code, Sec. 53.07; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
Chapter 6
BURGLAR AND HOLDUP ALARM SYSTEMS
3-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply:
ALARM SYSTEM SERVICE: Any person, firm or corporation that engages in the activity of altering, installing, maintaining, repairing, replacing, or
servicing a burglar or holdup alarm system, or which causes any of these activities to take place, and which is licensed as a private alarm contractor or
certified as a private alarm contractor agency under the provisions of the private detective and private security act of 1983.
ALARM SYSTEMS: An assembly, for transmission by either electrical or telephonic means, of equipment and devices (or a single device such as a solid
state unit which plugs directly into a 110 volt AC line) arranged to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which police are
expected to respond. An "alarm system" shall include herein the terms "burglar alarm system", "holdup alarm system", "automatic voice dialing alarm
system", "signaling alarm system", and a "direct line alarm system". Fire alarm systems and alarm systems which monitor temperature, smoke, or any
other condition not directly related to the detection of an unauthorized intrusion into a premises or an attempted robbery at a premises are specifically
excluded from the provisions of this chapter.
ALARM USER: Any person on whose premises an alarm system is maintained within the village. Excluded from this definition and from the coverage of
this chapter are persons who use alarm systems to alert or signal persons within the premises in which the alarm system is located, of an attempted
unauthorized intrusion or holdup attempt. If such a system, however, employs the transmission of a visual signal or employs an audible signal emitting
sounds or flashing light or beacon designed to signal persons outside the premises, such system shall be within the definition of alarm system and shall be
subject to this chapter.
AUTOMATIC VOICE DIALING ALARM SYSTEM: An alarm system which automatically sends over regular telephone lines, by direct connection or
otherwise, a prerecorded voice message or coded signal indicating the existence of the emergency situation that the alarm system is designed to detect,
to the police department communications center.
BURGLAR ALARM SYSTEM: Any unauthorized intrusion detection device which transmits an alarm signal, message or warning either audibly by means
of a bell, horn or other sounding device or visually or audibly from the premises where installed to some remote monitoring location by means of electrical
or telephonic lines.
DIRECT LINE ALARM SYSTEM: A special telephone line leading into the communication center of the police department and having the primary purpose
of handling emergency signals or messages, originating either directly or through a central location from automatic dialing devices, of an unauthorized
intrusion or a holdup.
FALSE ALARM: The activation of an alarm system through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation or the negligence of the user, owner or
lessee of an alarm system or of his employees or agents. Such terminology does not include alarms activated by weather related conditions, acts of God,
telephone line interruption (trouble alarm indication) or false alarms occurring during a period of thirty (30) days following installation of a new alarm
system or major alterations or additions to an existing alarm system.
HOLDUP ALARM SYSTEM: An alarm system signaling a robbery or attempted robbery, including a manually operated system in which the signal
transmission is initiated by the direct action of the person attacked or by an observer of the attack.
SIGNALING ALARM SYSTEM: An electrically operated signaling system which, when activated, automatically sends visual and/or audible signals over a
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 116/519
signal line to be registered by indicators at a monitor panel at the police department communication center. (Ord. 1513, 9-20-1982; amd. Ord. 1568, 2-20-
1984; Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-6-2: ALARM SYSTEMS INSTALLATION; PERMIT REQUIRED:
Any person owning or having possession and control of any premises in this village shall obtain a permit for installation, addition to, alteration, repair or
replacement of a burglar alarm system or a holdup alarm system to such premises in this village. No permit shall be required for repair and maintenance
service to an existing alarm system, where undertaken pursuant to a service contract by the same person which installed the alarm system. (Ord. 1568, 2-
20-1984; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-6-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Any person desiring to have a burglar or holdup alarm system installed, altered, added to, repaired or replaced within any premises owned or controlled by
them shall make written application for a permit to do so to the village manager on forms furnished by the village manager and signed by the individual
property owner, or by the partners, or by the proper corporate officials, as appropriate. Such application shall contain the name, address and telephone
number of the applicant, and the name and address of the alarm system service, and its state license or certification number, together with a description of
the kind of alarm system to be installed or worked on pursuant to the permit applied for. The application shall also contain information by the applicant
regarding the maintenance and servicing of the alarm system following its installation, including the name, address and telephone number of the alarm
system service engaged to do this work, and the pertinent state license or certification number. (Ord. 1568, 2-20-1984; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-6-4: INVESTIGATION:
Upon receipt of a permit application for the installation or work on a burglar or holdup alarm system, the village manager shall forward the same to the
chief of police who shall ascertain whether or not the alarm system service to be used for such work is a duly licensed private alarm contractor or a duly
certified private alarm contractor agency pursuant to the provisions of the private detective and private security act of 1983, and the chief of police shall
submit a written report of his findings to the village manager. (Ord. 1568, 2-20-1984; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-6-5: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT:
If the village manager receives a report from the chief of police that the alarm system service is duly licensed or certified by the state, he shall issue a
permit to the applicant to accomplish the particular burglar or holdup alarm system where specified in the application. If, however, the alarm system service
is not duly licensed or certified by the state as heretofore provided in this chapter, then the village manager shall notify the applicant and advise him of this
fact and shall withhold the issuance of such permit until such time as a duly licensed or certified alarm system service has been obtained by the applicant
to undertake the work applied for in the permit application. (Ord. 1568, 2-20-1984; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-6-6: INSTALLATION AND INSPECTION:
All such work pertaining to the installation, modification, service or repair of a burglar or alarm system in this village, as defined herein, whether audible or
silent, and the servicing thereof, shall be accomplished in accordance with the pertinent specifications of the village building and electrical codes,
requirements of federal regulations concerning security devices in national banking institutions, regulations and standards provided in this chapter and all
other existing laws and ordinances of the village where applicable.
It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the village building inspector to inspect all such work on a burglar or holdup alarm system installed, or being
installed, and maintained in a building within this village, to ensure that such work is being accomplished in a lawful manner. (Ord. 1513, 9-20-1982; amd.
Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-6-7: AUTOMATIC VOICE DIALING ALARM SYSTEMS:
(A) All automatic voice dialing alarm systems installed or to be installed on any premises in the village shall comply with the following regulations:
1. All such dialing services shall be interconnected to a special telephone line established especially for transmitting such signals directly to the police
department and shall utilize a special telephone number designated by the police department for such use.
2. The contents of the recorded message to be transmitted by such device must be intelligible and in a format approved by the chief of police as
appropriate for the type of emergency being reported.
3. Upon a single stimulus of the alarm device, an automatic dialing device may place no more than two (2) separate transmissions to the police
department via the special telephone line.
4. Messages transmitted during such calls, stating the location and nature of the alarm condition shall not exceed fifteen (15) seconds in length.
5. All such devices shall be capable of transmitting an emergency message to two (2) or more separate locations, so that upon activation any message
may be sent not only on a special telephone line but also to a location where an authorized person is available to respond to the emergency
message, and to open the premises on which the device is installed.
6. The sensory apparatus and hardware comprising such devices shall be maintained by the owner or lessee in such physical condition that false
alarms will be minimized.
(B) Upon and after the effective date of this chapter, no automatic dialing device shall be interconnected to the primary published police department
telephone line listed in the area telephone directory for use in handling emergency calls on a person to person basis.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 117/519
(C) Any automatic dialing device so interconnected to the primary published police department telephone line upon the effective date of this chapter shall
have a period ninety (90) days thereafter in which to disconnect therefrom.
(D) Use of such special telephone lines connected to the police department for automatic voice dialing alarm systems shall be made available to business,
financial institutions and residences on an annual subscription basis, as hereinafter provided. (Ord. 1513, 9-20-1982; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-6-8: DIRECT COMMUNICATION SIGNALING ALARM SYSTEMS:
(A) The chief of police is authorized to obtain bids regarding a contract for the installation of a standard communication panel to provide a uniform
monitoring system to receive visual and audible burglar or holdup signals over a signal line or lines at a central location in the police department
communication center. Such system shall be available as a burglar or holdup alarm system termination or receiving point for business premises,
financial institutions and residences recommended by the chief of police and approved by the village manager, on an annual subscription basis, as
hereinafter provided. (Ord. 1513, 9-20-1982; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
(B) Any subscribing alarm user who obtains authority from the village manager to terminate its alarm system in the police department monitoring system
may contract with any alarm system service of its choice for the installation, maintenance and/or servicing of the alarm system to be installed on its
premises, provided such alarm user has obtained a permit as required by this chapter, and the alarm system service so chosen is duly licensed or
certified by the state as herein provided in this chapter. (Ord. 1568, 2-20-1984; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
(C) The alarm user subscriber approved for a direct connection to the police department monitoring system or the alarm system service contracting for
servicing the subscriber's alarm system, shall be responsible for obtaining any leased telephone line between the alarm user's premises and the alarm
receiving equipment in the police department, if required, in order to provide an input signal which is compatible with the receiving equipment used to
operate the police department's standard annunciator panel.
(D) No alarm user subscriber shall utilize a single pair of wires to transmit a burglar or holdup alarm signal and a fire or other emergency signal. All signals
transmitted over such wires shall cause only one signal to be transmitted to the police department upon a single stimulus of the alarm device, and no
pulsating or intermittent signal shall be allowed. (Ord. 1513, 9-20-1982; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-6-9: TESTING:
No alarm system designed to transmit emergency messages directly to the police department shall be tested or demonstrated without first obtaining
permission from the chief of police. Permission is not required to test or demonstrate alarm devices not transmitting emergency messages directly to the
police department unless the messages are to be relayed to the police department. (Ord. 1513, 9-20-1982; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-6-10: INSPECTION:
(A) For the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this chapter, the chief of police or his designee shall have the authority, at a mutually agreeable time, to
enter any premises in the village in or upon which an alarm system subject to this chapter is located, to inspect the installation and/or operation of such
alarm system on official police business. (Ord. 1513, 9-20-1982; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
(B) If such inspection reveals any violations of the provisions of this chapter, a written report detailing such violations shall be promptly sent to the village
manager and to the alarm user with a copy thereof sent to the alarm system service responsible for the alarm system in violation of this chapter. Such
report shall require correction to be accomplished within thirty (30) days after receipt of the notice of the violation discovered, and shall state that a
failure to comply may result in the revocation of the alarm user's subscription permit or service permit in accordance with the provisions of this chapter
as hereinafter provided. The alarm user shall be granted a reasonable extension of time to correct such violations upon good cause shown. (Ord. 1568,
2-20-1984; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-6-11: REPAIR SERVICE:
Each alarm user in the village shall obtain a service contract from an alarm system service licensed or certified pursuant to the provisions of the private
detective and private security act of 1983, or shall have such licensed or certified service available to him on a twenty four (24) hour basis to make
inspections and/or repairs which become necessary for the proper functioning of the alarm and to minimize false alarms. (Ord. 1568, 2-20-1984; amd. Ord.
2506, 8-16-2004)
3-6-12: ALTERNATE POWER:
Each alarm user in the village shall provide an alternate source of power for his alarm system to prevent false alarms due to failure of power supplied from
the utility company. Such alternate source of power shall provide power for a minimum of thirty six (36) hours. (Ord. 1513, 9-20-1982; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-
16-2004)
3-6-13: ALARM USER, ANNUAL SUBSCRIPTION PERMIT:
(A) Annually, on or before January 1 of each year, every alarm user having an alarm system connected to the telephone lines or direct monitoring system
of the police department will obtain a subscription permit for the privilege of using such police department facilities. The annual subscription permit fee
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 118/519
shall be sixty dollars ($60.00) for each alarm system and said fee shall not be subject to proration or refund. (Ord. 2454, 6-16-2003; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-
16-2004)
(B) Every alarm user applying for the permit required in this section, shall state on a permit application form to be prepared by the police department and
approved by the village manager; his name, the address of the residence or business, or businesses in or upon which the alarm system has been or
will be installed, his telephone number, the type of alarm system, the alarm business or businesses installing, monitoring, inspecting, responding to
and/or maintaining the alarm system, and the name and telephone number of at least one person (in the case of partnership or corporate alarm user
applicant, at least 2 persons) who can be reached at any time, day or night, and who is authorized to respond to an alarm signal and who can open the
premises in which the system is installed.
(C) It shall be unlawful for any alarm user to connect to and use the special telephone lines or direct monitoring facilities of the police department for the
purpose of operating a burglar or holdup alarm system without first obtaining a subscription permit as required by this section, and it shall be further
unlawful for any alarm user to fail or refuse to disconnect such alarm system from the police department facilities in the event that his subscription
permit is suspended or revoked as hereinafter provided in this chapter. (Ord. 1513, 9-20-1982; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-6-14: FALSE ALARMS:
(A) Every alarm user shall be responsible for any false alarms transmitted by the burglar or holdup alarm system which is maintained and operated by him.
The police department shall maintain a record of all false alarms so transmitted to the police department using the facilities provided by the department
for such systems.
(B) There shall be a service charge of twenty five dollars ($25.00) assessed to the alarm user for every false alarm in excess of three (3) and less than six
(6) and a service charge of fifty dollars ($50.00) assessed to the alarm user for every false alarm in excess of five (5) transmitted by the user's alarm
system and responded to by the police department during any calendar year. Such charges shall be remitted to the village by the alarm user within ten
(10) days of receipt of the statement of such charge. For the purposes of this section false alarms activated by weather related conditions, acts of God,
telephone line interruption (trouble alarm indications) and false alarms occurring during a period of thirty (30) days following installation of a new alarm
system or major alterations or additions to an existing alarm system shall not be considered as false alarms subjecting the user to service charges or
other penalties.
(C) More than seven (7) false alarms in the first calendar year or six (6) false alarms in the second calendar year and every year thereafter from any alarm
system for which an alarm user subscription permit has been obtained may constitute grounds for revocation of such permit in the absence of any good
faith efforts on the part of the user to determine the cause of such false alarms and to correct the same.
(D) Alarm systems which have been the object of more than seven (7) false alarms during a calendar year are hereby determined to be a public nuisance
and adverse to the safety of the public and shall be subject to abatement.
Upon such occurrence the chief of police shall notify the alarm user in writing by first class mail of such fact and require that the user submit a report to
the chief of police within fifteen (15) days after receipt of such notice, describing efforts to discover and eliminate the causes of the false alarms. If,
however, the alarm user, by reason of absence from the village or on any other reasonable basis requests an extension of time to file the report, the
chief of police shall extend the fifteen (15) day period for a reasonable period. If the alarm user fails to submit such a report within fifteen (15) days or
within any such extended period the chief of police shall submit this fact together with his report of such false alarms to the president and board of
trustees which shall take action to revoke the user's permit.
(E) If the alarm user submits a report as required by subsection (D) of this section but the chief of police determines that the report is unsatisfactory or that
the alarm user has failed to show by the report that he has taken or will take reasonable steps to eliminate or reduce the false alarms, then the chief of
police shall issue a written notice by first class mail to the alarm user of his intent to recommend the revocation or suspension of the alarm user's
permit and shall forward the user's report, and his own report and recommendation to the president and board of trustees which shall take such action
as is deemed appropriate regarding the user's permit. (Ord. 1513, 9-20-1982; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-6-15: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF PERMITS:
Any permit issued to an alarm user pursuant to the provisions of this chapter may be suspended or revoked by the president and board of trustees. The
reasons for suspension or revocation of a permit may be, but are not limited to, the following:
(A) Violation of this chapter or any of its provisions in regard to the installation, maintenance and operation of an alarm system; or
(B) False or fraudulent information provided on the application for permit; or
(C) Substantial or uncorrected incidents of false alarms or failure to pay for service charges incurred in responding thereto; or
(D) Violation of any of the terms or conditions of the permit. (Ord. 1568, 2-20-1984; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-6-16: LIABILITY OF VILLAGE LIMITED:
The village shall take every reasonable precaution to assure that alarm signals and prerecorded alarm messages received by the village are given
appropriate attention and are acted upon with dispatch. Nevertheless, the village shall not be liable for any defects in the operation of automatic voice
dialing devices and signal line systems, for any failure or neglect to respond appropriately upon receipt of an alarm from such source, nor for the failure or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 119/519
neglect of any person with a permit issued pursuant to this chapter in connection with the installation and operation of equipment, the transmission of
alarm signals and prerecorded alarm messages, or the relaying of such signals and messages. In the event that the village finds it necessary to disconnect
a defective automatic voice dialing device or signaling device, the village shall incur no liability by such action. (Ord. 1513, 9-20-1982; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-
16-2004)
3-6-17: PENALTY:
The failure of any person to obtain an alarm system service permit, or to obtain an alarm user subscription permit, as required by this chapter; or to obey
any order of the president and board of trustees suspending or revoking an alarm system service permit or an alarm user subscription permit; or to correct
any other violation of the provisions of this chapter shall constitute an offense punishable, upon conviction, by the penalty as provided for by section 1-4-1
of this code. In lieu of filing a complaint in court, the proper police officer or other designated officer may employ the compromise and settlement procedure
as provided in section 1-4-6 of this code in full settlement, compromise and disposition of any claim violation of this chapter. (Ord. 2162, 9-16-1996; amd.
Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
Chapter 7
CATCH BASIN CLEANERS
3-7-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the village in the business of cleaning, collecting or transporting the contents of catch basins or sewers or
kindred refuse by wagon, cart or otherwise, or in any manner to engage in the business of scavenger without first obtaining a license to do so; provided,
that licensed plumbers or drain layers, who may clean catch basins or sewers as incident to the repair of such catch basins or sewers, shall not be
required to obtain such license. (1965 Code, Sec. 54.01; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-7-2: LICENSE FEES:
The fees for licenses issued hereunder shall be as set forth in section 3-1-6 of this code. (1965 Code, Sec. 54.02; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-7-3: PROMPT REMOVAL OF CONTENTS:
The contents taken from catch basins and sewers in cleaning and repairing same shall not be permitted to remain in any receptacle, wagon or vehicle
used to transport and remove such contents and said contents shall be disposed of at a proper place of disposal outside of the village. No such receptacle
or vehicle containing such material shall be permitted to be stored overnight in any building, barn, shed, yard or place on public or private property, and the
storing overnight of any of the materials taken from catch basins and sewers upon any premises within the limits of the village shall be deemed and is
hereby declared to be a public nuisance. (1965 Code, Sec. 54.04; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-7-4: EQUIPMENT REGULATIONS:
All substances taken from catch basins and sewers shall be conveyed to the place of disposal either in closely covered watertight iron or steel wagon
boxes or receptacles, or in closely covered iron, galvanized iron or steel cans or receptacles, and it shall be unlawful for any person to collect or remove
the materials from catch basins or sewers in wooden receptacles or to haul them in wooden boxes. Such carts, vehicles or receptacles or utensils used in
connection with such business, when not in use, shall be kept in a clean condition. (1965 Code, Sec. 54.05; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-7-5: DUTY OF CONTRACTOR OR CATCH BASIN CLEANER:
(A) It shall be the duty of every contractor, scavenger and person, his agents and employees, who has contracted or undertaken to remove any diseased
or dead animal, offal, rubbish, dirt, street sweepings, night soil or other filthy, offensive or noxious substance, or is engaged about any such removal or
in the loading or unloading of any such substance, to do the same with dispatch and in every particular manner as cleanly and free from offense and
with as little danger and prejudice to the life and health as possible.
(B) Each basin cleaned shall have the entire liquid and solid content removed to the bottom of the basin and after completion of the cleaning operation, the
basin shall be filled to the elevation of the trap with clean water. (1965 Code, Sec. 54.06; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-7-6: PENALTY:
Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to the
penalty as provided for by section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day that such violation
shall continue. In lieu of filing a complaint in court, the proper police officer or other designated officer may employ the compromise and settlement
procedure as provided in section 1-4-6 of this code in full settlement, compromise and disposition of any claimed violation of this chapter. (Ord. 2162, 9-16-
1996; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
Chapter 8
CHRISTMAS TREE MERCHANTS
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 120/519
3-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
The term "Christmas tree merchant" as used herein shall mean any person engaging, between November 10 and January 10 of the succeeding year, in
the sale at retail of Christmas trees, wreaths or accessories thereto, upon any vacant lot or parcel of land not appurtenant to or used in connection with an
adjacent building occupied and used in the carrying on of a permanent retail business. The term "Christmas tree merchant" shall not be construed to apply
to any person selling such trees, wreaths, or accessories in retail stores or on land adjacent to such stores occupied in connection therewith. (1965 Code,
Sec. 55.01; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-8-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in the business of a Christmas tree merchant except during the period between November 10 of any year and January 10 of the
succeeding year, or without first obtaining a license to engage in such business. (1965 Code, Sec. 55.02; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-8-3: LICENSE FEES:
The fees for licenses issued hereunder shall be as set forth in section 3-1-6 of this title. (1965 Code, Sec. 55.03; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-8-4: LICENSE APPLICATION:
The application for a license to conduct the business of Christmas tree merchant shall state:
(A) Name and address of the person who proposes to conduct the sale;
(B) The location of the lot upon which the sale is to be conducted (a sworn statement from the owner of the premises stating that he consents to the use of
the property for such sale);
(C) The legal description of the property to be used;
(D) The dates upon which the sale is to be conducted;
(E) Guaranty deposit provided in section 3-8-6 of this chapter. (1965 Code, Sec. 55.04; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-8-5: REGULATION OF SALES:
(A) No Christmas tree merchant shall call out or cry or use or operate any whistle, bell, horn, radio, phonograph or other sound making device for the
purpose of advertising any merchandise offered for sale or of inviting the patronage of any person. (1965 Code, Sec. 55.05; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-
2004)
(B) In the absence of a special permit, issued by the village manager, pursuant to the provisions of section 8-2-25 of this code, for the sale of Christmas
trees or greenery from a specific public street or public alley line location, no such merchandise shall be displayed or stored within ten feet (10') of any
such public street or public alley line. (Ord. 2109, 4-3-1995; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
3-8-6: DEPOSIT FOR REMOVAL:
Each Christmas tree merchant, at or before the expiration of the period for which he is licensed to carry on business, shall remove all unsold merchandise
and all refuse from the premises occupied by him under such license, so as to leave such premises in a clean and orderly condition. As a guaranty of
compliance with this section, each Christmas tree merchant, at the time of and as a condition for issuance of his license, shall deposit twenty five dollars
($25.00) with the village treasurer. If the Christmas tree merchant removes unsold merchandise and refuse and leaves the premises in a clean and orderly
condition as required by this section, the deposit shall be returned to him upon his vacation of the premises. Otherwise, the deposit shall be retained by the
village to cover the cost of removing such unsold merchandise and refuse and of cleaning up the premises. (1965 Code, Sec. 55.06; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-
16-2004)
3-8-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be subject to the penalty as provided for by section 1-4-1 of this code. In
lieu of filing a complaint in court, the proper police officer or other designated officer may employ the compromise and settlement procedure as provided in
section 1-4-6 of this code in full settlement, compromise and disposition of any claimed violation of this chapter. (Ord. 2162, 9-16-1996; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-
16-2004)
Chapter 9
CONTRACTORS
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 121/519
3-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
BITUMINOUS PAVING CONTRACTOR: Any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of constructing, laying, patching, seal coating or
repairing any bituminous driveway, walk, patio, court, floor or appurtenances in, on or about any structure or in any public street, alley or place in the
village, but the term "bituminous paving contractor" does not include employees employed by such contractor, nor contractors employed by the village.
Said business is hereby referred to as the business of construction contracting.
CONSTRUCTION AND BUILDING CONTRACTOR: All contractors engaged in the trade or occupation of building, constructing, enlarging, rehabilitating,
improving, altering, repairing, painting, moving, demolition, plastering, roofing work, fencing, or any other similar work not otherwise specified by this code
or ordinance or preempted by state law. The following persons are not construction and building contractors within the meaning of this chapter:
(A) Any person who merely furnishes materials or supplies for use at a construction site without fabricating them into, or consuming them in the
performance of, the work of a general contractor;
(B) Any licensed architect or engineer acting within the scope of his license;
(C) Any person who does construction or building contracting work on the person's own property;
(D) Any person who hires a construction or building contractor licensed under this chapter to do construction or building contracting work on the
person's own property;
(E) Any property owner, or employee or agent thereof, who does minor nonstructural repairs on the owner's property; and
