The rules and regulations set forth in this chapter shall be observed by the fire department of this village and by all citizens thereof. Enforcement and
administration of these provisions is hereby vested in the department of fire/rescue and emergency services as set out in title 2, chapter 13 of this code.
(Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-2-2: PERMIT ISSUANCE:
(A) Application And Approval: The village manager shall administer the application, examination and approval of all plans for the erection, remodeling or
revision of all buildings, structures and appurtenances, the issuance of building permits and the inspection of construction thereof.
(B) Plan Certification: No permit for construction of any building or structure, or for doing any other work for which a permit may be required and which is
subject to the regulation of the fire prevention code, shall be issued until plans for construction or other work have been submitted to and certified by
the village manager as complying with the fire prevention code. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 3011 - FEES AND CERTIFICATES OF COMPLIANCE. Go to new ordinance.
5-2-3: FIRE INSPECTION:
The fire chief shall administer the fire inspection provisions of the fire prevention code and other pertinent fire inspection duties required by the provisions
of the village code or directed by the department of fire/rescue and emergency services. He shall establish schools of instruction and train and qualify fire
inspectors in their duties. He shall appoint a person or persons to take charge of and be responsible for such training and inspection duties. (Ord. 2703, 3-
16-2009)
5-2-4: FIRE PREVENTION EDUCATION:
The department of fire/rescue and emergency services shall have the power and it shall be its duty to carry on a campaign of public education and to
prepare and publish newspaper articles and other forms of publicity to be distributed in the village, calling the attention of the public to the danger of certain
practices as conducive to causing fires in the village and by means of public demonstrations, exhibits and meetings to inform and educate the public in the
latest methods used to prevent the occurrence of fires. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 245/519
5-2-5: INTERPRETATION OF REGULATIONS:
Any interpretation of any regulations prescribed by the fire prevention code shall be determined in the first instance, by the fire chief. An appeal from his
decision may be taken to the village manager who may approve, modify or revise the ruling of the fire chief. An appeal may then be taken to the board of
trustees whose decision shall be final. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-2-6: INSPECTORS' RIGHT OF ENTRY:
The fire chief, any inspector designated by the department of fire/rescue and emergency services or any police officer of the village, upon production of
adequate identification and receipt of the consent of the owner, occupant, tenant, or authorized agent, is empowered to enter any building, structure or
premises, whether completed or in the course of construction, for the purpose of determining whether such building, structure or premises have been, or
are being constructed and maintained in accordance with the fire prevention code or other provisions of the village code. In the event the owner, occupant,
tenant, or authorized agent exercises his or her right to refuse entry, the village may exercise its right to seek issuance of an administrative search warrant
to permit such entry. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-2-7: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
The fire chief shall also make or cause to be made regular inspections with sufficient frequency to secure efficient supervision of all buildings and places
used for manufacturing or commercial purposes, or occupied or frequented by large numbers of people, and of all school buildings, public halls, churches,
institutional buildings, theaters, multiple dwellings, and all places of amusement, recreation or employment in order: a) to determine the safety of the
occupants of such buildings, structures, or places in the event of fire, panic or accident; b) to examine the working order and state of repair of all doors, fire
escapes and firefighting appliances, the condition and freedom from obstruction of exits, corridors, stairways, fire escapes and their approaches, the
disposition, arrangement and protection of stock, combustible material and rubbish, heating devices and ovens, inflammable liquids and explosives, and
the protection of hazardous machinery, appliances and apparatus; and c) to ascertain whether the fire regulations of this title are being efficiently carried
out. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-2-8: RECORDS; REPORTS:
The fire chief shall maintain complete, orderly and detailed files and records of all inspections made and at regular intervals transmit reports of such
inspections to the department of fire/rescue and emergency services and the village manager together with such other data and suggestions deemed
appropriate. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-2-9: MUTUAL AID AGREEMENTS:
(A) Mutual Aid Agreements Authorized: The fire chief of the village, with the approval of the president and board of trustees, is authorized, on behalf of the
village, to enter into, and from time to time alter and amend, a mutual aid agreement with member governmental units of the mutual aid box alarm
system (MABAS), including, but not limited to, the neighboring municipalities of Berwyn, North Riverside, Lyons, Brookfield, McCook, LaGrange and
LaGrange Park, defining and putting into effect a program of mutual aid for fire protection and other emergencies containing provisions as hereinafter
set forth in this section.
(B) Mutual Aid Program; General Provisions:
1. Authorization: The fire chief or his designee is authorized to take necessary and proper action to render and/or request mutual aid from other
MABAS member governmental units. The aid rendered shall be to the extent of available personnel and equipment not required for adequate
protection of the territorial limits of the aiding unit. The judgment of the fire chief, or his designee, of the aiding unit shall be final as to the personnel
and equipment available to render aid.
2. Notice Of Emergency: Whenever an emergency occurs and conditions are such that the fire chief, or his designee, of the stricken unit determines it
advisable to request aid pursuant to the mutual aid agreement, he shall notify the aiding unit of the nature and location of the emergency and the
type and amount of equipment and personnel and/or services requested from the aiding unit.
3. Immediate Action: The fire chief, or his designee, of the aiding unit shall take the following action immediately upon being requested for aid:
(a) Determine what equipment, personnel and/or services are requested according to the system maintained by MABAS;
(b) Determine if the requested equipment, personnel and/or services can be committed in response to the request from the stricken unit;
(c) Dispatch immediately the requested equipment, personnel and/or services, to the extent available, to the location of the emergency reported by
the stricken unit in accordance with the procedures of MABAS;
(d) Notify the stricken unit if any or all of the requested equipment, personnel and/or services cannot be provided.
4. Personnel Of Aiding Unit: Personnel dispatched to aid a stricken unit pursuant to the mutual aid agreement shall remain employees of the aiding
unit. Personnel rendering aid shall report for direction and assignment at the scene of the emergency to the fire chief or senior officer of the stricken
unit. The aiding unit shall at all times have the right to withdraw any and all personnel rendering aid upon the order of its fire chief or his designee;
provided, however, that the aiding unit withdrawing such aid shall notify the fire chief or senior officer of the stricken unit of the withdrawal of such aid
and the extent of such withdrawal.
5. Ability To Render Aid: The rendering of assistance under the terms of the mutual aid agreement shall not be mandatory if local conditions of the
aiding unit prohibit response. The aiding unit shall be responsible to immediately notify the stricken unit of the aiding unit's inability to respond;
however, failure to immediately notify the stricken unit of such inability to respond shall not constitute evidence of noncompliance with the terms of
the agreement and no liability may be assigned. Nor shall any liability, expressed or implied, be attributed to or assumed by an aiding unit or its
authorized agents or personnel for failure or refusal to render aid, or for withdrawal of aid once provided pursuant to the agreement.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 246/519
6. Costs And Expenses: Equipment, personnel and/or services provided pursuant to the mutual aid agreement shall be at no charge to the stricken
unit; however, any expenses recoverable from third parties shall be equitably distributed among responding parties, and this provision shall not
operate to bar any recovery of funds from any State or Federal agency under any existing statutes.
7. Waiver: Each member unit agrees to waive all claims against all other member units for any loss, damage, personal injury or death occurring in
consequence of the performance of the mutual aid agreement; provided, however, that such claim is not a result of gross negligence or wilful
misconduct by a member unit or its personnel.
8. Indemnity And Allocation Of Employee Benefit Costs: Each stricken unit requesting aid pursuant to the mutual aid agreement shall hold harmless,
indemnify and defend the aiding unit and its personnel from any and all claims, demands, liability, losses, suits in law or in equity which are made by
a third party, including attorney fees and costs that may arise from providing aid pursuant to the agreement; provided, however, that such claims
made by a third party are not the result of gross negligence or wilful misconduct on the part of the aiding unit. All employee benefits, wage and
disability payments, pensions, workmen's compensation claims, damage to or destruction of equipment and clothing, and medical expenses of the
aiding unit shall be the sole and exclusive responsibility of the aiding unit for its employees.
9. Insurance: Each member unit shall procure and maintain, at its sole and exclusive expense, insurance coverage or a self-insurance plan or pool,
including: comprehensive liability, personal injury, property damage, workmen's compensation, and, if applicable, emergency medical service
professional liability, with minimum limits of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) automobile and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single
limit general liability and professional liability. No member unit shall have any obligation to provide or extend insurance coverage for any of the items
enumerated herein to any other member unit or its personnel.
(C) Ambulance Mutual Aid Agreement: In addition to or as part of a mutual aid agreement with member governmental units of MABAS, the Fire Chief is
authorized to enter into (and from time to time alter and amend) an agreement for mutual aid use of the emergency ambulance vehicle in neighboring
MABAS municipalities, including, but not limited to, the municipalities of Berwyn, North Riverside, Lyons and Brookfield. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-2-10: AMBULANCE SERVICE FEES:
(A) Fees Established: User fees shall be paid for ambulance services provided by the Riverside Fire Department in accordance with the following
schedule: (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
ALS 1 and 2 resident $ 900.00
ALS 1 and 2 nonresident 1,200.00
BLS resident 750.00
BLS nonresident 900.00
Mileage (per mile or fraction thereof) 15.00
(Ord. 2973, 11-16-2017, eff. 1-1-2018)
(B) Collection Of Service Fees: All such persons who receive ambulance services as provided by this Village, who have medical insurance or government
coverage for such services, shall promptly submit a claim therefor to their insurance company or appropriate government agency and shall, in addition,
assist and cooperate fully with the Village in the collection of the said service fees from the medical insurance or government provider. In the event any
person who received ambulance services from the Village receives compensation from a third party which is allocable to the ambulance service fee,
such compensation shall be promptly forwarded by said person to the Village. Under no circumstances shall any term or provision of this section
adversely affect the rights of the Village as set forth in the Illinois Health Care Services Lien Act, 770 Illinois Compiled Statutes 23/1 et seq., as
amended, or any other similar statute. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009; amd. Ord. 2801, 11-5-2012, eff. 1-1-2013)
(C) Financial Hardship: In the event any person who received ambulance services is able to prove financial hardship, the Village Manager or designee
may have the authority to waive or reduce the above mentioned fees. (Ord. 2973, 11-16-2017, eff. 1-1-2018)
5-2-11: REIMBURSEMENT FOR SPECIALIZED RESCUE SERVICES:
(A) Definitions: For purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply:
RESPONSIBLE PARTY: Any of the following parties who have been found at fault by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration or the
Illinois Department of Labor:
1. The owner of the property on which the specialized rescue services occurred;
2. Any person involved in an activity that caused or contributed to the emergency;
3. An individual who is rescued during the emergency and his or her employer if the person was acting in furtherance of the employer's interests;
4. In cases involving the recovery of property, any person having control or custody of the property at the time of the emergency.
SPECIALIZED RESCUE SERVICE: Includes, but is not limited to, structural collapse, tactical rescue, high angle rescue, underwater rescue and
recovery, confined space rescue, below grade rescue, and trench rescue.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 247/519
(B) Reimbursement: As reimbursement for specialized rescue services provided by the Riverside Fire Department, a responsible party may be charged
any and all of the following fees, where applicable:
1. For each emergency response vehicle: One hundred twenty five dollars ($125.00) per hour.
2. For each specialized rescue service team member: Thirty five dollars ($35.00) per hour.
(C) Liability: In the event there is more than one responsible party, each responsible party shall be jointly and severally liable for any and all charges
incurred under this section.
(D) Failure To Reimburse Charges: Any person or entity that, after sixty (60) days' notice of the charge, has failed to pay the charges assessed under
subsection (B) of this section shall be deemed to have violated this section and will incur a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, plus all legal fees and other costs of enforcement and collection. Each day that a violation
continues shall constitute a separate offense.
(E) Other Charges Not Precluded: Nothing in this section shall preclude the assessment of fees or other charges pursuant to any other district ordinance,
resolution, or provision of this Code. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-2-12: RESTITUTION FOR EMERGENCY RESPONSES TO INCIDENTS INVOLVING ALCOHOL, DRUGS OR OTHER
INTOXICATING COMPOUNDS:
In addition to any other fine or penalty required by law, an individual who: a) has been convicted of a violation of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 et seq., or a similar provision pertaining to the use and/or control of alcohol, drugs, intoxicating compounds, any combination
thereof and b) proximately causes an incident resulting in an appropriate emergency response, shall reimburse the Riverside Fire Department for the costs
of that emergency response, up to the maximum permitted by law. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
Chapter 3
EXPLOSIVES
5-3-1: STORAGE PROHIBITED:
No gunpowder, gun cotton, giant powder, dynamite, nitroglycerin, fulminate of mercury or other high explosives of similar nature shall be permitted to
remain upon any landing, street, public way, railroad track, station platform, freight house, warehouse or upon or in any car or at any other place within the
village, in any quantity whether in bulk or made up or kept in package or cartridges. This provision shall not apply to paper or plastic caps containing
twenty five hundredths (0.25) grain or less of explosive compound or explosive mixture for use in toy pistols or other such devices. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-3-2: POSSESSION AND IGNITION OF FIREWORKS:
(A) Definitions: For purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply:
CONSUMER FIREWORKS DISPLAY: The detonation, ignition, or deflagration of consumer fireworks to produce a visual or audible effect.
FIREWORKS: Means and includes any explosive composition or any substance or combination of substances, or article prepared for the purpose of
producing a visible or audible effect of a temporary exhibitional nature by explosion, combustion, deflagration or detonation, and shall include, but is not
limited to, blank cartridges, toy cannons in which explosives are used, the type of balloons which require fire underneath to propel the same,
firecrackers, torpedoes, sky rockets, roman candles, bombs or other explosives of like construction and any device containing any explosive compound
for exhibitional purposes; or any tablets or other device containing any explosive substance, or containing combustible substances producing visual
effects. The term "fireworks" shall not include snake or glowworm pellets; smoke devices; sparklers; trick noisemakers known as "party poppers",
"booby traps", "snappers", "trick matches", "cigarette loads", and "auto burglar alarms"; toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns, or other devices in which paper
or plastic caps containing twenty five hundredths (0.25) grain or less of explosive compound are used, provided they are so constructed that the hand
cannot come in contact with the cap when in place for the explosion; and toy pistol paper or plastic caps which contain less than twenty five hundredths
(0.25) grain of explosive mixture; the sale and use of which shall be permitted at all times.
PYROTECHNIC DISPLAY: The detonation, ignition, or deflagration of display fireworks or flame effects to produce visual or audible effects of an
exhibitional nature before the public, invitees, or licensees, regardless of whether admission is charged, and as may be further defined in the
pyrotechnic distributor and operator licensing act, 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 227/1 et seq.
(B) Fireworks Prohibited: No person, firm, partnership, copartnership, or corporation may knowingly possess, offer for sale, expose for sale, sell at retail, or
use, ignite, explode, or otherwise discharge any fireworks within village limits; provided, however, upon application and village approval, the village may
grant permits for pyrotechnic and consumer fireworks displays. Permits for pyrotechnic and consumer fireworks displays may be granted in the
discretion of the fire chief, but a permit shall not be issued unless the requirements of section 2.1 or 2.2 of the fireworks use act, 425 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 35/0.01 et seq., as applicable, have been met.
(C) Penalty: In addition to any other penalty imposed by this code or by statute, any person, firm, partnership, copartnership, or corporation violating this
provision shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each violation
constitutes a separate offense and may be cited accordingly. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 248/519
Chapter 4
SMOKE AND HEAT DETECTION AND FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS
5-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
ANNUNCIATOR: A visual device, comprised of either a lighted panel or a constant or flashing red light which must be manually reset, indicating the
particular zone on which an automatic detection and/or alarm device is in operation, and identifying the location of each such zone.
COMBINED LOCAL SMOKE AND HEAT DETECTION AND FIRE ALARM SYSTEM: A fire alarm system using automatic detection devices or assemblies
which operate upon either an increase in temperature, the sensing of an abnormal amount of smoke or combustion products, or the sensing of a flame to
activate a buzzer, bell or other sounding alarm within the device to warn and notify the occupants within the area where installed, and to activate by direct
connection an alarm sounding within the building to warn or notify the occupants thereof of a dangerous fire condition. Such system must be installed as
hereinafter provided and must be approved as to materials and installation by the Riverside fire prevention bureau.
COMBINED SUPERVISED SMOKE AND HEAT DETECTION AND FIRE ALARM SYSTEM: A fire alarm system using automatic detection devices or
assemblies which operate upon either an increase in temperature, the sensing of an abnormal amount of smoke or combustion products, or the sensing of
a flame to activate by direct connection an alarm sounding or flashing device in the Riverside fire department communications center, and an alarm
sounding within the building to warn or notify the occupants thereof of a dangerous fire condition. Such system must be installed as hereinafter provided
and must be approved as to materials and installation by the Riverside fire prevention bureau.
LOCAL SMOKE DETECTION OR HEAT DETECTION SYSTEM: A detection system using an automatic detection device or assembly which operates on
sensing an abnormal amount of smoke or combustion products, or on sensing an increase in temperature or a flame to activate a buzzer, bell, or other
sounding alarm within said device to warn and notify the occupants within the area where installed of a dangerous condition due to fire or other causes.
Such system is not connected to the Riverside fire department communications center and does not require an annunciator or the installation of an internal
or external alarm and control panel and wiring by separate circuitry directly to the building's power supply. Such system shall be installed as hereinafter
provided and must be approved as to materials and installation by the Riverside fire prevention bureau.
ZONE: When used in connection with a fire detection or fire alarm system, means a separate area of a building being served by a distinct, combined
detection and alarm sending circuit. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-4-2: SYSTEM REQUIRED:
(A) Combined Supervised Smoke And Heat Detection And Fire Alarm System: A combined supervised smoke and heat detection and fire alarm system
shall be installed in the following buildings:
1. Nursing homes, medical clinics and healthcare centers, dental clinics and offices, orthodontic clinics and offices, oral surgery clinics and offices, and
other clinics or offices providing either inpatient or outpatient care and treatment;
2. Daycare centers and schools (both public and private) in accordance with requirements of state life safety or other state fire regulations;
3. Restaurants, delicatessens, cafes, bowling alleys, theaters, and public or private assembly buildings having a seating capacity or used for the
congregating or assembling of fifty (50) or more than fifty (50) persons;
4. Multi-family dwellings containing ten (10) or more units;
5. In buildings of use groups R-1 and R-2 where used as hotels, motels, lodging houses, dormitories, apartments and similar occupancies;
6. All buildings having multiple uses, including residential;
7. All other buildings exceeding three (3) stories in height or three thousand (3,000) square feet (278.709 m2) in area, or occupancies presenting a high
life or fire hazard as determined by the code official, such as assembly, educational, or institutional use groups.
(B) Combined Local Smoke And Heat Detection And Fire Alarm System: A combined local smoke and heat detection and fire alarm system shall be
installed in the following buildings:
1. Multi-family dwellings containing nine (9) or less units.
2. Office and commercial buildings over two (2) stories in height.
3. Rooming or lodging houses containing two (2) or more sleeping rooms.
4. Restaurants, delicatessens, cafes, bowling alleys, theaters, and public or private assembly buildings having a seating capacity or used for the
congregating or assembling of less than fifty (50) persons.
5. Mixed office residence and commercial residence buildings.
6. Churches, except for such churches which contain no kitchen or cooking facilities, and which have no persons residing therein, and which conduct
no weekday nursery or day school activities.
(C) Local Smoke And Heat Detection System: A local smoke and heat detection system shall be installed in the following buildings:
1. Multi-family dwellings containing six (6) or less units;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 249/519
2. Churches which contain no kitchen or cooking facilities, and which have no persons residing therein, and which conduct no weekday nursery or day
school activities.
(D) Approved Heat Detection System: An approved heat detection system shall be installed in attics, lofts, and spaces above false or dropped ceilings
containing two hundred fifty (250) square feet or more of surface area and located in any of the above designated buildings set forth in subsections (A)
and (B) of this section. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-4-3: INSTALLATION REQUIREMENTS:
(A) Compliance With NFPA Pamphlet 72: Except as otherwise specifically provided by this chapter, smoke and heat detection and fire alarm systems shall
be installed and maintained in accordance with current editions, as supplemented from time to time, of the National Fire Protection Association
pamphlet 72.
(B) Zones Required: Combined smoke and heat detection and fire alarm systems shall be zoned so as to designate each area served by a separate,
distinct detection and alarm sending device.
(C) Annunciator Required For Multiple Zone Systems: An annunciator shall be required on any system having more than one zone, and shall be placed in
a conspicuous location in the entrance, entrance hall, or outside of the entrance to the building in a weatherproof enclosure, as directed by the
Riverside fire prevention bureau. The annunciator shall indicate the zone from which an alarm or detection condition has originated by means of a
constant or flashing red light or a translucent rectangle which is electrically illuminated from behind when an alarm or detection signal is received from
the zone. The indication on the annunciator, once activated, shall be continuous until manually reset.
(D) Standards For Installation Equipment And Devices: All equipment and devices used in the installation of an alarm or detection system shall be tested
by and bear the label of approval of a nationally recognized standards testing laboratory acceptable to the Riverside fire prevention bureau. Such
systems shall be permanently wired to the electrical service of each building.
(E) Location And Wiring Requirements: Detection devices shall be installed on the ceiling and at least twelve inches (12") from any wall or installed on a
wall and at least six inches (6") from the ceiling. In multiple residence and mixed occupancy structures and rooming or lodging houses, one smoke
detector shall be installed on the ceiling at the top of each interior stairwell, and a heat detector shall be installed at the front and rear in all corridors
and in each storage room and in each other common area. Where a combined alarm detection system is required, such smoke and heat detectors in
the common areas shall be wired to the alarm system and in addition, in mixed occupancy structures with dwelling units above the first or grade level
floor such alarm and detection system shall be installed with a separate internal alarm sounding device so that a dangerous fire condition occurring
within the commercial area of the structure shall sound an alarm in the residential area.
(F) Sleeping Areas: In each dwelling unit of multiple residence and mixed occupancy structures and in rooming or lodging houses at least one local smoke
detector shall be installed to protect each sleeping area. Where bedrooms or rooms used for sleeping areas are separated by other use areas such as
a kitchen, dining or living room (but not including a closet or bathroom) such bedrooms or sleeping areas shall be considered as separate sleeping
areas for the purpose of this subsection. Such detectors shall be local in nature and need not be wired to the combined system in the common areas.
(G) Office And Commercial Buildings: In said office and office residential buildings the office areas shall contain a local detection system and the common
areas shall contain a combined system. The commercial areas and common areas of all commercial and commercial-residential buildings shall contain
a combined system.
(H) Fire Doors: Where fire doors are required in the corridors of any building required herein to have a combined alarm and detection system, such doors
shall be provided with a magnetic door holder or other self-closing device connected to the fire alarm system.
(I) Alarm Sounding Devices: Alarm sounding devices shall consist of approved bells, gongs, whistles, horns or buzzers, which shall be distinguished by
pitch and quality from all other sound devices; and which shall be so distributed as to be heard clearly throughout the building or designated zone.
(J) Alarm Sending Stations: At least one manual fire alarm sending (pull) station shall be located in the natural path of exit in a readily accessible location
on each floor and at all external exits within all buildings required herein to have a combined alarm and detection system, as directed by the Riverside
fire prevention bureau. The manner of operation of alarm sending stations shall be permanently attached to each station and in addition, a notice shall
be conspicuously posted on each floor and at each external exit area advising occupants to pull the alarm in case of fire. Every station shall be so
installed and equipped that it can be tested without sounding a general alarm.
(K) Annual Testing And Backup Trouble Signal: Each alarm sounding station and each combined alarm and detection system shall be tested at least once
a year. In addition, a combined system shall be provided with a trouble signal or bell, approved by the Riverside fire prevention bureau arranged to
audibly warn of a failure or defect or malfunction in the system. Such trouble signal shall be clearly marked and identified and shall be provided with a
silencing switch.
(L) Repair Of Failed Systems: Every detection and/or alarm system which fails to function properly shall be repaired and placed in good operating
condition within forty eight (48) hours.
(M) Approval Of System Plans: No work shall commence on any detection or alarm system provided for herein, including installation, alteration or
extension thereof, until complete plans and specifications for the proposed system have been first submitted to and approved by the Riverside fire
prevention bureau.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 250/519
(N) Duty On Owner: It shall be the duty of the owner of any building subject to compliance with the provisions of this section, and the beneficiaries of any
land trust holding title to such building, to comply with the provisions hereof.
(O) Notice Of Local Systems: In the event the owner of any residence or business property elects to install a local smoke detection or heat detection
system with a sounding alarm within such residence or business premises, it shall be the duty of such owner to comply with the applicable installation
requirements of this section and to further report to the Riverside fire department the existence of such system and the names, addresses and
telephone numbers of all those persons designated to deactivate the sounding alarm in the event of a malfunction or false alarm occurrence to said
system.
(P) Alarms Directly Connected To The Village Dispatch Center: Any fire alarm directly connected to the village of Riverside dispatch center shall be
required to complete an annual system test and certification and the owner/occupant shall provide such documentation to the Riverside fire department
annually. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-4-4: COMPLIANCE PERIOD; EXISTING OCCUPANCIES:
The fire detection and/or fire alarm system required by this chapter shall be installed within all applicable existing occupancies within a period of six (6)
months from the effective date of this chapter. The fire marshal or his designated representative is authorized, upon good cause shown, to extend this
compliance period. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-4-5: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to the penalty as provided for by section 1-4-1 of this code for each such offense. Every
day that a violation of the provisions of this chapter continues shall constitute a separate offense. In lieu of filing a complaint in court, the proper police
officer or other designated officer may employ the compromise and settlement procedure as provided in section 1-4-6 of this code in full settlement,
compromise and disposition of any claimed violation of this chapter. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-4-6: RAPID ENTRY SYSTEM:
All buildings that are equipped with an approved or required fire alarm system per this chapter, and/or buildings equipped with an approved automatic
sprinkler system and are interconnected to an alarm monitoring agency shall have an approved key box system.
(A) Location: The location of said key box shall be approved by the code official.
(B) Necessary Access: The key box shall contain keys to gain necessary access to the building at:
1. Locked points of ingress/egress whether on the exterior or interior of the building.
2. Locked electrical, mechanical, or storage rooms.
3. Elevator controls.
4. Alarm panels and devices.
5. Other areas as designated by the code official.
(C) Responsibility For Proper Key: It shall be the owner, tenant, or their agent's responsibility to maintain the proper key(s) in the approved box.
(D) Single Key: Where possible, a single master key shall be provided.
(E) Key Box Tamper Switch: At the request of the owner or lessee, the code official shall permit the installation of a key box tamper switch connected to
the building's alarm system. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-4-7: SPRINKLER SYSTEMS:
(A) Inspections Of Fire Sprinkler Systems: Inspections and testing of existing fire sprinkler systems and control equipment must be performed by a
licensee under the fire sprinkler contractor licensing act, 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 317/1 et seq., or an individual employed or contracted by such a
licensee. Any individual who performs inspection and testing duties under this subsection must possess proof of: 1) certification by a nationally
recognized certification organization at an appropriate level, such as NICET level II in "Inspection And Testing Of Water Based Systems" or the
equivalent, by January 1, 2009, or 2) satisfactory completion of a certified sprinkler fitter apprenticeship program approved by the U.S. department of
labor. State employees who perform inspections and testing on behalf of state institutions and who meet all other requirements of this subsection need
not be licensed under the fire sprinkler contractor licensing act or employed by a licensee under the fire sprinkler contractor licensing act in order to
perform inspection and testing duties under this section. The requirements hereof do not apply to individuals performing inspections or testing of fire
sprinkler systems on behalf of a municipality, a county, a fire protection district, or the office of the state fire marshal. This section does not apply to
cursory weekly and monthly inspections of gauges and control valves conducted in accordance with the standards of the National Fire Protection
Association. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-4-8: FALSE ALARM CHARGES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 251/519
(A) Escalating Charge: An escalating charge of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per call or response shall be made to the property owner, or automatic
fire alarm equipment owner, installed and maintained by others, which initiates a response by the village fire department, for a false alarm being given
or transmitted by these facilities to the village fire department. The first fine in a ninety (90) day period is two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), the second
fine is five hundred dollars ($500.00), the third fine and every one thereafter is seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(B) Time Period: The above named charge shall be for each false alarm transmitted and responded to in any capacity by the village fire department during
any ninety (90) day period, commencing with the third false alarm transmitted during any ninety (90) day period, whether caused by malfunctioning, or
intentionally or negligently misused or abused facilities or equipment, or inadequately maintained, and which results in a fire suppression and/or rescue
apparatus and equipment being unnecessarily called to the property in response thereto. All charges shall be paid within thirty (30) days of the mailing
or delivery of an invoice. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-4-9: FEE FOR VILLAGE MONITORING OF SUPERVISED SYSTEM:
(A) Fee: Each property owner of a building required by this chapter to have a combined supervised smoke and heat detection and fire alarm system shall
pay a monthly monitoring fee for service to the village in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per monitored building.
(B) Nonpayment Of Monitoring Fees: Failure of the property owner to pay the fees for monitoring set forth in subsection (A) of this section within thirty (30)
days after such charges are due and payable, shall be subject to a shutoff of water supply in accordance with the provisions of section 8-6-5 of this
code, citation, or such other enforcement action authorized by law. (Ord. 2750, 11-1-2010)
Chapter 5
HAZARDOUS WASTE AND MATERIALS
5-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
EMERGENCY HAZARDOUS MATERIALS RESPONSE AGENCY: The Riverside fire department and emergency rescue and medical services, hazardous
material teams and ancillary services operating under its supervision.
HAZARDOUS WASTE AND MATERIALS: Any hazardous substance or hazardous waste posing a substantial or potential threat to human life, health or
safety or to the environment, including potentially hazardous medical waste, as defined in section 3 of the Illinois environmental protection act, 415 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/1 et seq., or in Illinois pollution control board regulations established pursuant thereto; or any hazardous material determined by the
United States department of transportation to be capable of posing an unreasonable risk to health and safety and property when transported in commerce;
or any hazardous substance or mixture of substances which is toxic, corrosive, an irritant, strong sensitizer, flammable, combustible, or which generates
pressure through decomposition, heat or other means as defined in section 2 of the uniform hazardous substances act of Illinois, 430 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 35/1 et seq.; and any other substance determined to be hazardous or toxic under any other state or federal law or regulation, including, but not
limited to, explosives, compressed gases, carcinogens, radioactive materials, oxidizers and peroxides.
PERSON: Any individual, business, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, limited liability company, corporation, association, joint venture, trust,
estate, or any other legal entity or the legal representative, agent or assigns thereof.
RELEASE: Any spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying, discharging, injecting, escaping, leaching, throwing, dropping, placing, casting,
dumping, depositing, abandoning, or disposing of hazardous waste or materials on any public or private land, or public way, or into the air, or into any
water source, public water supply, well, sewer, or pipe within the boundaries of this village.
REMEDIAL ACTION: Any action consistent with a permanent remedy taken instead of or in addition to removal actions in the event of a release or
threatened release of a hazardous waste or material into the environment, to prevent or minimize the release of hazardous materials so that they do not
migrate to cause a substantial danger to present or future public health or welfare or property or the environment. The term includes, but is not limited to,
such actions at the location of the release as storage, confinement, perimeter protection using dikes, trenches or ditches, clay cover, neutralization,
cleanup of released hazardous waste or materials or contaminated materials, recycling or reuse, diversion, destruction, segregation of reactive wastes,
dredging or excavation, repair or replacement of leaking containers, collection of leachate and runoff, on site treatment or incineration, provision of
alternate water supplies, and any monitoring reasonably required to assure that such actions protect the public health and welfare and the environment.
REMOVAL: The cleanup or removal of released hazardous waste or material from the environment, actions as may be necessarily taken in the event of
the threat of release of hazardous material into the environment, action as may be necessary or appropriate to monitor, assess, and evaluate the release
or threat of release of hazardous material, the disposal of removed material, or the taking of such action as may be necessary to prevent, minimize, or
mitigate damage to the public health, or welfare, or the environment that may otherwise result from a release or threat of release of hazardous waste or
material. The term includes, but is not limited to, security fencing, provision of alternative water supplies, temporary evacuation of threatened individuals,
and any emergency assistance as may be provided under title 2, chapter 10 of this code.
RESPONSE: Any removal or remedial action by the emergency hazardous materials response agency of this village.
RESPONSIBLE PARTY: A person who owns or has custody of hazardous waste or material that is involved in a release incident within this village; or who
owns or has custody of the bulk or nonbulk packaging or container or of a transport vehicle that contains hazardous waste or material that is involved in a
release incident within this village; or who owns or has custody of any site, or building or structure thereon, or any equipment, pipe or pipeline or other
facility that is involved in a release incident within this village; or who causes or substantially contributes to the cause of a release incident in this village
requiring a response by the emergency hazardous materials response agency. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-5-2: RELEASE OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS PROHIBITED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 252/519
No person shall cause, threaten to cause, or allow the release of hazardous waste or material upon any place, public and private land, public way, water
source, water supply or otherwise into the environment within the boundaries of this village. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-5-3: UNATTENDED HAZARDOUS MATERIALS PROHIBITED:
No person shall leave, abandon, or cause to be left unattended in or upon any place within this village any tank vehicle or any drum, can, box or other
container containing hazardous waste or material, unless such person has first obtained the written approval of the village and each container is properly
labeled. (Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
5-5-4: LIABILITY FOR REMOVAL COSTS:
Any person responsible for the release of hazardous waste or material, or for allowing a tank vehicle or other container containing hazardous waste or
material to be left unattended without village approval within this village shall be liable for the costs of response by the emergency hazardous materials
response agency in cleaning up or otherwise eliminating such hazard. Costs shall include the actual labor costs of involved village personnel, including
firefighters; the administrative costs, including, but not limited to, workmen's compensation and other employee fringe benefits, and medical costs,
immediate or long term, resulting from the release incident; gasoline costs; the cost of equipment utilized at the rate of one hundred twenty five dollars
($125.00) per hour or portion thereof per vehicle; the cost of outside agencies or personnel hired to assist in removal procedures and of supplies, material
and equipment used, damaged or destroyed in responding to the release incident; disposal costs and such other costs as may be incurred in removing the
hazardous material, and in the repair or replacement of property damaged by such release incident. In addition, the responsible party shall be liable to
reimburse the Illinois emergency response reimbursement fund where the cost of supplies and materials is paid for by this fund. Liability for the costs
provided herein shall be in addition to any penalties prescribed in this chapter or other remedies provided by this code or by state and federal law. (Ord.
2703, 3-16-2009)
5-5-5: PENALTY:
Any person who violates the provisions of section 5-5-2 or 5-5-3 of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day that a violation of this chapter continues shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2703, 3-16-2009)
Title 6
POLICE REGULATIONS
Chapter 1
GENERAL OFFENSES
6-1-1: ADVERTISING MATTER:
(A) No person shall distribute, throw or place, or cause to be distributed, thrown or placed upon or along any street, sidewalk, alley or public place in the
village, advertising matter consisting of any handbill, pamphlet, circular, book or advertisement or sample of merchandise, or medical preparation for
the purpose or with the intent of advertising or making known, in general or promiscuous manner, the sale of any merchandise or any business,
occupation or profession, medical treatment, medicine, entertainment or other commercial enterprise.
(B) Except as herein provided, no person shall distribute, or cause to be distributed, except through the United States mail, any such advertising matter for
the purpose aforesaid to an occupant of any premises in the village unless such advertising matter has been previously ordered by an occupant of
such premises; provided that this section shall not apply to or be taken to prohibit the delivery of such advertising matter to the occupant of any
premises by any solicitor or other persons duly registered with the police department under provision of this code where such delivery is made in the
ordinary course of business by such solicitor or other person.
(C) No person shall place or cause to be placed, any such advertising matter for the purpose aforesaid in any area, vestibule or entry, or in front of, or
along the side of any building or upon the doorstep or porch thereof, or upon any vacant property, private land, yard, driveway or private sidewalk,
unless such advertising matter has been previously ordered by the owner or by the person in actual occupation of the premises where such advertising
matter is so placed.
(D) The distribution, throwing or placing of any such advertising matter for the purposes aforesaid in violation of the provisions of this chapter is hereby
declared to be a nuisance and may be abated as such. (1965 Code § 20.08)
6-1-2: BREAKDOWN OF BARRICADES, PUBLIC NOTICES:
No person shall wilfully break down, weaken, destroy, deface, alter or remove any bar, fence, plank, board, rail, post, wall, stone or barricade of any sort,
or public notice, traffic sign or signal or placard which shall have been erected or posted by order of the president and board of trustees, or shall direct, aid
or abet the doing of same. (1965 Code § 20.02)
6-1-3: BUSINESS PLACES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 253/519
(A) Picketing Places of Business:
1. Definitions: As used in this Section the following are defined as follows:
EMPLOYEE: A person shall be deemed to be an "employee" of the owner or proprietor of any business or place of business when, and only when:
(a) He is, at the time to which reference is made, in the employment of said owner or proprietor, or
(b) He was, until the inception of a then-existing dispute between said owner or proprietor and his employees concerning terms or conditions of
employment, in the employment of said owner or proprietor, and said employment has been terminated, at the instance of either employee or
employer, because, or as a result of, such dispute.
PLACE OF BUSINESS, OWNER OR PROPRIETOR: The words "place of business" shall be taken to include not only a place where any business
is permanently carried on, but also any property upon which business or construction or other work is being carried on temporarily by the owner or
tenant of such property or by or under the supervision of an independent contractor; and the words "owner or proprietor" as used with reference to
such business or place of business, shall be taken to include either or both such owner or tenant (of the business or property) or such independent
contractor.
UNLAWFUL PICKETING: The phrase "unlawful picketing" is defined as: The standing, sitting or walking on any street or other public place in the
Village, or the display or distribution on such street or public place of placards, signs, dodgers or handbills or any written, typewritten or printed
matter, by any person or persons not employees of the owner or proprietor of any business or place of business, or who have no dispute with said
owner or proprietor concerning terms or conditions of employment, for the purpose or with the result of:
(a) Compelling or persuading any employee of said owner or proprietor to join or refrain from joining any organization, or to quit the service of
such employer; or
(b) Compelling or persuading said owner or proprietor to employ only persons who are, or are not, members of any organization; or
(c) Compelling or persuading said owner or proprietor to discharge any person then in his employ or to employ any person not then in his
employ; or
(d) Preventing said owner or proprietor from, or hindering him in, making or receiving delivery of goods; or
(e) Interfering with said owner or proprietor in the carrying on of his business; or
(f) Dissuading any person from, or influencing any person against, patronizing the business or place of business of said owner or proprietor; or
(g) Making or publicizing any representation, oral or written, that said owner or proprietor is unfair to his employees or to any organization or
engages in any unfair labor practice or any similar representation. (1965 Code, Sec. 50.01)
2. Unlawful Picketing Prohibited: No person shall engage or procure others to engage in unlawful picketing in the Village. (1965 Code, Sec. 50.02)
(B) Amusement Business Prohibited:
1. Billiard, Pool or Pocket Billiards: No person shall operate for hire or keep or conduct for profit any billiard, pool or pocket billiard table within the
Village. (1965 Code, Sec. 52.01)
2. Public Roller Skating Rink, Ice Skating Rink or Dance Hall: No person shall carry on within the limits of the Village the business of conducting a
public roller skating rink, ice skating rink or a public dance hall, for which a fee is charged. (1965 Code, Sec. 52.02)
6-1-4: COMMON LAW MISDEMEANOR:
In addition to the offenses described in this Chapter and in other chapters of this Code, no person shall commit any offense that constitutes a
misdemeanor at common law or by the law of this State. (1965 Code, Sec. 20.16)
6-1-5: DAMAGE TO PUBLIC PROPERTY:
No person shall cut, injure, mark or otherwise damage any public street, public sidewalk, public building, sewer, water pipe, hydrant, lamppost, lamp or
other property of the Village or any walk, tree, grass, shrub or plant in any street, public way or public park. (1965 Code, Sec. 20.06)
6-1-6: DISCHARGE OF FIREARMS, WEAPONS:
No person shall fire, shoot or discharge any gun, cannon, fowling piece or firearms of any description or burn, explode or set off any squib, firecracker or
other thing containing powder or other explosive material without permission of the Board of Trustees. This provision shall not apply to toy pistols or other
devices using paper or plastic caps containing twenty five-thousandths (.025) grains or less of explosive compound, provided such pistols or devices are
so constructed that the hand cannot come into contact with the cap when in place for the explosion, nor shall this provision apply to the paper or plastic
caps containing less than twenty five-thousandths (.025) grains of explosive mixture which are used in said pistols or devices. (Ord. 1833, 12-20-88)
6-1-7: DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
(A) Persons who perform any of the following acts shall be deemed guilty of disorderly conduct and shall be punished accordingly:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 254/519
All persons who shall make, aid countenance or assist in making any improper noise, riot, disturbance, breach of the peace or diversion tending to a
breach of the peace within the limits of the Village; all persons who shall assemble, congregate or collect in bodies, crowds or gangs of three (3) or
more for unlawful purposes, or for any purpose to the annoyance or disturbance of others, within the limits of the Village; and all persons in a body of
three (3) or more, congregating, loitering, lingering, standing together or near each other on any sidewalk, street, alley or public passageway so as to
obstruct, block or impede free passage or to interfere with any business fronting upon any public sidewalk or passageway who fail to disperse and
move immediately after a request to do so made by any police officer or other public official; all persons who shall make or engage in abusive or
indecent language or gestures, cursing, swearing or other improper, loud and boisterous noise or shouting; and all persons who make or engage in
noisy, rude, insulting and indecent words or conduct toward another; all persons who shall make use of, or aid and assist in the use of any public street,
sidewalk, alley, park, public place or any other open space or area within the limits of the Village for purposes of fornication, urinating, indecent
exposure or other unlawful acts and conduct contrary to public decency and morals; all persons who are idle or dissolute and go about begging; all
persons who use or exercise any juggling or other unlawful games or plays; all persons who are found in houses of ill-fame or gaming houses; all
persons lodging in or found at any time in outhouses, sheds, barns, stables or unoccupied buildings, or lodging in the open air and not giving a good
account of themselves; all persons who shall wilfully assault another in the village, or be engaged in or aid or abet in any fight, quarrel or other
disturbance in the village; all persons who stand, loiter or stroll about in any place in the village waiting or seeking to obtain money or other valuable
things from others by trick or fraud or to aid or assist therein; all persons who shall engage in any fraudulent scheme, device or trick to obtain money or
other valuable thing in any place in the village, or who shall aid or abet or in any manner be concerned therein; all persons found loitering about any
hotel or public building or wandering about the streets by day or night without any lawful means of support or without being able to give a satisfactory
account of themselves; all persons who shall have or carry any pistol, knife, dirk, knuckles, slingshot or other dangerous weapon concealed on or about
their persons; or persons who shall be found in a state of intoxication on any street or public place in the village, or in any private house or place to the
annoyance of any citizen or person, shall be deemed guilty of disorderly conduct. (1965 Code § 20.01)
6-1-8: HANDBILLS, POSTING:
No person shall paste, post, paint, print or nail any handbill, sign poster, advertisement or notice of any kind on any curbstone, flagstone or any other
portion or part of any sidewalk, or upon any tree, lamppost, hitching post, telegraph or telephone pole, hydrant or upon any private wall, door, gate or fence
within the village (without the consent in writing of the owner of such wall, door, gate or fence). (1965 Code § 20.12)
6-1-9: LOITERING:
No person shall obstruct or encumber any depot, railroad platform, street corner or other public place in the village by loitering or lounging in or about the
same. (1965 Code § 20.05)
6-1-10: OPEN CISTERNS, WELLS:
(A) Every cistern within the limits of the village shall be kept securely covered. Every person who shall suffer or permit any cistern to remain uncovered
upon any premises owned or controlled or occupied by him in the village shall be deemed guilty of maintaining a nuisance.
(B) No well shall be created within the limits of the village after May 1, 2013.
(C) No well within the limits of the village, regardless of when created, shall be used as a source of potable water, for irrigation, or for any other purpose
after May 1, 2013. Wells existing within the village limits as of May 1, 2013, shall only be allowed to remain if securely capped and covered to prevent
use.
(D) The penalty for a violation of this section shall be not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00),
with each day a violation exists constituting a separate offense. (Ord. 2815, 4-1-2013)
6-1-11: PALMISTRY, FORTUNETELLING:
(A) No person shall hold or give any public or private meeting, gathering, circle or seance of any kind in the name of spiritualism or of any other religious
body, society, cult or denomination, and therein practice or permit to be practiced, fraud or deception of any kind.
(B) No person shall obtain money or property from another by fraudulent devices and practices in the name of, or by means of spiritual mediumship,
palmistry, card reading, astrology, character reading, phrenology, seership or like crafty science or fortunetelling of any kind.
(C) Every room, house, building, structure or premises used for the purpose of conducting any of the above mentioned activities is hereby declared to be a
public nuisance and may be abated as such. (1965 Code § 20.15)
6-1-12: AMUSEMENT DEVICES:
(A) Definitions: As used in this section, the following terms are thus defined:
COIN OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES: Any skill ball machines, target shooting machine, mechanical grab machine, foosball machine, disk
bowling machine, air hockey machine, and any other similar mechanical or electronic amusement machine or device which may be operated by the
public generally upon the insertion or deposit of a coin, slug, or other token, and which returns to the player thereof no money or property or right to
receive any money or property.
NOT FOR PROFIT: An organization which satisfies the definition under section 501(c)(3) of the internal revenue code.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 255/519
PINBALL, BAGATELLE OR PIGEONHOLE GAME: A game played with any number of balls upon a table or board having holes or cups into which
such balls may drop or become lodged, and having arches, pins or springs or any of them to control, deflect or impede the direction of the balls when
put in motion by the player and shall include any of the games commonly known as "pin games".
PLACE OF PUBLIC RESORT: Any premises wherein any service or merchandise is offered for sale to the public, or where any table or implement for
the playing of any pinball, bagatelle, pigeonhole or other coin operated amusement device is kept for profit, or any premises used as a clubhouse or
clubroom; but such term shall not include any place set aside or provided for organized recreational activities or youth recreational activities under the
ownership, control or supervision of a public municipal or not for profit organization engaged in conducting or administering such recreational activities
within the village.
SIMULATED VIDEO GAMING DEVICES: Video poker machine, video slot machine, video bingo machine, and other device which involves any game
or amusement based upon poker, blackjack, dog racing, or horseracing, craps, any card or dice game, or any similar amusement machine or device
operated by means of the insertion of a coin, token, currency or similar object.
(B) Amusement Devices Prohibited: No person, firm or organization shall keep or use in any place of public resort in the village any table or implement for
any pinball, bagatelle or pigeonhole game or for any other coin operated amusement devices, nor shall any person, firm or organization permit the
playing of any such game or amusement device in any such place of public resort.
(C) Seizure Of Devices: It shall be the duty of any police officer of this village to seize any table or implement kept or used in violation of this section, and
upon conviction of the keeper thereof, any such table or implement so seized shall be destroyed.
(D) Exception, Nonprofit Organizations: Coin operated amusement devices may be kept and used in a place set aside under the ownership, control or
supervision of a public-municipal or not for profit organization engaged in conducting or administering organized recreational activities in the village,
provided that:
1. Said devices are part of (and not the primary implements of) an organized public recreational program or activity conducted in the village.
2. No more than three (3) such devices shall be permitted, kept and used for organized recreation programs or activities in the village by any one
organization.
3. All net proceeds received from the use and operation of such devices shall be used to support the public or youth recreational programs of the
organization concerned.
(E) License Required: No public-municipal or not for profit organization engaged in conducting or administering organized public recreation activities or
programs within this village shall keep or use any coin operated device within this village without first obtaining a license therefor from the village
manager and paying a license fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per each device. Such license shall be issued on an annual basis, expiring on December 31
of each year of issuance and shall be nontransferable. No portion of the license fee shall be proratable.
(F) Simulated Video Gaming Devices Prohibited: Notwithstanding any provision herein to the contrary, it shall be unlawful for any person, firm or
corporation to locate, maintain or operate within the village any simulated video gaming device. (Ord. 2215, 3-3-1998)
6-1-13: PUBLIC GROUNDS, INJURING TREES:
No person shall cut, break, mutilate or injure any tree, shrub, plant, vine, ornamental foliage or flower growing in or upon any public park, road-border or
pleasure grounds or shall cut any grass or turf or dig up or remove any soil, clay, sand or gravel thereon or therefrom without permission from the board of
trustees to do so. (1965 Code, Sec. 20.03)
6-1-14: PUBLIC PARKS, RESTRICTIONS:
No person shall hereinafter occupy or use any part of the public parks or parkways within the village or any part of the Barrypoint Road bridge or the
Forest Avenue bridge or any other bridge within the village for fishing or picnic purposes or for snowmobiling; or to operate or drive any motorcycle, motor
bike, moped or any motor vehicle (except for police, emergency and other authorized vehicles) upon or across said parks and parkways; nor shall any
person fish or picnic or launch or retrieve any boat, canoe, raft or other water vessel from or within said parks or parkways or upon said bridges or operate
any or drive any motor propelled sled or snowmobile upon or across said parks or parkways or bridges or any part thereof, or upon or across any public
street, sidewalk, alley or highway or upon or across any portion of any navigable river or stream located within the village. (Ord. 1780, 10-19-1987)
Except as may be otherwise provided in section 2-16-3 of this code with respect to designated public playground and recreation areas, all public parks and
park areas within this village shall be closed to public use between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and six thirty o'clock (6:30) A.M. The baseball
diamond and soccer field portions of the Harrington park, Longcommon park and Indian Gardens recreation areas shall be limited to public use between
the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) noon and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. for organized team activities on Sunday. (Ord. 1780, 10-19-1987; amd. Ord. 2450, 4-
21-2003)
6-1-15: TRESPASSES:
(A) Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to commit a trespass within this municipality upon either public or private property.
(B) Specifically Enumerated Trespasses; Suppression: Without constituting any limitation upon the provisions of subsection (A) of this section, any of the
following acts by any person, firm or corporation shall be deemed included among those that constitute trespasses in violation of the provisions of said
subsection (A) of this section, and appropriate action may be taken hereunder at any time, or from time to time, to prevent or suppress any violation or
violations of this section, the aforesaid enumerated acts so included, being as follows:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 256/519
1. An entry upon the premises, or any part thereof, of another, including any public property in violation of a notice posted or exhibited at the main
entrance to said premises or at any point of approach or entry or in violation of any notice, warning or protest given orally or in writing, by any owner
or occupant thereof; or
2. The pursuit of a course of conduct or action incidental to the making or an entry upon the land of another in violation of a notice posted or exhibited
at the main entrance to said premises or at any point of approach or entry, or in violation of any notice, warning or protest given orally or in writing by
any owner or occupant thereof; or
3. A failure or refusal to depart from the premises of another in case of being requested, either orally or in writing, to leave by any owner or occupant
thereof; or
4. An entry into or upon any vehicle, made without the consent of the person having the right to the possession or control thereof, or a failure or refusal
to leave any such vehicle, after being requested to leave by the person having such right. (1974 Code)
6-1-16: WEAPONS, CARRYING OR POSSESSION:
Except as provided in subsection (C) of this section:
(A) No person shall carry or possess, or shall sell, loan or give to any other person, any blackjack, slingshot, sand club, sandbag, metal knuckles or
bludgeon.
(B) No person shall carry on or about his person:
1. A pistol, revolver, derringer or other firearm; or a high pressure air or gas pistol; or
2. A dagger, dirk, stiletto, bowie knife, commando knife; any knife, the blade of which is released by a spring mechanism, including knives known as
"switchblades"; a razor, or any other kind of knife, any blade of which is more than three inches (3") in length; or
3. Any other dangerous or deadly weapon.
(C) This section shall not apply:
1. To the following officers while engaged in the discharge of their official duties: sheriffs, coroners, constables, policemen or other duly constituted
police or peace officers, and wardens, superintendents, and keepers of prisons, penitentiaries, jails and other institutions for the detention of persons
accused or convicted of crime; or
2. To the following employees or agents while engaged in the discharge of the duties of their employment: conductors, baggagemen, messengers,
drivers, watchmen, special agents and policemen employed by railroads or express companies; or
3. To persons lawfully summoned by an officer to assist in making arrests or preserving the peace, while so engaged in assisting such officer. (1965
Code, Sec. 20.04)
6-1-17: WEEDS, GROWTH OF1:
No owner, lessee or any occupant, or any agent, servant, representative or employee of any such owner, lessee or occupant having control of any lot of
ground situated in the village shall allow or maintain on any such lot any growth of weeds to a height of over ten inches (10"). (1965 Code, Sec. 20.10)
6-1-18: MASSAGE PARLORS; PUBLIC NUISANCE:
(A) It is determined and declared by the president and board of trustees of this village to be a public nuisance and a menace to the public health, safety
and welfare for any person, firm, association or corporation to establish, operate, maintain and conduct a massage parlor within the village, or for any
person, firm, association or corporation owning or having an interest (either wholly or partially) in any real estate in this village, or managing the same,
to allow, lease or otherwise permit such premises, or any part thereof to be used for the operation, maintenance and conduct of a massage parlor.
(B) For the purposes of this section the term "massage parlor" shall be defined as any establishment, whether open to the public generally or conducted as
a private or semiprivate club, wherein members of one sex touch, rub, stroke, knead, pound, fondle, manipulate or otherwise vibrate or stimulate with
the hands or with the aid of any mechanical or electric device a portion of the body of a member of the same or opposite sex, including in particular, the
application of such acts of touching, rubbing, fondling or manipulation to the genital, anal and pubic areas of any person and to the breast area in the
case of a female for the purpose of sexual arousal and/or sexual gratification, and wherein either or both participants are nude or have such genital or
female breast areas exposed. Body touching, rubbing or other massage activities conducted in a duly licensed medical clinic or in the offices of a
licensed physician, chiropractor, osteopath or physical therapist or in the home of a patient under the immediate direction, treatment and supervision of
a licensed physician, chiropractor, osteopath or physical therapist are not included within the definition herein of a massage parlor. (Ord. 1279, 2-16-
1976)
6-1-19: PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY:
(A) Definitions: As used in this section, the following terms shall be defined as follows:
ALCOHOL: As used herein, shall have the meaning given to "alcoholic liquor" in section 1-3.05 of the Illinois liquor control act of 1934, as amended,
235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-3.05 (1994).
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 257/519
CUSTODY: As used herein, shall mean the legal ability granted to a parent to govern the activities of a minor child. In the case of parents who are
divorced or legally separated, custody shall be deemed to be exercised by a parent who has legal custody over the minor child and by a parent who
has visitation rights over the minor child at the time any act set forth in this section shall be engaged in by such minor child. Where a decree of
dissolution shall provide for joint custody of such minor child, both parents shall be deemed to have custody of such child at all times.
GUARDIAN: As used herein, shall mean a person appointed the legal guardian of a minor child in any proceedings recognized by the state of Illinois,
but shall not include a person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor child under the juvenile court act.
PARENT: As used herein, shall mean a natural or adoptive parent of a minor child, provided, however, that a natural or adoptive parent who shall have
relinquished parental status as to a particular minor child through adoption or emancipation proceedings recognized by the state of Illinois shall not be
included within the term "parent" insofar as such minor child is concerned.
(B) Conditions Precedent For Parental Responsibility:
1. Before a parent or guardian shall be held responsible for the act or acts of a minor child under subsection (D) of this section, one or more of the
following events described in subsection (B)1(a) through (B)1(d) of this Section, inclusive, shall have occurred, and the parent or guardian shall have
actual knowledge of such event or events as described in subsection (B)2 of this Section:
(a) The unemancipated child under the age of eighteen (18) years shall have been adjudicated in any court of competent jurisdiction of having
violated any ordinance, statute, or common law duty, or some combination thereof, prohibiting such child from engaging in any intentional act
resulting in injury to a person or property, or both.
(b) The unemancipated child under the age of eighteen (18) years shall have received nonjudicial sanctions or penalties from a unit of local
government or other governmental agency recognized by the State as a result of having violated any ordinance, statute, or common law duty, or
some combination thereof, prohibiting such child from engaging in any intentional act resulting in injury to a person or property, or both.
(c) The unemancipated child under the age of eighteen (18) years shall have been adjudicated in any court of competent jurisdiction of having
violated any ordinance or statute relating to the consumption, the supplying, or the procuring of alcohol. Acts included within this subsection (B)1(c)
shall include, but are not limited to: 1) consumption of alcohol; 2) possession of alcohol; 3) possession of false identification which shows such
child to be twenty one (21) years old or older; 4) driving under the influence of alcohol in violation of the Illinois Motor Vehicle Safety Code or in
violation of the laws of any other state or local government; 5) supplying alcohol to individuals under the age of twenty one (21) years; 6) assisting
or permitting the gathering of individuals, one or more of which shall be under the age of twenty one (21) years, at which gathering alcohol is
consumed or possessed by an individual under the age of twenty one (21) years.
(d) The unemancipated child under the age of eighteen (18) years shall have received nonjudicial sanctions or penalties from a unit of local
government or other governmental agency recognized by the State as a result of having violated any ordinance or statute relating to the
consumption, the supplying, or the procuring of alcohol. Acts included within this subsection (B)1(d) shall include, but are not limited to: 1)
consumption of alcohol; 2) possession of alcohol; 3) possession of false identification which shows such child to be twenty one (21) years old or
older; 4) driving under the influence of alcohol in violation of the Illinois Motor Vehicle Safety Code or in violation of the laws of any other state or
local government; 5) supplying alcohol to individuals under the age of twenty one (21) years; or 6) assisting or permitting the gathering of
individuals, one or more of which shall be under the age of twenty one (21) years, at which gathering alcohol is consumed or possessed by an
individual under the age of twenty one (21) years.
2. The parent or guardian shall have actual knowledge of any such event of which they became aware through any source or method. In the absence
of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, it shall be presumed that the parent or guardian shall have actual knowledge of any such event if
the parent or guardian is mailed by the Village notice of such event, and such mail is sent certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, or is
personally delivered to the parent or guardian by an officer of the Riverside Police Department.
(C) Parental Responsibility: If a minor child under the custody of a parent or guardian shall commit within the jurisdiction of the Village any of the following
enumerated acts after the conditions precedent for parental responsibility set forth in subsection (B) of this Section have been met, then, in the
absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, the parent or guardian having custody of such minor child be presumed to have failed or
refused to prevent such minor child from committing such act or acts by the exercise of proper parental responsibility over such minor child:
1. A child under the age of eighteen (18) years committing an intentional act resulting in injury to person or property, or both;
2. A child under the age of eighteen (18) years possessing alcohol;
3. A child under the age of eighteen (18) years consuming alcohol;
4. A child under the age of eighteen (18) years driving or having custody or control of a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol, as prohibited
by the laws of the State;
5. A child under the age of eighteen (18) years supplying alcohol to individuals under the age of twenty one (21) years;
6. A child under the age of eighteen (18) years inviting an individual or individuals under the age of twenty one (21) years into a residence for the
purpose of supplying alcohol to such individual or individuals or for the purpose of allowing such individual or individuals to consume alcohol in such
residence;
7. A child under the age of eighteen (18) years manufacturing or possessing an identification card falsely showing that such child is twenty one (21)
years old or older.
(D) Violation: It shall be a violation of this section for a parent or guardian having custody of a child to fail to properly exercise parental responsibility over
such child, as set forth herein.
(E) Penalty: Any person convicted of any violation of the provisions of this section shall be subject to the penalty provided for by section 1-4-1 of this code.
(Ord. 2193, 6-16-1997)
6-1-20: POSSESSION OF CANNABIS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 258/519
(A) Cannabis Defined: "Cannabis" includes marijuana, hashish and other substances which are identified as including any parts of the plant Cannabis
