that there is probable cause to believe that the vehicle, operated with the knowledge of the owner, was used in the commission of a violation of this
Chapter, the hearing officer shall order the continued impoundment of the vehicle as provided in this Section, unless the owner of the vehicle posts with
the Village a cash bond in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus fees for the towing and storage of the vehicle. If the hearing officer
determines that there is no such probable cause, the vehicle shall be returned without penalty or other fees.
(D) Within ten (10) days after the vehicle is seized and impounded, pursuant to this Section, the Village shall notify by certified mail, return receipt
requested, the owner of record of the date, time and location of a hearing that will be conducted, pursuant to this Section. The hearing shall be
conducted no later than forty five (45) days after the vehicle was seized. All interested persons shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be heard at
the hearing. If, after the hearing, the hearing officer determines by a preponderance of the evidence that the vehicle, operated with the knowledge of
the owner, was used in commission of a violation of this Section, the hearing officer shall enter an order requiring the vehicle to continue to be
impounded until the owner pays a penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus fees for the towing and storage of the vehicle. The penalty and fees
shall be a debt due and owing the Village. However, if a cash bond has been posted, the bond shall be applied to the penalty. If the hearing officer
determines that the vehicle was not knowingly used in such violation, the hearing officer shall order the return of the vehicle or cash bond.
(E) Any motor vehicle that is not reclaimed within thirty (30) days after the expiration of the time during which the owner of record may seek administrative
review of the Village's action under this Section, or the time at which a final judgment is rendered in favor of the Village, may be disposed of as an
unclaimed vehicle as provided by law. As used in this Section, the "owner of record" of a vehicle means the record title holder. (Ord. 2194, 6-16-1997)
6-4-4: PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY:
It shall be unlawful for any person having the legal care and custody of a child under the age of seventeen (17) years to allow or permit said child to go or
to be in any public place, street, or alley in the Village in violation of the provisions of this Chapter, except in the case of necessity. (Ord. 2194, 6-16-1997)
6-4-5: PENALTY AND ENFORCEMENT:
(A) Any person violating any provision of this Chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
For any subsequent violation of this Chapter, the fine shall be not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00). If a minor shall fail to pay a fine lawfully imposed on him or her and any costs related thereto, the parents or legal guardians of the minor
shall be jointly and severally liable for said fines and costs.
(B) Every member of the Police Department while on duty is hereby authorized to escort any minor child under the age of seventeen (17) years found
upon the streets, alleys or public ways of the Village during the prohibitive hours to the Village Hall and thereupon contact the parents or legal
guardians of said child and request said parents or legal guardians to come to the Village Hall and escort said minor child to his home. (Ord. 2194, 6-
16-1997)
Chapter 5
PARADES
6-5-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No parade or procession shall be allowed on any street, sidewalk, parkway or other public way within the village, and no open air meeting shall be held in
any street, parkway, park or public lot or premises or other public area within the village, until a permit in writing therefor shall first be obtained from the
village manager. (1965 Code, Sec. 26.01A)
6-5-2: APPLICATION:
Any person, group or organization desiring to conduct such parade or procession or open air meeting shall make written application to the village manager
at least thirty (30) days in advance of such event, and shall include in said application the names and addresses of the person, persons, groups,
organization or organizations in charge or control of such parade, procession or open air meeting, or responsible therefor; the number of persons and the
names of all groups or organizations participating in such parade, procession or meeting; the number and kind of motor vehicles and animals taking part in
such parade or procession; the desired route along which such parade or procession is to proceed, or the place where such meeting is to be held; the
desired time of starting and the duration of such parade, procession or meeting; and the purpose of such parade, procession or meeting; together with any
additional information as may be required by the village manager. (1965 Code, Sec. 26.02A)
6-5-3: INVESTIGATION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 272/519
Upon receipt of an application for a permit to conduct a parade, procession or open air meeting, the village manager or his designee shall make an
investigation of the proposal with reference to community benefit, welfare, safety and traffic control; and when necessary, he shall investigate the applicant
or applicants and the persons or organizations mentioned in the proposed application and the truth of the statements set forth therein. (1965 Code, Sec.
26.03A)
6-5-4: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT:
If the village manager shall find that such parade, procession or open air meeting will not be for any unlawful purpose; and will not in any manner tend to
cause a breach of the peace; and will not unnecessarily interfere with public use, safety and the free flow of traffic on the streets and public ways of the
village; or unnecessarily interfere with the peace and quiet and welfare of the inhabitants thereof, which permit shall apply solely to the conducting of that
single parade, procession or open air meeting proposed in the application. (1965 Code, Sec. 26.04A)
Chapter 6
BLACKOUTS AND AIR RAID PROTECTION
6-6-1: AUTHORITY FOR AIR RAID PROTECTION MEASURES:
In order to protect life and property in the village from enemy action the village president is authorized and directed to carry out blackouts and air raid
protection measures in the village at such times and for such periods as are ordered by the military and naval forces and the village president is authorized
and directed to prescribe such orders, rules and regulations as may be necessary to ensure the success of the blackouts and air raid protection measures
and to protect life and property during such periods. (1965 Code, Sec. 42.01)
6-6-2: SPECIAL POLICE; APPOINTMENT:
(Rep. by Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
6-6-3: SIREN; UNAUTHORIZED OPERATION OF:
Any unauthorized person who shall operate a siren or other device so as to simulate a blackout signal or air raid, or the termination of a blackout or air
raid, shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter. (1965 Code, Sec. 42.03)
6-6-4: LIABILITY FOR DAMAGE:
This chapter is an exercise by the village of its governmental functions for the protection of the public peace, health and safety and neither the village nor
any individual subject to or engaged in the enforcement of regulations lawfully included herein, or promulgated pursuant to authority herein conferred shall
be liable for any damage sustained to person or property during, or as the result of, an authorized blackout or air raid protection measure. (1965 Code,
Sec. 42.04)
6-6-5: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
When deemed necessary in order to protect life or property during a blackout or air raid, the police are authorized and directed to enter upon any premises
within the village and extinguish lights or take other necessary action to make effective any order, rule or regulation promulgated under the authority
conferred by this chapter. (1965 Code, Sec. 42.05; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
6-6-6: PROCLAMATION FOR PRACTICE BLACKOUTS:
The village president may by proclamation establish and declare practice blackouts whenever in his opinion the same may be necessary for the
preparation of the citizens for emergencies. During said practice blackouts, all the rules set forth in this chapter applicable to blackouts shall be applicable
and in force. (1965 Code, Sec. 42.06)
6-6-7: INCONSISTENT ORDINANCES SUPERSEDED:
At all times when the orders, rules and regulations made and promulgated pursuant to this chapter shall be in effect, they shall supersede all existing
provisions, orders, rules and regulations insofar as the latter may be inconsistent therewith. (1965 Code, Sec. 42.09)
Title 7
HEALTH AND SANITATION
Chapter 1
HEALTH REGULATIONS
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 273/519
7-1-1: REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
The rules and regulations for the control of communicable diseases of the department of public health of the state of Illinois, 77 Illinois administrative code
690, ("rules and regulations") currently in force, and all subsequent revisions thereof, except as the same may be modified by the village, are hereby
adopted and made a part of this chapter and shall be enforced as such, of which rules and regulations not fewer than three (3) copies have been and now
are filed in the office of the village clerk, and from the effective date hereof the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the limits of the village and shall
be known as the "IDPH communicable diseases rules and regulations". (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-2: HEALTH OFFICER:
(A) Subject to the overall direction of the village manager, the chief building inspector and the health officer of the village ("health officer") shall enforce all
health and sanitation ordinances and regulations of this village and of the state and county, to the extent authorized, and shall make recommendations
from time to time for the improvement of health conditions. Whenever in this chapter and in any other chapter of this title, the term "health officer" is
used, said term shall also mean and include the chief building inspector.
(B) The health officer shall have the authority to take the following actions and such other actions assigned by the village manager as may be necessary to
carry out the provisions of this title:
1. Enforce all rules, regulations and ordinances of the village relating to the public health;
2. Enforce any special requirements applying to food service, food sanitation, food processing and retail food establishments;
3. Investigate or cause to be investigated complaints of or the existence of any communicable, contagious or preventable disease within the village and
report the same to the Cook County department of public health and to the Illinois department of public health and, at the direction of the village
manager, implement such measures for controlling the progress of the same as either or both of such government agencies shall authorize;
4. Make all necessary sanitary and health investigations and inspections and take measures to abate or cause abatement of all nuisances affecting the
health of the public with all reasonable promptness;
5. Administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter as they relate to the ventilating, heating, lighting and sanitation of all buildings;
6. Administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter as they pertain to the preservation of the health of those in attendance at the public and private
schools in the village, and make regular inspections of all school buildings and premises, all with regard to their food service and sanitation
conditions as such are a menace to the health of those in attendance and whereby their safety from disease is threatened. Reports of violations or
conditions deemed to present a threat to health and safety shall be submitted to the state board of education or to those having charge or control of
such schools with a recommendation for such alterations or changes as may be necessary to remove such conditions and to take lawful steps to
cause any such school to be closed to attendance until any condition therein found dangerous to life or health is remedied;
7. Furnish to the village manager and other departments such information as they may require with a view to the preservation of the public health; and
8. Require reports from physicians and hospitals regarding patients suffering from infectious or contagious diseases. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-2-1: AGENTS; RIGHTS OF ENTRY; ARRESTS:
For the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this chapter in connection with health and sanitation, the health officer shall, in accordance with applicable
law, be permitted to enter at any reasonable hour, any commercial or other premises licensed by the village, and shall have the authority to issue citations
and report to the appropriate authorities and recommend arrest of any person who shall violate any of the health or sanitation provisions of this chapter,
and shall, upon receipt of credible complaints or evidence of violations on residential premises, have authority to seek an administrative search warrant or
other court order authorizing entry to such premises. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-3: REVOCATION AND SUSPENSION OF LICENSES:
(A) Temporary Suspension: Based upon information provided by the health officer, and subject to the provisions of any applicable law, state statute or
administrative regulation, the village manager shall have authority to suspend immediately any license for not to exceed ten (10) days for violations of
the provisions of this chapter pertaining to health and sanitation when, in the health officer's or village manager's determination, a health or safety
hazard presenting an imminent danger to the public has been created by the owner, tenant or person in control of the premises.
(B) Revocation: The board of trustees may, for reasons and in accordance with the limitations set forth in subsection (A) of this section, revoke or suspend
any license in order to protect the public health, safety and welfare. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-4: QUARANTINE REGULATIONS:
(A) Quarantine Procedures: The village hereby declares the presence of any contagious or communicable disease or epidemic as defined in the IDPH
communicable diseases rules and regulations to be a nuisance due to the potential impact upon the public health. Except when otherwise directed by
the board of trustees or the village manager, it shall be the duty of the health officer to determine if a disease is contagious, communicable or epidemic
and to establish such quarantine procedures as necessary and as are authorized by county or state authorities, provided that in the event of an
emergency where it is determined that the public health and welfare are at risk, the board of trustees or the village manager may take all reasonable
steps to contain the disease or other health threat.
(B) Nuisance Abatement: The village's building department, or agents or employees of said department and the police officers of the village, shall have
power to cause any house or premises to be cleaned, disinfected or closed to visitors, and to prevent persons from residing therein, while any person
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 274/519
therein is afflicted with a communicable or contagious disease. Such persons may, by an order in writing, direct any nuisance to be abated or
unwholesome matter or substance, dirt or filth to be removed from any house or premises, and may prescribe the time and mode of doing so, and take
any other measures they may deem necessary and proper to prevent an epidemic or the spread of a communicable, contagious disease.
(C) Posting Quarantine Notice: The health officer shall cause a notice or notices, printed in large letters, to be conspicuously placed upon or near the
entrance or entrances of any building in which any person may be afflicted with a contagious, communicable or epidemic disease, as such disease or
diseases may be specified by the Illinois department of public health or Cook County department of public health. The name of such disease shall be
printed on the notice.
If any person shall be found guilty of defacing, altering, mutilating, destroying or tearing down such notice, without permission, such person shall be
deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, in accordance with requirements set forth in section 1-2-1.1 of the Illinois municipal code, ("IMC"), 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/1-2-1.1, and subject to the general penalty provisions of section 1-4-1 of this code. In prosecuting such offense, the village may
seek a penalty that includes incarceration of up to six (6) months as allowed by section 1-2-1.1 of the IMC. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-5: OBSTRUCTING SEWERS AND PUBLIC RIGHTS OF WAY:
No contaminant, garbage, liquid, food matter, byproduct from any manufacturing establishment, contents of any cistern, privy, catch basin or similar waste
receptacle, or obstruction of any kind whatsoever, shall be placed, thrown or deposited in any receiving basin or sewer or on any public right of way.
Any person so causing any such obstruction or substance to be placed in any public right of way or placed so as to be carried into such basin or sewer,
and any person damaging, breaking or removing any portion of any receiving basin, covering flag, manhole, vent or any part of any sewer or drain, shall
be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, in accordance with section 1-2-1.1 of the Illinois municipal code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2-1.1, and subject
to the general penalty provisions of section 1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-6: DISEASED ANIMALS:
(A) Removal: Every person having within his possession or control or upon any premises occupied or owned by him any dead animal or any diseased
animal past recovery and likely to become noxious and detrimental to health, shall at once remove or cause the removal of such animal to some proper
place and, when such place is designated by the health officer, to the place so designated.
(B) Diseased Or Sickly Animals: No diseased or sickly horse, cattle, swine, sheep, dog, cat or other animal, nor any animal which has been exposed to
any disease that is contagious among such animals, shall be brought into or kept in the village, except that the owners of diseased or sickly dogs, cats,
birds and other domesticated animals kept as household pets shall take measures to assure appropriate veterinary treatment for those animals and
shall report the presence of such animals and pets with a contagious illness or disease to a local or state animal control agency.
(C) Disposal Of Dead Animals: No person shall throw into a place or leave in any street or public place or public water or public water source, or
offensively expose anywhere within the village, the body, or part thereof, of any dead or fatally sick or injured animal, nor shall any person keep any
dead animal, or any offensive meat, bird, fowl or fish, in a place where the same may be dangerous to the life or detrimental to the health or safety of
any person or the public. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-7: CONVEYING REFUSE:
No person, unless licensed for garbage hauling by the village, shall drive through the public streets, ways or alleys of the village any vehicle which
contains refuse, garbage, or any other substance which emits a foul or disagreeable smell or odor, to the annoyance and discomfort of any of the residents
of the village or the public. Violation of this section shall, without prejudice to the penalty hereinafter provided, also constitute a nuisance, which may be
abated as such, and the vehicle and the contents thereof be removed beyond the corporate limits of the village by any police officer, or any member of the
village's building department. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-8: EXPOSURE OF MATTER IMPERILING HEALTH:
No person shall take, carry, expose or place in or upon any street or public place any substance, animal or thing which shall imperil the health of any
person. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-9: MATTERS DETRIMENTAL TO HEALTH:
(A) Prohibitions Generally: No building, vehicle, structure, receptacle or thing used or to be used for any purpose whatever, shall be made, kept,
maintained or operated in the village, if the use, keeping, maintaining or operating of such building, vehicle, structure, receptacle or thing shall, in the
determination of the health officer or village manager be dangerous to the life or detrimental to the health or safety of any person or the public.
(B) Prohibitions Relating To Business And Labor: No substance, matter or thing of any kind whatever which shall, in the determination of the health officer
or village manager, be dangerous to the life or detrimental to the health or safety of any person or the public shall be used in connection with any
permitted business, or allowed to exist in connection therewith, or be used in any work or labor carried on in the village, and no nuisance shall be
permitted to exist in connection with any business or in connection with any such work or labor. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-10: STORM WATER DRAINAGE INTO SANITARY SEWERS:
The discharge of storm water into sanitary sewers is prohibited as provided herein. No roof drain, downspouts or foundation discharge drains shall
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 275/519
hereafter be connected to the sanitary sewer system anywhere in the village, nor shall any connection hereafter be made to the sanitary sewer system of
the Village so as to permit the flow of storm waters into any sanitary sewer in the Village. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-11: NOXIOUS PLANTS:
No owner, lessee or other person in control of any parcel of land within the village shall permit or maintain thereon any growth of poison ivy, common
ragweed, or giant ragweed whereby the health or safety of the public or of any person lawfully upon or passing by said land may be endangered. Any such
plant existing in violation of this section shall constitute a nuisance. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-12: UNSANITARY BUILDINGS:
No person shall build, maintain or suffer or permit any building or part thereof to be or remain in an unsanitary condition by reason of the basement or
cellar being damp or wet, or by reason of the floor of such basement or cellar being covered with stagnant water, or by reason of the presence of sewer
gas. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-13: CONSTRUCTION AND LANDSCAPING ACTIVITIES; TIME LIMITS:
(A) Except as otherwise provided in this Code, no person or commercial or business entity shall use construction tools or power equipment, or engage in
any building or construction activities requiring the use of any equipment that creates a loud and disturbing noise, or use gasoline-powered landscape
maintenance equipment, including, without limitation, leaf blowers, lawn mowers, chain saws, trimmers, edgers, mechanical tree or brush grinding
equipment, or other mechanical landscape maintenance devices except between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) P.M.
Monday through Friday, eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. on Saturday, and nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. to eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. on
Sunday. Notwithstanding the foregoing, no commercial or business entity shall use construction tools or power equipment, or engage in any building or
construction activities requiring the use of any equipment that creates a loud and disturbing noise, or use gasoline-powered landscape maintenance
equipment at any time on Sunday.
(B) No commercial or business entity shall engage in any building, construction, repair, restoration or landscaping activities on the following Federal
holidays: New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day.
(C) The restrictions of this section shall not be applicable to situations requiring emergency repairs related to health or safety of persons or property. Once
the emergency has been remedied, the property owner shall comply with this section. (Ord. 2957, 7-6-2017)
7-1-14: OFFENSIVE ODORS:
No person shall so negligently conduct any business or use any premises as to create such an offensive odor as may taint the air and render it
unwholesome or disagreeable and therefore a nuisance to the neighborhood. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-15: OFFENSIVE RECEPTACLES:
The contents of any tub, or of any receptacle, cesspool, privy, vault, catch basin, sink or water closet, cistern or anything in any room, excavation, vat,
building or premises or place shall not be allowed to become a nuisance or offensive so as to be dangerous to the life or detrimental to the health and
safety of any person or the public. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-16: CONTAMINATING WATER SUPPLIES:
No person shall corrupt or render unwholesome or impure the water of any drinking fountain, spring, river, stream or pond. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-17: OBSTRUCTING WATERCOURSES OR DRAINAGE:
No person shall obstruct any watercourse, river, ravine or gutter so as to cause water to stagnate therein, or to permit foul or stagnant water to stand upon
any premises or to block, impede or obstruct the natural drainage to a sewer inlet or of water upon a public street, ditch, gutter or other public drainage
course. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-18: NO SMOKING IN DESIGNATED PUBLIC BUILDINGS1:
Smoking shall be prohibited in all designated public buildings or portions thereof owned or under the jurisdiction of the Village, except for the dispatch area
in the Police Department Offices. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)
7-1-19: PENALTY:
Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists any of the provisions of this chapter or any lawful rule,
regulation or order of the Health Officer or Village Manager, or any police officer, made pursuant thereto, shall be subject to penalty as provided for by
section 1-4-1 of this Code, except where other or additional penalties are specified elsewhere in this Code. (Ord. 2437, 1-21-2003)

Chapter 2
GARBAGE; REFUSE
7-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of constructing and applying this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings herein ascribed to them:
BULK ITEMS: Any discarded item which is not able to be adequately reduced to fit in a village approved rubbish container, including furniture, fixtures, and
small amounts of construction or demolition debris, but not including white goods.
COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Shall mean and refer to any property containing a school, church or business located within the village.
COMPANY: A waste collection contractor licensed by the village to remove construction debris.
CONTRACTOR: Shall mean and refer to the waste collection contractor with whom the village has contracted for exclusive waste collection services.
GARBAGE: All rejected or waste household food, offal, swill and carrion.
HAZARDOUS WASTE: Shall mean and refer to a waste or combination of wastes which, because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical, or
infectious characteristics, may cause, or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious, irreversible or incapacitating reversible
illness; or pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, or disposed of,
or otherwise managed or which has been identified, by characteristics or listing, as being hazardous or having such impacts pursuant to section 3001 of
the resource conservation and recovery act of 1976 (PL 94-580), pursuant to pollution control board, federal regulations or other applicable laws,
ordinances or regulations.
LANDSCAPE WASTE: All accumulations of grass, or shrubbery cuttings, leaves, tree limbs and other materials accumulated as the result of the care of
lawns, shrubbery, vines and trees.
MULTI-FAMILY PROPERTY: Shall mean and refer to only multi-family residential structures including three (3) or more residential dwelling units and which
are located within the corporate limits of the village.
RECYCLABLE MATERIAL: Shall mean and refer to those materials which are to be collected for recycling or reuse and which are generated by residential
units, multi-family properties and commercial properties, including newsprint, mixed paper, wet strength cardboard, corrugated cardboard and chipboard,
glass, plastics, aluminum, all types of metal food and beverage cans, empty paint cans, and empty aerosol cans.
RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY: Shall mean and refer to only single-family residential structures and any multiple-family structure of up to, and including, two
(2) residential units and which is located within the corporate limits of the village.
RESIDENTIAL UNIT: Shall mean and refer to only single-family residential dwelling units and any residential dwelling unit located in a multiple-family
structure of up to and including two (2) residential units and which is located within the corporate limits of the village.
RUBBISH: Shall mean and refer to nonhazardous waste, including garbage, trash, and other similar waste generated by residential units, multi-family
properties or commercial properties. Rubbish shall not include hazardous waste, recyclable materials, bulk items, white goods and landscape waste.
VILLAGE: Shall mean and refer to the village of Riverside, an Illinois municipal corporation.
WHITE GOODS: Shall include all ranges, refrigerators, water heaters, freezers, air conditioners, humidifiers, other similar domestic and commercial large
appliances and other items required by law to be treated or processed prior to disposal which are discarded by a residential unit, multi-family unit or a
multi-family property. (Ord. 2393, 1-21-2002)
7-2-2: RECEPTACLES:
(A) All rubbish shall be placed into receptacles that are designed for such purpose, are waterproof, are constructed of durable metal or heavy plastic
material, have a tight fitting cover, have handles suitable for lifting by one worker, and contain thirty (30) gallons' or less capacity. Alternatively, rubbish
may be placed into contractor provided wheeled carts. Said receptacles shall be placed on the ground to the rear of or within twenty five feet (25') of
the rear of the building and at all times kept covered with tight metal or plastic lids. No landscape waste shall be deposited in receptacles used for
rubbish.
(B) All heavy items of junk or trash including machinery, furniture and heavy appliances shall be placed at the curb.
(C) Items for collection shall be placed at the curb no sooner than four o'clock (4:00) P.M. of the day preceding a scheduled collection day. Prior to this
time, it shall be kept out of plain view from the street.
(D) No person shall leave any receptacle, container or other waste related materials on the parkway or at the curb of any premises after seven o'clock
(7:00) P.M. on the day that a scheduled collection has been accomplished. (Ord. 2393, 1-21-2002)
7-2-3: COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL:
(A) Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, all rubbish, landscape waste, bulk items, white goods, and other waste, including heavy trash and junk
items, shall be collected and disposed of by the contractor, and no owner or occupant of any premises shall employ or permit any person or firm except
the contractor to remove any such items from such premises, nor shall any person dispose of, or cause to be disposed of, any items in any other
manner.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 277/519
(B) All rubbish collected from residential units shall be placed into an acceptable container of standard waterproof construction consisting of durable metal
or plastic material, with a tight fitting cover and with handles suitable for lifting by one worker. Residential units will be limited to two (2) 30-gallon
containers of rubbish per collection. Each resident shall be responsible for either furnishing and utilizing village approved waste containers or reaching
agreement with the contractor regarding contractor provided wheeled carts. The contractor will not be responsible for collecting loose materials unless
a special pick up is ordered. Each residential unit may place one bulk item or white goods per week for collection as part of regular service, without
additional cost.
(C) A junked automobile, truck, tractor or other motor vehicle shall be disposed of in accordance with state laws and requirements pertaining to the junking
of such vehicle.
(D) No person shall allow rubbish or other waste to accumulate on any premises or to be stored or kept thereon in such manner as may constitute a
nuisance or be a menace to public health or comfort, or except as provided or permitted herein. For the purpose of this provision, it shall constitute a
nuisance for any person to deposit or otherwise allow any garbage or other food or edible products to remain in the open on his property for the
purpose of feeding or attracting any stray cat or dog not owned by said person or any other domestic animal or rodent or other wild animal at or upon
his property.
(E) The following days shall be considered holidays for purposes of this chapter:
New Year's Day
Memorial Day
Independence Day
Labor Day
Thanksgiving Day
Christmas Day
Should one of these holidays fall on a regularly scheduled collection day, collection shall be one day late after the holiday for the remainder of that
week. The contractor shall inform the residents of each change in schedule due to holidays through local media. No other change in the weekly
schedule shall be allowed without prior written consent of the village. (Ord. 2393, 1-21-2002)
7-2-4: LANDSCAPE WASTE AND COLLECTION:
(A) The landscape waste collection season shall be from April 1 to November 30 of each year.
(B) The contractor shall provide once per week unlimited landscape waste collection to each residential property and multi-family property. Unlimited
landscape waste collection shall include collection of unlimited quantities of bagged leaves during the fall leaf season. Landscape waste collection
services are not provided to commercial properties under the village's contract with the contractor.
(C) Landscape waste shall be placed at the curb in front of the property, except that on property devoted to commercial purposes, such waste materials
shall be placed in the rear of the premises near the rubbish receptacles. Materials shall be neatly stacked, bundled and so arranged as to prevent the
same from being scattered by the wind, and shall be placed at the curb no sooner than four o'clock (4:00) P.M. of the day preceding a scheduled
collection day. Prior to this time, all landscape waste shall be kept out of plain view from the street.
(D) Landscape waste must be segregated from other materials and packaged as follows:
1. That contained within village approved thirty (30) gallon or smaller containers, kraft paper bags or in bundles;
2. That contained in rigid containers of no more than thirty (30) gallons' capacity and that are clearly marked with a "Landscape Waste only" sticker to
be provided by the contractor; and
3. That contained within bundles of brush:
(a) Not exceeding sixty (60) pounds in weight;
(b) Not exceeding four feet (4') in diameter;
(c) Containing individual branch lengths not exceeding four feet (4'); and
(d) Individual branch diameters not exceeding three inches (3").
Any landscape waste placed for collection not meeting the requirements herein shall not be collected.
(E) Christmas trees left at the designated collection point during the Christmas season, ending two (2) weeks after New Year's Day of each year, shall be
collected at no additional cost.
(F) Dead leaves and other plant materials may be accumulated upon the premises for mulching, or other gardening purposes. (Ord. 2393, 1-21-2002)
7-2-5: RECYCLABLE MATERIALS COLLECTION:
Recyclable materials, including newsprint, mixed paper, wet strength cardboard, corrugated cardboard and chipboard, glass, plastics, aluminum, all types
of metal food and beverage cans, empty paint cans, and empty aerosol cans shall be collected by the contractor. Appropriate receptacles for such
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 278/519
materials will be provided at no cost to residential customers. These receptacles will remain village property. Commercial customers may participate in the
recycling programs established by the village and the contractor. (Ord. 2393, 1-21-2002)
7-2-6: SPECIAL PICK UP SERVICE:
(A) Special pick up service shall be provided to any residential units, multi-family property or commercial property for any type of material collected under
this chapter in excess of one cubic yard.
(B) Residential units, multi-family properties or commercial properties shall notify the contractor to provide special pick up service for any of the wastes or
other materials collected under this chapter. The contractor shall promptly provide the residential unit, multi-family property or commercial property with
a price estimate for the requested special pick up service. Thereafter, the residential unit, multi-family property or commercial property shall authorize
the contractor to provide the special pick up service. (Ord. 2393, 1-21-2002)
7-2-7: PICK UP OF IMPROPERLY PREPARED WASTE UPON EVICTION:
In order to protect the public health, safety and welfare and at the request of the village, the contractor shall collect quantities of rubbish, recyclable
material, landscape waste, bulk items, and white goods left at the street curb or alley without proper preparation in unusual circumstances (e.g., evictions
or "skip-outs") and shall bill the property owner for the actual cost thereof. (Ord. 2393, 1-21-2002)
7-2-8: NONCOLLECTION OF HAZARDOUS WASTE:
The contractor shall not collect or transport any hazardous waste or any other waste or material which the designated transfer station and/or disposal or
other facility receiving such waste is not permitted to receive. (Ord. 2393, 1-21-2002)
7-2-9: RATES FOR COLLECTION:
(A) Rates: The rates for collection of rubbish, landscape waste, and other types of waste shall be as established by resolution.
(B) Nonpayment Of Rubbish And Refuse Collection Charges: Failure of the owner or occupant of any premises to pay the charges for rubbish and refuse
collection thereto within thirty (30) days after such charges are due and payable, shall be subject to a shutoff of water supply in accordance with the
provisions of section 8-6-5 of this code. (Ord. 2393, 1-21-2002)
7-2-10: NUISANCE:
The storage or accumulation of rubbish and other types of waste, including heavy junk or trash materials, upon the open area of any lot or parcel of land in
this village for a period of eight (8) days or more, and the deposit or accumulation of garbage, including any food or other edible products for the purpose
of feeding or attracting stray or wild animals, upon the open area of any such premises for a period exceeding twenty four (24) hours constitutes a menace
to public health and comfort and is offensive to the public welfare and is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and shall be subject to abatement. (Ord.
2393, 1-21-2002)
7-2-11: PENALTY:
Any person who deposits or stores any rubbish or other waste materials, including junk cars and other heavy junk and trash items, on any lot or parcel of
land in this village in violation of the provisions of this chapter, or who accumulates or otherwise disposes of any such rubbish or other waste materials in
violation of the provisions of this chapter, or any person who collects, obtains, possesses or picks up recyclable materials placed for collection at the
curbside for purposes of being collected in connection with the village's curbside recycling program, unless said person is an agent of a contractor duly
authorized under contract with the village to collect recyclable materials within the corporate limits of the village, and any person who maintains a nuisance
as defined in this chapter, upon any premises within this village shall be subject to a penalty as provided for in section 1-4-1 of this code for each such
offense; and each day that such violation or nuisance continues shall be deemed as a separate offense. (Ord. 2393, 1-21-2002)
7-2-12: FAILURE TO REMOVE RUBBISH AND WASTE FROM PRIVATE PROPERTY; REMOVAL BY VILLAGE; LIEN FOR COST
OF REMOVAL:
The village may remove or provide for the removal of rubbish and other waste or debris from private property when the owner of such property after
reasonable notice refuses or neglects to remove such rubbish and waste as provided for in this chapter, and may collect from such owner the reasonable
cost thereof. This cost shall be a lien against the real estate affected, superior to all subsequent liens and encumbrances, except tax liens, if within sixty
(60) days after such cost and expense is incurred by the village, or the person performing the removal service by authority of the village, in his or its own
name, files notice of lien in the office of the recorder of deeds or of the registrar of Torrens Titles of Cook County, Illinois, wherein such real estate is
located. The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: a) a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof, b) the amount of
money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the removal service, and c) the date or dates when such expense was incurred by the
village. However, the village's lien shall not be valid as to any purchaser whose rights in and to such real estate have arisen subsequent to removal of the
rubbish, waste or debris and prior to the filing of said notice, and the said lien of the village shall not be valid as to any mortgagee, judgment creditor or
other lien or whose rights in and to such real estate arise prior to the filing of such notice. Upon payment of the cost and expense of removal by the owner
of or persons interested in such property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the village or person in whose name the lien has
been filed and the release may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. The lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclosure as in the
case of mortgages or mechanic's liens. Suit to foreclosure of this lien shall be commenced within two (2) years after the date of filing notice of lien. (Ord.
2393, 1-21-2002)

7-2-13: COMPANIES LICENSED FOR REMOVAL OF CONSTRUCTION WASTE:
(A) No person or company shall provide construction waste removal services without first receiving a license from the village.
(B) Each company shall pay an annual fee of three hundred dollars ($300.00) to be licensed under this section.
(C) All companies providing construction waste removal services shall be subject to the following standards and requirements:
1. Equipment:
(a) The company shall use modern equipment.
(b) Equipment used to perform any services under this chapter shall be properly licensed by the state of Illinois and conform to all applicable safety
standards.
(c) The appearance and sanitary condition of collection vehicles and other equipment will be maintained to high standards by cleaning, washing,
painting and disinfecting as necessary. All equipment operated by the company will be in good repair at all times.
(d) The company shall not store, or allow to be stored, any equipment or materials on private property except in strict compliance with applicable
village ordinances.
2. Care And Disposition Of Materials:
(a) All waste collected by the company shall be removed from the village no less frequently than once per week during construction and within twenty
four (24) hours after completion of construction and transported to a facility designated or approved by the state in which it is located.
(b) The company shall not cause or contribute to litter in the process of making collections.
(c) All materials collected by the company shall be so contained, secured or enclosed during collection and transportation so that leaking, spilling or
blowing is prevented.
(d) The company shall immediately clean up and remediate all litter, blowing debris, spills and releases of any material over which it exercises control
occurring prior to the delivery of the material to its intended destination.
3. Insurance:
(a) The company shall at all times during its performance of services within the village maintain in full force and effect employer's liability, workers'
compensation, public liability and property damage insurance, including contractual liability coverage. Certificates or other evidence of such
insurance shall be furnished by the company to the village prior to the village's issuance of a license to the company. The company shall carry the
following types of insurance in at least the limits specified below:
Workers' compensationStatutory as amended from time to time
Employer's liability $500,000.00
Bodily injury liability$500,000.00 each occurrence
Except automobile$1,000,000.00 aggregate
Property damage liability$500,000.00 each occurrence
Except automobile$1,000,000.00 aggregate
Automobile bodily injury$1,000,000.00 each person
Liability$3,000,000.00 each occurrence
Automobile property damage$500,000.00 each occurrence
Excess umbrella liability$5,000,000.00 each occurrence
(b) Said insurance policies shall provide that they cannot be canceled without thirty (30) days' prior written notice to the village. The company shall
furnish the village with certificates evidencing that the insurance provided for herein is maintained by the company.
(c) The company shall also provide a bond in favor of the village in an amount of no less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) to secure the repair
of any damage to village property caused by the company. (Ord. 2393, 1-21-2002)
Chapter 3
MOSQUITO PREVENTION
7-3-1: DEFINITION:
The term "collections of water" is hereby defined as collections of water in which mosquitoes breed or are likely to breed, which waters are those contained
in ditches, ponds, pools, excavations, holes, depressions, open cesspools, privy vaults, fountains, cisterns, tanks, shallow wells, barrels, troughs (except
horse troughs in frequent use), urns, cans, boxes, bottles, tubs, buckets, defective house roof gutters, tanks of flush closets or other similar water
containers. (1965 Code, Sec. 35.02)
7-3-2: COLLECTION OF STANDING WATER:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 280/519
It shall be unlawful for any person to have, keep, maintain, cause or permit within the corporate limits of the village any collection of standing or flowing
water in which mosquitoes breed or are likely to breed, unless such collection of water is treated so as to effectually prevent such breeding. (1965 Code,
Sec. 35.01)
7-3-3: MOSQUITO LARVAE EVIDENCE:
The natural presence of mosquito larvae in standing or running water shall be evidence that mosquitoes are breeding in such water. (1965 Code, Sec.
35.03)
7-3-4: TREATMENT:
Collections of water in which mosquitoes breed or are likely to breed shall be treated by such one or more of the following methods as shall be approved
by the village:
(A) Screening with wire netting of at least sixteen (16) meshes to the inch each way, or any other material which will effectually prevent the ingress or
egress of mosquitoes.
(B) Complete emptying at least every seven (7) days of unscreened containers, together with their thorough drying or cleaning.
(C) Using a larvicide approved and applied under the direction of the village.
(D) Covering completely the surface of the water with kerosene, petroleum, or paraffin oil at least once every seven (7) days.
(E) Cleaning and keeping sufficiently free of vegetable growth and other obstructions, and stocking with mosquito destroying fish.
(F) Filling or draining to the satisfaction of the village.
(G) Proper disposal, by removal or destruction, of tin cans, tin boxes, broken or empty bottles and similar articles likely to hold water. (1965 Code, Sec.
35.04)
7-3-5: FAILURE TO TAKE MEASURES:
In case the person responsible for the condition of premises on which mosquitoes breed or are likely to breed fails or refuses to take necessary measures
to prevent their breeding within ten (10) days after notice in writing has been given him by the village, or within such longer time after such notice as may
be specified in the notice the said person responsible shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter; and for each day after the expiration of ten (10)
days after the expiration of the time specified in the notice, as the case may be, that the person responsible fails or refuses to take such measures, the
said person responsible shall be deemed guilty of a separate violation of this chapter; and in case of such failure or refusal of the person responsible the
village is authorized to take the necessary measures to prevent the breeding of mosquitoes on such premises, and all necessary costs and expenses
incurred by the village for that purpose shall be a charge against the person responsible. (1965 Code, Sec. 35.05)
7-3-6: PENALTY:
Any person found guilty of a violation of this chapter, as described in section 7-3-5 of this chapter, shall be subject to penalty as provided for by section 1-
4-1 of this code. (1965 Code, Sec. 35.06)
Chapter 4
FOOD SERVICE AND RETAIL FOOD STORE SANITATION REGULATIONS
7-4-1: ADOPTION OF CODES:
There are hereby adopted by the village for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing the licensing and operation of food service, food sanitation,
food processing and retail food establishments, that certain code known as the food service sanitation code, 77 Illinois administrative code 750,
promulgated and published by the Illinois department of public health, being the 1999 and all subsequent editions of, or amendments to said code, save
and except such portions as are hereinafter modified or amended by section 7-4-2 of this chapter, and that certain code known as the retail food store
sanitation code, 77 Illinois administrative code 760, promulgated and published by the Illinois department of public health, being the 1998 and all
subsequent editions of, or amendments to said code, save and except such portions as are hereafter modified or amended by section 7-4-2 of this
chapter, of which codes not fewer than three (3) copies of each have been and now are on file in the office of the village clerk, and the same are hereby
adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the effective date hereof, the provisions of said codes shall be controlling within
the limits of the village and shall be known as the food service sanitation code and the retail food service sanitation code. (Ord. 2467, 10-20-2003)
7-4-2: AMENDMENTS TO CODES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 281/519
(A) The food service sanitation code is amended in the following respects:
1. The following definition contained in section 750.10 of the food service sanitation code, 77 Illinois administrative code 750, subpart A, shall be
amended to read as follows:
"Regulatory authority", for purposes of enforcement of this Code within the Village of Riverside, means the Illinois Department of Public Health, or the
Village of Riverside.
2. The following paragraphs shall be added to the food service sanitation code as part of new section 750.105:
SECTION 750.105 PROHIBITIONS; ENFORCEMENT
a.Prohibitions on Manufacturing and Sale of Food. No person shall manufacture for sale, produce, offer for sale or sell any product, drug, or article
of food, which is adulterated, misbranded or insufficiently labeled. The term "misbranded" as used herein, shall apply to all articles of food or drink,
the packages of which bear any statement, design or device regarding such article or the ingredients or substance contained therein which is false
or misleading in any particular; it shall also apply to any such products which are falsely branded as to the manufacturer, packer or dealer who
sells the same, or as to the state, territory or country in which it is manufactured or produced. The term "insufficiently labeled" as used herein shall
mean if a package, bottle, or container of food does not bear the name of the real manufacturer or jobber, the true grade or class of the product,
and the true net weight or volume or the contents or the capacity or trade size of the container.
b.Restrictions on Persons With Contagious Illnesses. No person, while affected with a disease in a communicable or contagious form or while a
carrier of such disease, or while afflicted with boils, open or infected wounds, or acute respiratory infection, shall work in a food service, food
processing, or retail food establishment in an area and capacity in which there is a likelihood of transmission of disease to patrons or to fellow
employees, either through direct contact or through the contamination of food or food contact surfaces with pathogenic organisms. No such person
shall be employed in such an area and capacity in a food service, food processing or retail food establishment. In addition to any other persons or
entities that may be responsible, the person or entity that owns, controls or manages the food service, food processing or retail food establishment
at which such person is found to be employed shall be responsible for compliance with this Rule.
c.Enforcement of Food Service Sanitation Code. The Health Officer, the Village Manager, and the police officers of the Village shall have the power
to enforce the provisions of this Chapter and all laws of the State in relation to food service sanitation regulations. For the purpose of carrying out
the foregoing, such persons shall have authority at all reasonable times to enter into any food establishment to inspect and record the conditions,
to inspect any article there held or offered for sale, which he or she has reason to believe is decayed, poisoned, adulterated, infected or in any way
unfit for human consumption, and to seize and confiscate the same forthwith. Any person, whether owner, operator, or occupant of said store,
room, or premises, who shall obstruct such entry or inspection or interfere with such seizure or confiscation shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, in
accordance with the requirements set forth in § 1-2-1.1 of the Illinois Municipal Code ("IMC"), 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1.1, and subject to the general penalty
provisions of § 1-4-1 of the Village Code. In prosecuting such offense, the Village may seek a penalty that includes a period of incarceration of up
to six (6) months as allowed by § 1-2-1.1 of the IMC.
d.Inspection of Food. The Health Officer, the Village Manager, and the police officers of the Village shall have power and authority to open any
package, can or vessel containing or supposed to contain any article manufactured, sold, or exposed for sale, or held in possession with intent to
sell, in violation of the provisions of Title 7, and may inspect the contents thereof and may take samples therefrom for analysis. All parties offering
food products for sale shall cooperate with the inspectors and render to such inspectors all the assistance in their power, in disclosing the
presence of any article so requested, and in selecting samples of food products as hereinafter provided.
e.Samples and Selection. The Health Officer or the inspector taking such samples as are referenced in Section 750.105d shall, in the case of bulk
or broken package goods, upon request of the dealer, divide the same into two (2) equal parts, as nearly as may be, and in case of sealed and
unbroken packages, he shall select two (2) of said packages, which two (2) packages shall constitute the sample taken, and to properly identify the
same, he shall in the presence of the person from whom the sample is taken, mark or seal each half or part of the package of such sample with a
paper seal or otherwise and shall write thereon the date and the name of the dealer in whose place of business the sample is found, and at the
same time he shall give notice to the person from whom said sample was taken, that said sample was obtained for the purpose of chemical
examination and testing.
(Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003; amd. Ord. 2467, 10-20-2003)

amended to read as follows:
"Regulatory authority", for purposes of enforcement of this Code within the Village of Riverside, means the Illinois Department of Public Health, or the
Village of Riverside.

the packages of which bear any statement, design or device regarding such article or the ingredients or substance contained therein which is false
or misleading in any particular; it shall also apply to any such products which are falsely branded as to the manufacturer, packer or dealer who
sells the same, or as to the state, territory or country in which it is manufactured or produced. The term "insufficiently labeled" as used herein shall
mean if a package, bottle or container of food does not bear the name of the real manufacturer or jobber, the true grade or class of the product,
and the true net weight or volume or the contents or the capacity or trade size of the container.
b.Restrictions on Persons With Contagious Illnesses. No person, while affected with a disease in a communicable or contagious form or while a
carrier of such disease, or while afflicted with boils, open or infected wounds, or acute respiratory infection, shall work in a retail food store in an
area and capacity in which there is a likelihood of transmission of disease to patrons or to fellow employees, either through direct contact or

7-4-3: ENFORCEMENT:
The persons designated in sections 7-1-2, 7-1-2-1 and 7-1-3 of this title shall have all the same powers and duties set forth therein with regard to the
enforcement of this chapter against food service and food processing establishments and commissaries as such terms are defined in the food service
sanitation code, as well as retail food stores and bakeries. (Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
7-4-4: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person or entity shall conduct business as a food service establishment, food processing establishment, or retail food store within the village without
obtaining a license so to do, and paying the license fee herein specified. (Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
7-4-5: LICENSE FEES:
The license fee for each place of business operated as a food service establishment, food processing establishment, or retail food store shall be as
provided in title 3, chapter 1 of this code. (Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
7-4-6: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for license shall be made by each person or entity identified in section 7-4-4 or 7-4-11 of this chapter on a form furnished by the village
manager and shall include (but need not be limited to) the following information:
(A) Name and address of person applying for license.
(B) Address of place where business is to be carried on.
(C) Nature of business for which license is desired.
(D) An agreement by the applicant for license that if license is issued, the health officer or his designee may at any reasonable time enter the premises
where the business is to be carried on and may make such inspection and tests as may be necessary for the purpose of determining whether or not the
provisions of this chapter are being complied with. (Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
7-4-7: PRELIMINARY INSPECTION:
Before any license shall be issued, the health officer shall cause an inspection to be made of the premises to be occupied by the applicant as a food
service or food processing establishment or retail food store, the equipment contained therein, the persons to be employed therein, the sanitary and
hygienic conditions, and all other matters relating to the business which it considers necessary or proper to inquire into from the standpoint of health and
sanitation. If it appears from such inspection or from other information furnished by applicant, that the business on the premises in question will be
conducted in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and of other applicable provisions of this code, the health officer shall approve such application
in writing. Thereupon, the village manager, upon the payment by the applicant of the license fee herein provided for, shall issue a license to the applicant
to carry on said business on said premises. Each licensee shall cause his license to be posted in a conspicuous place on the walls of the premises where
the business is carried on. (Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
7-4-8: BAKERIES:

Every operator of a bakery shall conform to sections 750.1200, 750.1210, 750.1230, 750.1240 and other applicable regulations of the IDPH food service
sanitation code, and the following additional regulation:
All rooms for storage of flour and other materials used for making bakery products shall be dry and well ventilated and shall be so arranged that the
shelves, cupboards, trays, troughs, bins, cases and other appliances for handling and storing said materials can be easily removed and cleaned. If the
floor of any such room is at or below the adjacent street level, no such materials shall be stored nearer to the floor than one foot (1'). (Ord. 2438, 1-21-
2003)
7-4-9: CONFECTIONERIES:
Every operator of a confectionery shall conform to the following additional regulations:
No operator of a confectionery shall sell or offer for sale or have in his custody for any purpose, any candy or other confection that contains malt, vinous or
spirituous liquors; or that contains any ingredient that gives or imparts to said candy or confection any color, flavor or aroma, unless such ingredient is a
vegetable product and conforms to the provisions of the United States food and drug act and is not injurious to health. (Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
7-4-10: REVOCATION, SUSPENSION OF LICENSE:
Any license issued hereunder may be revoked or suspended by the board of trustees for violation by licensee, or any employee thereof, of any provision of
this chapter. Any license may be suspended by the village manager for any such violation for a period not to extend beyond the date of the next regular
meeting of the board of trustees, if the village manager or health officer determines, based upon findings of violations by the health officer, that an
emergency exists that is injurious to the public health. (Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
7-4-11: VENDING MACHINES:
No person shall engage in the business of operating or having on the premises a vending machine dispensing food or drink within the village without
obtaining a license to do so and paying the license fees herein specified. (Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
7-4-12: LICENSE FEES FOR VENDING MACHINES:
The license fee for each vending machine dispensing food or drink shall be as provided in title 3, chapter 1 of this code. (Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
7-4-13: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to penalty as provided for in section 1-4-1 of this code, and such penalty may be in
addition to any suspension or revocation of a license. (Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 3016 - OUTDOOR EATING CAFES. Go to new ordinance.
7-4-14: OUTDOOR EATING CAFES:
(A) Eligibility:
1. Outdoor eating cafes are allowed as temporary uses on private property and on village rights of way in any business zoning district of the village only
upon approval by the board of trustees and based upon the standards set forth herein.
2. The use of public or private sidewalks or other public right of way (including property leased by the village) for outdoor eating cafes shall only be
permitted incidental to the operation of a restaurant on private contiguous property and only along the frontage of said restaurants or other property
immediately adjacent to said restaurants.
(B) Requirements For Outdoor Cafes:
1. An annual permit fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) shall be required;
2. All tables, chairs and other appurtenances shall be removed during the months of December to March or if required by the village manager at any
other time;
3. All outdoor cafe establishments shall comply with state and village health code regulations;
4. The outdoor cafe shall not be detrimental to the health, safety or general welfare of persons residing or working near the eating establishment;
5. The operation of outdoor cafes shall be permitted only between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M.;
6. All outdoor cafe permits shall be subject to review and such permits may be revoked at any time with thirty (30) days' notice;
7. If utilizing the public right of way or other property owned or leased by the village, the applicant must apply for a permit, and agree to enter into a
lease of the right of way, sign a hold harmless agreement prepared by the village, and submit to the village evidence of general liability insurance
(and, when applicable, dramshop liability insurance) including the village as a named insured and insuring the village against any liability resulting
from the uses permitted by this section. Minimum coverage shall be one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence, and the company issuing the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 284/519
policy shall have no less than an "A" rating by the most recent "AM Best Insurance Rating Guide". The decision as to whether to approve a permit
shall be within the discretion of the village board, based upon consideration of the safety and welfare of the public and the impact of the obstruction
on the right of way, in addition to other factors set forth in this section.
8. In no case shall the operation of the sidewalk cafe reduce the open portion of public and private sidewalk to less than five feet (5') clear of all
obstructions (i.e., street lighting, benches, trees, etc.);
9. All maintenance and upkeep of the public right of way associated with the operation of the outdoor cafe shall be the responsibility of the owner of
such cafe (upkeep includes clean up and the replacement of damaged public property).
(C) Design Criteria:
1. All outdoor furnishings shall be designed to withstand a wind pressure of not less than thirty (30) pounds per square foot;
2. Tables to be placed within the village right of way shall not have a surface area greater than nine (9) square feet, shall be easily removable and may
not impede safe pedestrian movement.
3. Materials and finishes shall be selected for their durability and wear as well as for their appearance. Proper measures shall be taken to correct
damage or decline due to the elements, neglect, or abuse;
4. Devices incorporated to separate eating areas from pedestrian pathways, such as fencing or planters, must conform to the above standards of
design.
(D) Submittal Requirements:
1. Completed application form and application fee;
2. Proof of insurance listing the village as an additional insured (for cafes using public rights of way);
3. Indemnification form signed by owner of the establishments (for cafes using public rights of way);
4. Site plan drawn to accurate scale illustrating location of the proposed outdoor eating area;
5. Catalog cuts and/or photographs of all furniture and other appurtenances to be located within the outdoor eating area.
(E) Approval Process:
1. Initial applications shall be reviewed by the building department and shall be approved by the village board;
2. Renewals (provided no or minimal changes are requested) shall be approved by the building department;
3. In each case an annual permit/inspection fee is required. (Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
Chapter 5
MILK AND MILK PRODUCTS
7-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
Certain of the words and terms used in this chapter are hereby defined as follows:
CERTIFIED MILK: Shall designate and include raw milk which conforms to the standards and requirements of the American Association of Medical Milk
Commissioners and is produced under the supervision of the Medical Milk Commission of the Medical Society of the city of Chicago and of the Illinois
department of public health or of the board of health of this village.
MILK: Except where otherwise stated, shall designate and include fresh milk, cream, skimmed milk, buttermilk and cultured buttermilk.
MILK PLANT: Shall designate and include any place, premises or establishment where milk or milk products are collected, handled, processed, stored,
bottled, pasteurized or prepared for distribution.
PASTEURIZED MILK: Shall designate milk which has been pasteurized as defined by the statutes of Illinois in a pasteurization plant approved by the
Illinois department of public health and cooled and bottled in a pasteurization plant or milk plant conforming with all of the requirements of construction,
equipment and operation specified in "Minimum Requirements For Construction, Equipment And Operation Of Milk Pasteurization Plants" as formulated by
the Illinois department of public health, and containing not more than the following number of bacteria per cubic centimeter for each of the following
classes of milk:
Milk (not including cream or buttermilk) 30,000
Cream 50,000
RAW MILK: Shall designate and include milk which is not included in the term "pasteurized milk" as that term is defined in this chapter.
SALE OR SELL: Shall refer to the sale, selling, exchange or giving away of "milk" as herein defined. (1965 Code, Sec. 40.01; amd. Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
7-5-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 285/519
No person shall sell or deliver or have in his custody for the purpose of selling or delivering any milk for human food without having obtained a license for
that purpose from the village manager. Application for such license shall be made on a form to be provided by the village manager and shall contain (but
need not be limited to) the following information:
(A) Name and place of business of the person applying for the license; the description or class of milk to be handled, i.e., whether "pasteurized" or
"certified".
(B) Whether or not the place of business of the applicant is in a store, delicatessen shop or other shop or stand or store whatsoever.
(C) The number of vehicles, if any, used or to be used in the village, in the business of the applicant for the transportation and delivery of milk and such
description of each as the village manager shall require upon such application. (1965 Code, Sec. 40.02; amd. Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
7-5-3: RULES; REGULATIONS; INSPECTIONS:
The board of health may make such reasonable rules and regulations regarding applications for, issuance and revocation of licenses as it may deem
necessary for the proper protection of the public health, and may make suitable regulations regarding the sanitary conditions under which milk is produced,
transported, stored and handled; the health officer or other representative of the board of health shall have authority to enter at all reasonable times and
inspect all places where milk is kept, transported or produced. (1965 Code, Sec. 40.03; amd. Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
7-5-4: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
The health officer upon being satisfied that an applicant for license is a responsible party, and that he is complying or will comply with the provisions of this
code and the state law regarding the sale and distribution of milk, shall approve, in writing, such application, and the village manager, upon the payment of
the fee hereinafter provided for, shall issue a license to such applicant, bearing a serial number, containing the name, residence and place of business of
the licensee, the time of expiration of the license, and a description of the kinds or classes of milk in which the licensee is authorized to deal within the
village. Each licensee shall cause his license to be posted in his place of business, and the serial number of such license and the term for which it is
issued shall be posted legibly and conspicuously upon each vehicle used to deliver milk within the village. (1965 Code, Sec. 40.04; amd. Ord. 2438, 1-21-
2003)
7-5-5: LICENSE FEE:
The license fee for each vehicle used for delivery of milk shall be as provided in title 3, chapter 1 of this code. (1965 Code, Sec. 40.05; amd. Ord. 2438, 1-
21-2003)
7-5-6: SALE OR DELIVERY OF MILK:
No milk shall be sold or delivered in the village except "pasteurized milk" or "certified milk" as defined in this chapter, providing that nothing herein
contained shall prevent the bringing into the village of raw milk solely for delivery to a pasteurization plant or plants. (1965 Code, Sec. 40.06; amd. Ord.
2438, 1-21-2003)
7-5-7: LABELING CONTAINER:
All containers enclosing milk shall be plainly labeled or marked with: a) the designation of the contents as, for example, "raw milk", "pasteurized milk",
"certified milk", "pasteurized cream", "pasteurized buttermilk", etc.; b) the name of the producer or distributor. (1965 Code, Sec. 40.07; amd. Ord. 2438, 1-
21-2003)
7-5-8: ORIGINAL CONTAINER:
No milk producer or distributor, or person engaged in the sale or delivery of milk shall transfer milk from one container to another upon the street or in any
vehicle or store or any place except in a "milk plant" as herein defined. No milk shall be sold or delivered within the village or served in any hotel, soda
fountain, restaurant or similar establishment, therein except in the original tightly closed container in which received from the milk plant where it was
pasteurized and bottled. (1965 Code, Sec. 40.08; amd. Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
7-5-9: TUBERCULIN TEST:
All milk sold or delivered within the village shall be from cows that are free from tuberculosis as shall have been determined by the tuberculin test as
administered under the supervision of state or federal authorities empowered to supervise such test. (1965 Code, Sec. 40.09; amd. Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
7-5-10: STANDARDS OF PURITY:
All milk sold and delivered in the village shall conform to the standards of purity and butterfat and solid content prescribed by the statutes of Illinois. No
milk shall be sold or delivered within the village which has been obtained from any cow within fifteen (15) days before or five (5) days after that cow has
borne a calf or such longer period as may be necessary to render the milk practically colostrum free. (1965 Code, Sec. 40.10; amd. Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 286/519
7-5-11: DELIVERY AT QUARANTINED PREMISES:
Milk may be delivered at quarantined premises provided that there is no contact of any kind between inmates of the quarantined premises and the delivery
agent. The householder may place a thoroughly clean container (a freshly scalded bottle or pail) to receive the milk at some convenient place outside the
house out of reach of cats or dogs. The milkman shall then place the milk therein without handling the receiving container. No milk bottle, bucket or any
other article whatsoever, shall be taken out or away from the quarantined premises during the period of quarantine. Before milk bottles are removed from
the premises after quarantine is raised they must be sterilized by boiling under the direction of the board of health. (1965 Code, Sec. 40.11; amd. Ord.
2438, 1-21-2003)
7-5-12: LICENSE SUSPENDED OR REVOKED:
All licenses granted pursuant to this chapter may be suspended or revoked at any time by the president or board of trustees, upon recommendation of the
health officer for violation of the provisions of this chapter, or of the state law, or of any regulation of the board of health made pursuant to law respecting
the production, sale or delivery of milk, but the health officer may suspend such license, because of any such violation, for a period not exceeding five (5)
days, pending action by the president or board of trustees. (1965 Code, Sec. 40.12; amd. Ord. 2438, 1-21-2003)
Chapter 6
RODENT AND ANIMAL CONTROL
7-6-1: DUTY TO MAINTAIN PROPERTY:
It shall be the duty of every owner of and person interested in private real property ("owner") to take all necessary actions to: a) prevent the presence of
and eliminate rats from the property, and b) prevent and eliminate from the property the continuing presence of other rodents and nondomesticated
animals to the extent that such animals constitute a human health and safety hazard and therefore a nuisance to neighboring property and the public.
Such actions shall include, but not be limited to: complying with all provisions of chapter 2 of this title pertaining to garbage and refuse; removing from the
real property any materials of whatever nature, in addition to "garbage", manure and waste as those terms are defined in section 7-2-1 of this title that
attract or may attract rats, other rodents and nondomesticated animals to the real property, and eliminating any unsafe and unsanitary conditions that may
cause or contribute to the presence of rats and undomesticated animals upon the real property as determined by the village's designated officer. (Ord.
2423, 9-16-2002)
7-6-2: NOTICE:
The village shall cause a notice to be served upon any owner who fails to comply with section 7-6-1 of this chapter, or upon whose real property any rats
or other rodents and nondomesticated animals are observed by the designated officer, or whenever complaints of rats or undomesticated animals on the
property are received by the village. The notice shall state the conditions observed or reported, and, with regard to rats, shall give the owner seven (7)
days to take the necessary actions to prevent ingress of rats to such property and to exterminate the rats therefrom, or, with regard to other rodents and
nondomesticated animals, shall give the owner fourteen (14) days to notify the appropriate government authorities as to their presence and request that
those authorities take lawful action to trap or otherwise capture and remove such animals in the manner allowed by law and in accordance with prevailing
health and safety standards. The written notice required by this subsection shall be deemed delivered when deposited in the United States mail, first class,
postage prepaid, addressed to the owner at the address of the property on which the violation(s) exist. (Ord. 2423, 9-16-2002)
7-6-3: EXTERMINATION OF RATS BY VILLAGE; LIEN UPON PROPERTY:
(A) Upon the failure of the owner to comply with the notice required in section 7-6-2 of this chapter within the specified time period, where the notice
concerns rats, the village shall have the authority to enter upon the real property and exterminate the rats therefrom, and take further measures to
prevent ingress of rats to such property.
