9-1-22: WAIVER OF PARKING RESTRICTIONS, NOTICE:
The parking restrictions provided for in this Chapter, particularly the restrictions provided in Section 9-1-4 of this Chapter on all-night parking and in Section
9-1-13 of this Chapter on use of parking lights, may be varied or otherwise waived by the Police Department, where it is determined, upon notification
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 361/519
being first given to the Department by the person concerned, that compliance with such restrictions cannot be achieved due to the disability of a particular
motor vehicle, or that compliance with such restrictions would constitute an undue hardship or be unreasonably burdensome under the circumstances.
(1974 Code)
Where parking has been prohibited at all times on both sides of a residential street in section 9-1-15 of this chapter upon notification being first given to the
Police Department by the person concerned, requesting on-street parking, and upon a determination being made by the department that such parking is
necessary under the circumstances to accommodate such person concerned, as in the event of a party or meeting, or other gathering where off-street
parking facilities are inadequate to service the parking requirements, the Police Department shall allow on-street parking on one (1) side of such public
street for such distance and for such period of time as shall be determined and designated by the department as sufficient and necessary to satisfy the
parking requirements of the person requesting the same. (Ord. 1378, 10-25-1978)
9-1-23: PENALTIES:
(A) General Penalties: Except as otherwise provided for herein, any person convicted of a violation of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be subject to the
penalty as provided by section 1-4-1 of this Code.
Any person convicted of a violation of the provisions of section 9-1-11 of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00) or more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.
Any person convicted of a violation of the provisions of section 9-1-25 of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) or more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), or such higher amount as may be imposed by 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-1301.3 for
each offense.
(B) Administrative Adjudication Of Certain Violations: Any person accused of violating any of the provisions of this chapter may be issued a violation
notice, in lieu of filing a complaint in court against said person for such violation, to be administratively adjudicated pursuant to chapter 6 of this title or
title 1, chapter 23 of this Code, where administrative adjudication is authorized by such chapters, and shall be subject to the fines and penalties
established therein.
(C) Penalties For Certain Illinois Vehicle Code Violations: Any person accused of violating any of the following designated provisions of the Illinois Vehicle
Code1, which are hereby adopted by reference as part of this chapter, may be issued a violation notice, in lieu of filing a complaint in court against said
person for such violation, to be administratively adjudicated pursuant to chapter 6 of this title and the fines and penalties established therein. The
violations subject to use of the violation notice and administrative adjudication are described as follows:
Code
Section Code Violation
3-112(b) Failure to transfer title within five (5) business days
3-401(a) No valid registration - never applied
3-404 No bill of lading or manifest/dispatch record - second division vehicle
3-411(a) Failure to carry registration card or reciprocity permit - second division vehicle
3-412(a-e) Improper display of license plates, registration stickers and driveway decal permits

9-1-24: USE OF AUTOMOBILE IMMOBILIZATION AUTHORIZED:
In lieu of or in addition to other remedies provided for violations of this chapter, the Police Department is hereby authorized to use an immobilizer or
immobilization equipment on any vehicle owned by the violator and located on public property within this Village. Such immobilization equipment is
authorized for the purpose of reducing or eliminating costs of towing, impounding and inventorying said vehicle; reducing the additional time and expense
concerning the issuance of a complaint or violation notice and the processing of the same; and deterring would-be "scofflaws" from consistent violations of
one (1) or more provisions of this chapter. Immobilization shall be accomplished pursuant to section 9-6-11 of this title. It shall further be a violation of this
section for any person to injure, damage or otherwise destroy any immobilizer or immobilization equipment belonging to the Police Department of this
Village and attached to any vehicle. (Ord. 2163, 9-16-1996)

9-1-27: SPECIAL PERMIT PARKING:
Parking within the following designated areas shall be limited to persons having a special permit therefor during the hours from seven thirty o'clock (7:30)
A.M. to eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. Monday through Friday of each week and from seven thirty o'clock (7:30) A.M. to three o'clock (3:00) P.M. on Saturday of

for a distance of one hundred two feet (102') northeasterly thereof. (Ord. 1788, 12-21-1987)
9-1-28: SAFETY BELTS REQUIRED:
(A) Definitions: The following words and phrases when used in this section will, for the purpose of this section, have the meanings respectively ascribed to
them in chapter 1 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 et seq.: "driver", "motor vehicle", "passenger car", "motorcycle",
"operator" and "roadway".
(B) Violations, Exceptions, Penalties, Applicability:
1. Each driver and each passenger of a motor vehicle operated on a roadway in this Village will wear a properly adjusted and fastened seat belt; except
that children less than six (6) years of age will be protected as required pursuant to the Illinois Child Passenger Protection Act2. Each driver of a
motor vehicle will, when transporting a child six (6) years of age or more, but less than sixteen (16) years of age, in a motor vehicle, secure the child
in a properly adjusted and fastened safety belt.
2. The provisions of this section will not apply to any of the following:
(a) A driver or passenger frequently stopping and leaving the vehicle for roadway maintenance or roadway construction, if the speed of the vehicle
between stops does not exceed fifteen (15) miles per hour.
(b) A driver or passenger possessing a written statement from a physician that such person is unable, for medical or physical reasons, to wear a
safety belt.
(c) A driver or passenger possessing an official certificate or license endorsement issued by the appropriate agency in another state or county
indicating that the driver or passenger is unable for medical, physical or other valid reasons to wear a safety belt.
(d) A driver operating a motor vehicle in reverse.
(e) A motor vehicle with a model year prior to 1965.
(f) A motorcycle.
(g) A motor vehicle which is not required to be equipped with safety belts under Federal law.
3. Violation of any provision of this section is hereby declared to be a petty offense, and any operator or passenger of a passenger motor vehicle,
convicted of a violation hereunder will be fined up to one hundred dollars ($100.00).
4. Failure to wear a seat belt in violation of this section will not be considered evidence of negligence, will not limit the liability of an insurer, and will not
diminish any recovery for damages arising out of the ownership, maintenance, or operation of a motor vehicle.
5. Any Riverside police officer may stop any motor vehicle or driver or passenger of such vehicle solely on the basis of a violation or suspected
violation of this chapter while such motor vehicle is being operated on any roadway within this jurisdiction. (Ord. 2260, 11-16-1998)
9-1-29: CURB LOADING ZONE/PICK-UP PARKING:
(A) The Village Manager and Chief of Police may designate or sign any curb loading zone upon special request of any person who makes application for a
permit for the zone.
(B) No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers or
materials in any place marked as a curb loading zone or fifteen (15) minute parking zone during hours when the regulations applicable to that zone are
in effect, and then only for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) minutes. (Ord. 2925, 10-20-2016)
Chapter 2
PARKING LOTS
9-2-1: DEFINITIONS; LOT LOCATIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, certain terms used herein are defined as follows:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 366/519
BUSINESS PARKING: Parking space provided for the parking of vehicles of those persons who own, operate, are employed by or are customers and
patrons of business establishments located within the village and who use such motor vehicles to travel to and from their homes and such business area.
BUSINESS PERMIT: A permit conferring on a business owner, manager or employee a right to park in lots designated for business parking purposes. A
business permit must be permanently displayed on the rear window of a vehicle in order to be effective.
COMMUTER PARKING: Parking space provided for the parking of vehicles of those persons, both residents and nonresidents, who use the train facilities
of the Burlington Northern, Inc., and who use such motor vehicles to travel to and from their homes and the boarding point of such facilities at the train
station situated on Riverside Road in the village.
COMMUTER PERMIT: A permit conferring on the person to whom issued a right to park the vehicle for which the permit is issued, in a village commuter
parking lot, or a designated stall within a commuter lot, specified in the permit, between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M., on
any day during the period for which the permit is issued.
HOLIDAY: Shall mean and include New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day.
HOURLY CHARGES: The charge per hour or hours for parking a vehicle in a village parking lot, by a person who does not hold a "parking permit" as
herein defined.
OFF STREET RESIDENTIAL PARKING: Parking space provided in certain village lots for the parking of noncommercial passenger vehicles of residents
who do not have sufficient area on their residence premises to provide the minimum number of parking spaces for such vehicles required by the zoning
ordinance of the village. Off street residential parking is available for a limited number of spaces designated by the village and is intended primarily for
persons residing in the central business district, with a limit of two (2) permits per household.
PARKING PERMIT: A "commuter permit", "business permit", or a "twenty four hour parking permit", as herein defined.
QUARTER: Each of the three (3) month periods from January 1 to March 31; April 1 to June 30; July 1 to September 30 and October 1 to December 31,
all dates inclusive.
STALL: A parking space for a single vehicle, the boundaries of which are indicated by lines or boundaries marked in any village parking lot.
TWENTY FOUR HOUR PARKING PERMIT: A permit conferring on the Riverside resident to whom issued a right to park the vehicle for which the permit is
issued, in the village parking lot, or a designated stall within a lot, specified in the permit, at all hours, both day and night during the period for which the
permit is issued.
VILLAGE PARKING LOT: Any parking lot owned or leased by the village and set aside for the parking of vehicles, including the following:
(A) Lot no. 1, located on the north side of the intersection of Barrypoint and Bloomingbank Road.
(B) Lot no. 2, located on the south side of Pine Avenue west of well house no. 3.
(C) Lot no. 3, located on the north side of Park Place throughout its length.
(D) Lot no. 4, located on the north side of Pine Avenue west of East Avenue.
(E) Lot no. 5, located on the south side of Riverside Road east of the village hall.
(F) Lot no. 6, located on the south side of East Burlington Street, approximately five hundred feet (500') east of Longcommon Road.
(G) Lot no. 7, located on the south side of East Burlington Street, approximately one hundred fifty feet (150') east of Longcommon Road.
(H) Lot no. 8, located east of the Longcommon Road railroad crossing on the north and south side of the tracks on Burlington Northern Railroad right
of way.
(I) Lot no. 9, located on the south side of Riverside Road west of the village hall, adjacent to the Riverside Public Library.
(J) Lot no. 10 located east of the Longcommon Road railroad crossing adjacent to the north side of the tracks on the Burlington Northern Railroad
right of way.
Together with such other parking lots as may be acquired by the village and made available for parking of vehicles, either in addition to, or in replacement
of, any of the foregoing lots. (Ord. 2826, 11-7-2013)
9-2-2: PARKING LOT DESIGNATION AND RESTRICTIONS:
Village parking lots shall be restricted to the following designated uses:
(A) Lot no. 1: To be used for commuter and residential parking.
(B) Lots no. 2, 3 and 4: To be limited to off street residential parking use with twenty four (24) hour permits only provided.
(C) Lot no. 5: To be used for parking of municipal employee vehicles and limited daytime public parking where available, and for the temporary parking of
inoperative and other vehicles by order or at the instance of the police department in the event of an emergency situation as determined by the chief of
police or the ranking officer in command during the absence of the chief.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 367/519
(D) Lot no. 6: To be used for business parking by patrons of the business district, with parking in the three (3) southernmost parking spaces to be limited to
fifteen (15) minutes between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) P.M. on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday, and eight
thirty o'clock (8:30) A.M. and two o'clock (2:00) P.M. Wednesday and Saturday of each week, holidays excepted.
(E) Lot no. 7: To be used for business parking by patrons of the Business District.
(F) Lot no. 8: To be used for commuter parking weekdays with commuter permits and for daytime public parking on weekends and holidays.
(G) Lot no. 9: To be used for parking of Municipal and designated Township and library personnel vehicles.
(H) Lot no. 10: To be used primarily for business parking by employees of businesses in the Business District. A portion of the western end of lot no. 10
may be designated for commuter parking. The Village Manager may decide what portion of the lot is appropriately designated for commuter parking
and may adjust such portion from time to time. No parking is allowed between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. (Ord.
2826, 11-7-2013)
9-2-3: PERMITS REQUIRED:
No person shall park any vehicle on a Village parking lot, except on lot no. 5 without complying with the following requirements:
(A) Without paying the hourly charge;
(B) For parking between six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M., without procuring a commuter permit or twenty four (24) hour parking permit
for the period during which the vehicle is parked; and
(C) For parking between nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on the following day, without procuring a twenty four (24) hour parking permit
for the period during which the vehicle is parked or paying the charges pursuant to section 9-2-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 2826, 11-7-2013)
9-2-4: HOURLY CHARGE FOR PARKING:
Effective January 1, 2017, hourly charges for parking a vehicle in a Village parking lot shall be at the rate of twenty five cents ($0.25) every one (1) hour up
to twenty four (24) hours. Charges for hourly parking shall be due every day except Saturdays, Sundays and holidays. The hourly charge shall be collected
through parking meters or by such other means as the Village Manager shall prescribe. (Ord. 2929, 11-3-2016)
9-2-5: PARKING PERMIT FEES:
Parking permit fees for individuals and businesses shall be for a minimum three (3) month period as follows:
(A) The cost of a commuter permit for individuals shall be one hundred thirty dollars ($130.00) for each three (3) month period. In computing the permit fee
for any period, prorating shall be calculated in half month (15 day) increments.
A second commuter permit for the same immediate family in the same household for the same space shall be twenty dollars ($20.00) for each three (3)
month period. Reasonable proof that both vehicles belong to the same family at the same address, such as vehicle registrations, driver's licenses, etc.,
may be required as evidence. No prorating or refunds shall be permitted for the second permit.
(B) The cost of a twenty four (24) hour permit for lots no. 1, no. 2, no. 3 and no. 4 shall be one hundred seventy five dollars ($175.00) for each three (3)
month period, with a limit of one (1) vehicle per space. In computing the permit fee for any period, prorating shall be calculated in half month (15 day)
increments.
(C) Business permits for lot no. 10 shall be provided at no charge, on a quarterly basis. A business permit is valid between the hours of five o'clock (5:00)
A.M. and two o'clock (2:00) A.M. on the following day. (Ord. 2929, 11-3-2016)
9-2-6: PERMIT APPLICATION, ISSUANCE:
(A) Application For Permit: Any person desiring a permit for twenty four (24) hour or commuter parking for a motor vehicle other than a truck, trailer,
commercial vehicle, or recreational vehicle as heretofore described, shall file an application with the Village Manager, upon a form to be provided by
the Manager, signed by the applicant and setting forth the applicant's name, address, a description of the motor vehicle to be permitted and such other
information as may be required in order to identify said motor vehicle and to enforce the provisions of this chapter.
(B) Permit Issuance: Upon receipt of an application for a parking permit for an eligible motor vehicle, and upon payment of the permit fee, the Village
Manager shall issue to the applicant the permit applied for including thereon the designated lot and the stall number when so assigned and the period
for which issued. The Manager will issue a sticker evidencing issuance of the permit. The sticker shall have imprinted thereon the permit number and
the period for which issued. The sticker shall have an adhesive substance on one (1) side and the permit shall be effective when the sticker has been
affixed to the exterior rear window of the passenger side of the motor vehicle to which it applies.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 368/519
The Village shall assign parking stalls to permit holders. (Ord. 2826, 11-7-2013)
9-2-7: PARKING HOURS INCLUDED:
(A) Except as provided in section 9-2-10 of this chapter, the holder of a parking permit may park the vehicle for which it is issued in a Village parking lot
during the hours covered by the permit, in the quarter or other period for which the permit is issued.
(B) The holder of a permit, for parking in a Village lot between certain specified time limits, may use the parking lot for an additional one-half (1/2) hour
before, or after, the period specified in the permit without extra charge, if there is parking space available. (Ord. 1253, 2-17-1975)
9-2-8: SPECIAL REGULATIONS:
(A) No parking permit or fees shall be required for the parking of a vehicle in lot no. 5, but the following regulations shall apply to that lot:
1. Except by action of the Police Department as heretofore provided in this chapter, no vehicle other than that of a government employee during
working hours shall be parked in said lot between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M.
2. Except by action of the Police Department as heretofore provided in this chapter, the public may utilize the parking lot after six o'clock (6:00) P.M.
until two o'clock (2:00) A.M.
3. Except by action of the Police Department as heretofore provided in this chapter, no vehicle shall be parked in said lot between the hours of two
o'clock (2:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. (Ord. 2482, 1-20-2004)
9-2-9: PARKING WITHIN STALLS REQUIRED:
The village may, by appropriate lines or markers, divide any parking lot into stalls. In such case, each vehicle shall be parked within a stall, with its sides
parallel to the adjacent boundaries of the stall, and at least one foot (1') distant therefrom. (1965 Code, Sec. 28.09)
9-2-10: VEHICLES EXCLUDED FOR MAINTENANCE:
The village may exclude vehicles from all or any part of any village parking lot for such periods between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. and four thirty
o'clock (4:30) P.M., as may be reasonably required to clear the lot of snow, or otherwise to improve or to maintain it in proper condition. (1965 Code, Sec.
28.10)
9-2-11: CERTAIN VEHICLES EXCLUDED:
No truck, trailer or commercial vehicle and no recreational vehicle exceeding seven feet (7') in height and nineteen feet (19') in length may be parked in
any village parking lot. (Ord. 1253, 2-17-1975)
9-2-12: REPAIR OF VEHICLES ON LOT PROHIBITED:
Except by action of the police department as heretofore provided in this chapter, no vehicle that is not in operating condition shall be parked in any village
parking lot. No one shall repair or service any vehicle on a village parking lot except insofar as may be necessary to facilitate the removal of the vehicle
from the lot. (Ord. 1253, 2-17-1975)
9-2-13: LITTERING LOT PROHIBITED:
No one shall deposit any rubbish, paper, litter or debris in any village parking lot. (1965 Code, Sec. 28.13)
9-2-14: VILLAGE LIABILITY LIMITED:
The village shall not be responsible for damage to any vehicle while in a village parking lot, whether or not such damage results from the condition of the
lot or its appurtenances, or for loss of any such vehicle, or for loss of any property contained in such vehicle. The permission given by this chapter to any
person to park his vehicle in the village parking lot is conditioned upon his acceptance of the exemption of the village, as in this section provided. Every
person so parking a vehicle in a village parking lot shall be deemed to have accepted and agreed to such exemption. (1965 Code, Sec. 28.14)
9-2-15: ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION OF PARKING VIOLATIONS:
Any person accused of violating any of the provisions of this chapter may be issued a violation notice, in lieu of filing a complaint in court against said
person for such violation, to be administratively adjudicated pursuant to chapter 6 of this title and the fines and penalties established therein. (Ord. 2164, 9-
16-1996)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 369/519
9-2-16: AUTOMOBILE IMMOBILIZATION/TOWING AND IMPOUNDMENT:
In lieu of or in addition to other remedies provided for violations of this chapter, the police department is hereby authorized to use an immobilizer or
immobilization equipment on any vehicle owned by the violator and located on public property within this village or, in the alternative, to have any such
vehicle found to be in violation of any provision of this chapter towed and impounded at the expense of the owner, pursuant to section 9-6-11 of this title.
Such immobilization equipment is authorized for the purpose of reducing or eliminating costs of towing, impounding and inventorying said vehicle; reducing
the additional time and expense concerning the issuance of a complaint or violation notice and the processing of the same; and deterring would be
"scofflaws" from consistent violations of one or more provisions of this chapter. It shall further be a violation of this section for any person to injure, damage
or otherwise destroy any immobilizer or immobilization equipment belonging to the police department of this village and attached to any vehicle. (Ord.
2164, 9-16-1996)
9-2-17: REGULATION OF PRIVATE PARKING LOTS:
Any regulation of private parking lots within the village of Riverside by the village shall be pursuant to contract, as authorized by section 11-209 of the
Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-209 (2000). (Ord. 2369, 6-18-2001)
9-2-18: RESIDENTIAL PARKING ZONES:
(A) The board of trustees shall designate residential permit parking zones from time to time as traffic conditions require and such permit parking zones
shall be properly posted with appropriate signs designating the area as a "permit parking zone".
(B) A resident who lives in the block directly adjacent to the particular sides of the streets in the blocks described in subsection (D) of this section, and who
purchases a village of Riverside vehicle license as required by section 9-5-2, "License Required", of this title, shall be furnished with a resident parking
permit decal to be devised and issued by the village treasurer and which is to be distinctive for each described area or zone.
(C) Decals issued under this section shall be affixed immediately above the village of Riverside's vehicle license as required by section 9-5-5, "Issuance Of
License", of this title.
(D) The following shall be such particular and distinct areas or zones for which a residential parking permit decal shall be issued to residents living in such
areas or zones under this section:
1. Residents living on Selborne Road from York Road to Kent Road.
(E) Visitor parking passes may be obtained by any village resident living on a street designated as a "residential permit parking zone".
(F) Visitor parking passes will be available at the Riverside police department.
(G) Residency must be shown by proof of purchase of a current village vehicle license. If the resident is not a vehicle owner, other proof, such as a phone
bill, electric bill, etc., may be provided.
(H) All visitor parking passes, and any visitor parking cards issued under the previous provisions of this section, shall expire on December 31, of the year
in which they were issued.
(I) Visitor parking passes may only be used on the street where a resident lives or, if no parking is available, on an adjacent street.
(J) Visitor parking passes are to be displayed on the driver's side dashboard.
(K) The fee for either a residential parking permit or a visitor parking pass is as follows:
First 2 permits or passes per household per year No charge
Per permit or pass thereafter $5.00
(L) Any person who:
1. Provides false or misleading information to obtain the issuance of either a residential parking permit or a visitor parking pass;
2. Sells, assigns, rents or leases any such residential parking permit or visitor parking pass or charges a fee for use thereof;
3. Duplicates or attempts to duplicate a residential parking permit or visitor parking pass; or
4. Uses a residential parking permit or visitor parking pass not properly issued by the village of Riverside shall be subject to the penalty provided in
section 9-6-9, "Schedule Of Fines/Penalties", of this title, for each such violation. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or
on which a violation occurs or continues to occur. (Ord. 2489, 4-19-2004)

Chapter 3
BICYCLES
9-3-1: DEFINITION:
The term "bicycle" shall be taken to mean and include a vehicle propelled by the pedalling of the rider or riders and having two (2) wheels, one in front of
the other, at least one of which is over twenty inches (20") in diameter. The term does not include motorcycles. (1965 Code, Sec. 30.01)
9-3-2: STATE VEHICLE CODE GOVERNS:
Every person operating a bicycle in the village shall conform to the provisions of the Illinois vehicle code, and shall also be subject to the following
regulations in this chapter. (Ord. 1230, 7-15-1974; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
9-3-3: OPERATING REGULATIONS:
(A) Speed: No bicycle shall be propelled faster than is reasonable and proper for the safety of the rider and others using the highway. (1965 Code, Sec.
30.14; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
(B) Hitching To Other Vehicles: No person operating a bicycle shall cling to or attach himself to any other moving vehicle. (1965 Code, Sec. 30.15; amd.
Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
(C) Riding Rules: All bicycles shall be operated as near to the right hand curb as the conditions will permit and not more than two (2) bicycles shall be
operated abreast, or side by side, and only when both bicycles can be thus operated to the right of the center of the highway and when no vehicle is
approaching from front or rear. When a vehicle is approaching or passing from the front or rear, bicycles shall be operated only in single file. (1965
Code, Sec. 30.16; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
(D) One Rider: No bicycles shall be used to carry more than one person at a time unless it is designed and equipped for the use of two (2) or more
persons. (1965 Code, Sec. 30.17; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
(E) No Vehicles To Be Attached: No bicycle shall have attached to it any other vehicle such as a wagon or sled. (1965 Code, Sec. 30.18; amd. Ord. 2506,
8-16-2004)
(F) Riding On Walks: Bicycles may be operated on the sidewalks providing that they are operated at such speed and in such manner as not to conflict with
the use of the sidewalks by pedestrians and not otherwise. Pedestrians shall at all times have the prior right to the use of the sidewalks, and if, under
the conditions of use of the sidewalk, a bicycle cannot be operated without interfering with the safety and comfort of any pedestrian using the sidewalk,
the bicycle rider must dismount. (1965 Code, Sec. 30.19; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
(G) Trick Riding: No rider of a bicycle shall remove both hands from the handlebars or practice any acrobatic or fancy riding on any public street or
sidewalk. (1965 Code, Sec. 30.20; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
(H) Parking, Obstructing Walks: No bicycle shall be left lying upon any street or sidewalk or in such position as to obstruct or interfere with the use of any
street or sidewalk. (1965 Code, Sec. 30.21; amd. Ord. 2506, 8-16-2004)
9-3-4: FINE; IMPOUNDMENT:
Any person convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished as set forth in section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense, or
by the impounding of his bicycle for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days, or by any combination of the penalties herein prescribed. (Ord. 2506, 8-16-
2004)
Chapter 4
TAXICABS
9-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Chapter, the following terms are thus defined:
OWNER: Every person having the use or control of one or more taxicabs as defined in this Section.
PUBLIC PASSENGER VEHICLE: Any automobile for hire used for the transportation of passengers.
TAXICAB: A public passenger vehicle equipped with a taximeter.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 371/519
TAXIMETER: A mechanical device which records and indicates a charge or fare measured by distance traveled, waiting time and extra passengers. (Ord.
2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No public passenger vehicle shall be operated in the Village, except to deliver passengers therein from points outside of Riverside, without a license
having first been obtained for such vehicle as provided in this Chapter. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-3: LIABILITY INSURANCE REQUIRED:
No owner shall be licensed to operate a taxicab until he has complied with the State of Illinois law pertaining to a surety bond or liability insurance
coverage and can provide proof of insurance to the Village. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Every request for license to operate a taxicab shall be made to the Village Clerk by the taxicab owner. The Village Clerk will provide blank application
forms to the owner. Applications must be completed for:
(A) Cab company license.
(B) Taxicab driver's license.
(C) Taxicab registration.
All applications must be accompanied by proof of insurance.
Taxicab licenses shall be issued annually on January 1, and shall be valid through December 31 of that same year. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-5: POLICE AUTHORITY FOR INSPECTION AND LICENSE:
The licensing and inspecting of taxicabs, the examining of applicants for licenses to drive such taxicabs, the licensing of drivers and enforcing of the
provisions of this Chapter shall be under the control of the Chief of Police.
The Chief of Police shall require that all taxicabs be kept in a condition of continued fitness for public use. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-6: TAXICAB INSPECTIONS:
(A) No taxicab shall be licensed until the Chief of Police or his designated inspector has inspected it. In the event that the taxicabs are licensed and
inspected regularly by another municipality, proof of inspection and compliance in said municipality may be substituted in lieu of an inspection
conducted by Riverside.
(B) The above mentioned inspections shall occur, at least, once every six (6) months. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-7: INSPECTIONS OF VEHICLES AS PREREQUISITE TO LICENSING:
No vehicle shall be licensed as a taxicab, whether upon new application or renewal, unless it is less than four (4) years old, and until it has been
thoroughly and carefully inspected and examined. The taxicab must be found to be in thoroughly safe condition for the transportation of passengers, clean
fit, or good appearance and well painted. The taximeter in such taxicabs must also be inspected and deemed accurate.
(A) It shall be the duty of the owner of each taxicab to submit to the Chief of Police each taxicab for inspection, or proof of inspection by an approved
municipality, prior to the issuance of the license and at least once every six (6) months thereafter, or at any time upon complaint.
(B) Such inspections or proof of inspections shall have been made prior to issuance of any license. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-8: ISSUANCE OF TAXICAB LICENSES:
Upon approval of the applications, the Chief of Police shall endorse such applications and file the same with the Village Clerk, who shall, upon payment of
the fee schedule prescribed in Section 3-1-6 of this Code, issue the license. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-9: REGISTER OF LICENSES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 372/519
The Chief of Police shall file with the Village Clerk a register containing the name and address of each person to whom a license is issued under this
Chapter. The register must contain the license number, a description of each vehicle licensed and a completed record of inspections made on each
vehicle. The register and accompanying records shall be available for public review during regular office hours in the Village offices. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-
1998)
9-4-10: POSTING OF NAMES AND LICENSEES:
Every public passenger vehicle shall bear on the right side thereof, in letters plainly visible from the street, the name, license number and address of the
licensee and shall otherwise be designated by such design or color scheme as the Chief of Police may prescribe. There shall be posted in the passenger
compartment of each taxicab, the name of the driver of the vehicle and the date and number of the driver's license issued to him by the Village. (Ord.
2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-11: TRANSFER:
It shall be unlawful to transfer any license to operate and conduct a taxicab business from one person to another person. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-12: TAXICAB CERTIFICATION DECALS:
All taxicabs licensed by the Village Clerk as provided in Section 9-4-9 of this Chapter shall be issued decals every six (6) months which shall contain a
number assigned to the taxicab along with the date of the most recent inspection. Such decal shall contain a space upon which an entry shall be made of
the date of inspection of the taxicab by the Chief of Police or an inspector appointed by him, unless inspections are carried out by an approved municipality
and accepted by Riverside in which case, said municipality's inspection decal will suffice so long as certification decals are of a distinctly different color
with each issuance. Decals shall be affixed to the lower right-hand corner of the windshield of each taxicab. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-13: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF TAXICAB LICENSE:
(A) Any taxicab license shall be subject to suspension or revocation upon conviction of the holder for any violation of this Chapter. The Board of Trustees
may, at its discretion, suspend or revoke a license granted upon any provision of this Chapter pending, or in advance of, the criminal prosecution of the
licensee, after notice and hearing.
(B) If any licensed taxicab shall become unsafe for the transportation of passengers or shall become unclean or unsightly in appearance, as determined by
the Chief of Police, the license for such taxicab shall be suspended by the Chief of Police until taxicab and all its appurtenances shall, in the opinion of
the Chief of Police, be put in fit condition for public use.
(C) Failure to keep such taxicabs in a safe and clean condition may also be grounds for suspension or revocation of the business license. (Ord. 2252, 10-
5-1998)
9-4-14: DUTY OF OWNERS TO FURNISH SERVICE; ABANDONMENT OF SERVICE:
The applicant shall operate his licensed vehicle(s) during each day of the licensed year to the extent necessary to meet public demand of such service.
Upon complete abandonment of such service for a period of ten (10) consecutive days by the owner or operator of such service, the Chief of Police, after
five (5) days' notice to such owners or operator, shall recommend to the Board of Trustees that the license of said owner/operator be revoked, covering all
licensed vehicles of such owner/operator. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-15: TAXICAB COLORS AND NAME:
No taxicab license shall be issued under the provisions of this Chapter to any person having the name or colors of his taxicab similar to that of any other
person having a taxicab license within Village limits. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-16: TAXIMETERS REQUIRED:
(A) Taximeters Required: Each taxicab shall be equipped with a taximeter or instrument so devised as to register, in plain view of the passenger, the fares
as accumulated while said cab is in operation.
(B) Inspections Required: Each taximeter shall be inspected in accordance with the regularly scheduled inspections of said taxicabs as provided for in
Section 9-4-7 of this Chapter. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-17: COMPLIANCE WITH TRAFFIC REGULATIONS:
The owner, operator and driver of any taxicab shall obey all laws, ordinances and regulations relating to the operation of motor vehicles and taxicabs, and
all traffic regulations. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 373/519
9-4-18: CABSTANDS:
The Chief of Police may designate portions of the streets as public cabstands and shall have installed suitable markers indicating such use. No vehicles,
other than taxicabs, shall be parked in a public cabstand. Taxicabs shall not be parked in any other location. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-19: CRUISING:
No driver of a taxicab licensed under the provisions of this Code shall seek passengers by repeatedly or persistently driving his vehicle to and fro in a short
space before any place of public gathering, or by otherwise interfering with traffic or the proper orderly ingress or egress from any such place. No driver of
any taxicab licensed in accordance with this Chapter shall solicit any passenger(s) upon or along any of the streets or public ways of the Village, orally or
by a signal, sign or sounding of a horn.
A driver of such taxicab may solicit passengers by driving through any public street at such speed as not to interfere with traffic or violate Village
ordinances. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-20: CARRYING ADDITIONAL PASSENGERS:
No driver of a taxicab licensed under this Chapter shall carry any person other than the first passenger employing the taxicab without the consent of the
first passenger. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-21: OVERCHARGING:
No driver of any taxicab shall charge or attempt to charge any passenger a greater fare than that to which such driver is entitled under the provisions of
this Chapter. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-22: PREPAYMENT OF FARE:
Every driver shall have the right to demand payment of the legal fare in advance and may refuse employment unless so prepaid, but no driver of a taxicab
shall otherwise refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person upon request anywhere in the Village unless previously engaged or unable to do so. (Ord.
2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-23: RECEIPT FOR FARE PAID:
If demanded by the passenger, the driver in charge of a taxicab shall deliver to the person paying for the hiring of the same at the time of such payment, a
receipt in legible type or writing containing the name of the owners or operator, the Village decal number, the driver's Village license number, or the
taximeter number and any items for which a charge is made, the total amount paid and the date of payment. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
9-4-24: SCHEDULE OF RATES; RATE CARD REQUIRED:
(A) No person owning, operating or controlling any taxicab within the Village limits shall charge in excess of the following rates as determined by the
taximeter:
For the first 1/6 mile, or fraction
thereof, for one person $1.60
For each succeeding 1/6 mile thereafter 0.20
For each additional passenger over 12
years of age for the entire journey 0.75
For each 3 minutes of waiting time or
fraction thereof 0.90
(B) Waiting time shall include the time when the taxicab is not in motion, beginning with the arrival at the place to which it has been called, time consumed
while standing at the direction of the passenger, or time consumed while standing because of conditions beyond the control of the operator. No time
shall be made for time lost for inefficiency of the taxicab or its operator or time consumed by premature response to a call.
(C) Where, with the consent of the licensee, any such taxicab is hired by the hour, the charge shall not exceed two dollars fifty cents ($2.50) an hour for no
more than four (4) passengers, and an additional twenty five cents ($0.25) an hour for each passenger in excess of four (4).
(D) The rate to be charged for a touring car having a seating capacity of five (5) passengers and carrying not more than four (4) passengers, shall not
exceed three dollars ($3.00) an hour, with an additional fifty cents ($0.50) an hour for each passenger in excess of four (4).
(E) The rate to be charged for the use of a touring car having seating capacity for more than five (5) passengers and carrying not more than six (6)
passengers shall not exceed four dollars ($4.00) an hour, with an additional charge of fifty cents ($0.50) an hour for each passenger in excess of six
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 374/519
(6).
(F) Every taxicab operated under this Chapter shall have a rate card setting forth the authorized rates of fare displayed in such a place as to be in view of
all passengers.
(G) A licensed taxicab company may provide for multiple passengers and shared rides, provided that the passengers are advised when ordering a cab that
the ride will be shared. Group rates for shared rides will be established by the taxicab company provided the rate for the group does not exceed the
rate that would have been applicable under this Section to one passenger multiplied by the number of persons in the group. (Ord. 2252, 10-5-1998)
Chapter 5
MOTOR VEHICLE TAX
9-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this Chapter, the following terms shall have the following meanings:
COMMERCIAL VEHICLE: Shall include motor trucks, tractors, trailers and motor buses, whether or not actually used for commercial purposes, and all
motor vehicles used for public hire.
MOTOR BUSES: Shall include all vehicles used or designed for use for carriage of more than seven (7) persons.
MOTOR TRUCKS: Shall include all motor vehicles, including tractor trucks, used or designed to be used to carry goods.
MOTOR VEHICLE: Shall mean every self-propelled device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a street,
except devices moved by human power or used exclusively on stationary rails or tracks.
PERSON: Shall mean any individual, entity, firm, proprietorship, partnership, association, corporation or organization of any kind.
PLEASURE VEHICLES: Shall include all motor vehicles used or designed to be used to carry not more than seven (7) passengers, and all recreational
vehicles, excepting motor bicycles, tricycles and commercial vehicles.
SITUS OR BASE: Shall mean, when applied to a person, the place where that person or business is principally located and, when applied to a motor
vehicle, the place where that motor vehicle is principally garaged, or from whence it is principally dispatched, or where its movements usually originate.
TRAILER: Includes every vehicle without motive power designed to carry passengers or property and to be drawn by a motor vehicle.
VEHICLE: Includes every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be drawn upon a street except devices moved by human power or
used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. (Ord. 2198, 8-18-1997)
9-5-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person residing in the Village, or for any person having his, her or its situs or base within the Village to park, store, use or
operate, or to cause or permit any of his, her or its agents or employees to park, store, use or operate, any motor vehicle within the corporate boundaries
of the Village unless that motor vehicle is licensed as provided in this Chapter. In addition, any motor vehicle that has its situs or base within the corporate
boundaries of the Village must be licensed as provided in this Chapter. If an application for a State vehicle registration represents that the vehicle is
situated in or that the owner resides within the corporate boundaries of the Village that shall be deemed to be proof of these facts for the purposes of this
Section. (Ord. 2198, 8-18-1997)
9-5-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
(A) Any person desiring a motor vehicle license shall file an application with the village manager upon a form to be provided by the village manager. The
form must be signed by the applicant and include the applicant's name, address and telephone number, a description and the class of the motor
vehicle for which the license is being sought, the motor vehicle's license plate number, and such other information as may be required in order to
identify the motor vehicle and to enforce the provisions of this chapter.
(B) The license application period shall commence on May 1 of each year and extend to the following June 30. New residents moving into the village after
expiration of the May 1 application period shall have thirty (30) days following physical occupancy of such residence to apply for a license. Residents
acquiring a motor vehicle after expiration of the May 1 application period shall have a like period of thirty (30) days following possession of the motor
vehicle in which to apply for a license. (Ord. 2198, 8-18-1997)
9-5-4: LEASED AND COMPANY OWNED VEHICLES:
Except as provided in section 9-5-7 of this chapter, a motor vehicle that is not owned by a resident of the village but is a leased or company owned vehicle
must be licensed with the village if the lessee or employee that uses the motor vehicle resides within the corporate boundaries of the village. In order to
obtain a license, the applicant must show proof of residence, such as a driver's license with a current address indicating that the applicant resides within
the corporate boundaries of the village. (Ord. 2198, 8-18-1997; amd. Ord. 2225, 5-4-1998)
9-5-5: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 375/519
Upon receipt of an application and the applicant's payment of the license fee provided for in this chapter, the village manager shall issue a license to the
applicant for the motor vehicle and shall provide the applicant with a suitable license sticker with an adhesive substance on one or both sides. The license
sticker shall bear the word "Riverside", the license number, the designation of the class to which the motor vehicle belongs, and the year for which the
license is issued. The license sticker shall be affixed to the lower right hand corner of the front windshield of the motor vehicle being licensed, if such motor
vehicle has a front windshield; otherwise, the license sticker shall be affixed to the license plate of the motor vehicle being licensed. It shall be unlawful to
disfigure, destroy or alter a license sticker in any way. (Ord. 2198, 8-18-1997)
9-5-6: EXPIRATION DATE:
All licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall expire on June 30 following their issuance. (Ord. 2198, 8-18-1997)
9-5-7: LICENSE FEES:
(A) Regular Fee: The license fee shall be due and payable prior to July 1 of any year. The fees for licenses issued under this chapter shall be as follows:
(Ord. 2643, 11-5-2007)
Pleasure vehicles and recreational vehicles:
Class A-B $ 90.00
Motor trucks and commercial vehicles, classified by gross weight including weight of vehicle and weight of maximum bed:
Class C (8,000 pounds or less) 100.00
Class T (over 8,000 pounds) 120.00
Motorcycles and motorbikes:
Class M 90.00
(Ord. 2643, 11-5-2007; amd. Ord. 2736, 12-21-2009)
(B) Prorated Fee: If a motor vehicle is purchased or lawfully acquired by the applicant on or after January 1 of any given year, the license fee to be paid
shall be equal to one-half (1/2) of the regular fee. Before any applicant shall be entitled to such prorated license fee, the applicant must furnish an
affidavit, in a form satisfactory to the village manager, stating that the motor vehicle for which the license is sought was purchased or otherwise lawfully
acquired by the applicant on or after January 1 of that year. The applicant must also provide the village manager with a copy of the bill of sale covering
the motor vehicle for which the license is sought. (Ord. 2643, 11-5-2007)
(C) Late Fee: In the event a motor vehicle license is not obtained on or before June 30 of the year when due, or as otherwise provided in section 9-5-3 of
this chapter, an additional late fee shall be charged in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00) for each month or portion thereof following the due date that
transpires before said license is obtained. Applicants for motor vehicles purchased or acquired during June of any given year may purchase a motor
vehicle license for the following vehicle sticker year (July 1 to June 30) without any penalty.
(D) Previous Year: In the event a motor vehicle license was not obtained for one or more previous years and such license was required, the village
manager shall not issue a motor vehicle license for the current or upcoming year unless the payment accompanying the application for such license
includes the amounts owed, including late payment fees set forth in subsection (C) of this section for the previous years' licenses. Total late fees
assessed during any single calendar year extending from July 1 to June 30 shall not exceed one hundred ten dollars ($110.00). If license fees and late
fees are owed, the village shall collect unpaid late fees and license fee(s) for each of the prior three (3) years.
(E) Limited Amnesty: From February 16, 2010, through March 11, 2010, previous year stickers may be purchased without late payment fees. During this
limited amnesty period, late payment fees for the current year sticker shall still be required. As of March 12, 2010, all late payment fees shall be
required. (Ord. 2741, 2-15-2010)
9-5-8: SALE, TRANSFER OR ASSIGNMENT OF LICENSED MOTOR VEHICLES:
Any person owning a motor vehicle licensed under this chapter who sells, transfers or assigns the motor vehicle must remove and destroy the license
sticker before delivering the motor vehicle to the purchaser or assignee. The license issued for that motor vehicle shall cease to apply to the motor vehicle
as of the date of the sale, transfer or assignment. Upon showing to the village manager that the license sticker has been removed from the sold,
transferred or assigned vehicle, the village manager may issue, for a fee of five dollars ($5.00), a new tag bearing a new license number which shall apply
to and be assigned to any other vehicle of the same class owned by said vendor or transferor. No vehicle license issued for or assigned to any motor
vehicle shall ever be used for or attached to a different motor vehicle. (Ord. 2198, 8-18-1997)
9-5-9: DESTRUCTION OF STICKER OR PLATE:
In the event of destruction of any license sticker or plate, the village manager, upon application by the person to whom the sticker or plate was issued, and
upon receipt of an affidavit by such person or other satisfactory proof that the license sticker or plate was destroyed, shall issue to the applicant a new
license and license sticker for the same year as the license plate or sticker destroyed and for the same vehicle, if such vehicle has not been sold,
transferred or assigned. The applicant shall pay a fee of five dollars ($5.00) for this new license and license sticker. If the vehicle originally licensed has
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 376/519
been sold, assigned or transferred and the applicant has since acquired another vehicle for which a license is required or desired, the applicant can
receive a new license and license sticker as provided in section 9-5-8 of this chapter. (Ord. 2198, 8-18-1997)
9-5-10: PENALTY:
Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day in which a violation occurs or continues shall constitute a separate offense. A person charged
with violating a provision of this chapter may be issued a violation notice in lieu of the village filing a complaint in court against that person. The violation
notice shall be administratively adjudicated pursuant to chapter 6 of this title and the fines and penalties established therein. (Ord. 2198, 8-18-1997)
Chapter 6
ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION OF CERTAIN TRAFFIC AND OTHER VIOLATIONS
9-6-1: PURPOSE AND SCOPE:
The purpose and scope of this Chapter is to provide a fair and efficient enforcement of Village vehicular standing, parking, and vehicle compliance
regulation violation(s), vehicle license or wheel tax violations and other Village regulation violation(s) as may be allowed by law, through an administrative
adjudication of violation(s) of such regulations and to establish a schedule of uniform fines and penalties and authority and procedures for collection of
unpaid fines and penalties; pursuant to the authority provided in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3. For purposes of this Chapter, "compliance
violation" means a violation of a Village regulation governing the condition or use of equipment on a vehicle or governing the procurement and display of a
Village vehicle tax license, as provided in Chapters 1 and 5 of this Title. (Ord. 2160, 9-16-1996)
9-6-2: ADMINISTRATIVE COMPOSITION:
The system of administrative adjudication of vehicular standing, parking, compliance, and other regulation violations shall provide for a Traffic Compliance
Administrator, Hearing Officer, Computer Operator/System Coordinator and Hearing Room Personnel (Deputy), with the power, authority and limitations as
are hereinafter set forth:
(A) Traffic Compliance Administrator: Shall be empowered and is hereby authorized and directed to:
1. Operate and manage the system of administrative adjudication of vehicular standing, parking, compliance and other regulation violations.
2. Adopt, distribute, and process the necessary violation notices and other notices as may be required under this Chapter or as may be reasonably
required to carry out the purpose of this Chapter.
3. Collect monies paid as fines and/or penalties assessed after a final determination of violation liability.
4. Conduct hearings, as a hearing officer with the same power and authority as is hereinafter set forth, during the absence of the appointed Hearing
Officer.
5. Certify copies of final determination of violation liability and factual report verifying that the final determination of violation liability was issued in
accordance with this Chapter and 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3.
6. Certify reports to the Secretary of State concerning initiation of suspension of driving privileges in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter,
hereinafter set forth, and those of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-306.5.
7. Review final determination of violation liability, validity of notices of impending impoundment or validity of notice of impending driver's license
suspension, in an administrative review capacity in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter, hereinafter set forth.
8. Promulgate rules and regulations reasonably required to operate and maintain the administrative adjudication system hereby created.
9. Collect unpaid fines and penalties by filing complaints in the Circuit Court or selecting or appointing an individual or agency to act on behalf of this
village in filing complaints seeking judgments for unpaid fines or penalties and in pursuit of all postjudgment remedies available by current law.
10. To select or appoint an individual, agency or firm to tow and impound vehicles in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, hereinafter set
forth.
(B) Hearing Officer: The hearing officer shall be empowered and is hereby authorized and directed to:
1. Preside over the administrative hearings, established herein, as the adjudicator.
2. Administer oaths.
3. Issue subpoenas to secure the attendance of witnesses and production of relevant papers or documentation.
4. Assess fines and penalties for the violation so provided in this code as are established in section 9-6-9 of this chapter.
5. Make final determination of:
(a) Vehicular standing, parking, compliance and other regulation violation(s) liability.
(b) Validity of notice of impending impoundment.
(c) Validity of notice of impending driver's license suspension in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, hereinafter set forth.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 377/519
6. Provide for the accurate recordation of the administrative adjudication hearing(s).
(C) System Coordinator/Computer Operator: The system coordinator/computer operator are hereby authorized and directed to operate and maintain the
computer program(s) for the administrative adjudication system hereby created, on a day to day basis, including, but not limited to:
1. Input of violation notice information.
2. Hearing date(s) and notice dates.
3. Fine and penalty assessments and payment(s).
4. Issuance of payment receipts when payment is made in person or a cash payment is received by mail.
5. Issuance of succeeding notices of hearing dates, final determination of liability, notice of impending impoundment, and notice of impending driver's
license suspension, as directed by the traffic compliance administrator in accordance with the provisions hereinafter set forth.
6. Keeping accurate records of appearances and nonappearances at administrative hearings, pleas entered, fines and penalties assessed and paid.
(D) Hearing Room Personnel: Hearing room personnel are hereby authorized and directed to:
1. Maintain hearing room decorum.
2. Have and execute authority as is granted to courtroom deputies of the circuit court.
3. Perform such other duties or acts as may reasonably be required and as directed by the hearing officer or traffic compliance administrator.
(E) Appointments: The chief of police is hereby authorized to appoint persons to hold the positions above set forth. One person may hold and fulfill the
requirements of one or more of the above stated positions.
(F) Compensation: Compensation to be paid for each of the above stated positions shall be as determined and approved by the village board. (Ord. 2160,
9-16-1996)
9-6-3: PROCEDURE:
The system of administrative adjudication of vehicular standing, parking, compliance and other regulation violation(s) shall be in accordance with the
following procedures, and final determination of liability, validity of notice of impending impoundment, validity of notice of impending driver's license
suspension, impoundment of vehicle and collections shall be made only in accordance with the provisions set forth below:
(A) Violation Notice: Vehicular standing, parking, compliance and other regulation violation notice(s) ("violation notice") shall be issued by the person(s)
authorized herein and shall contain information and shall be served, certified and have evidentiary admissibility as is hereinafter set forth.
(B) Authorization: All full time police officers and community service officers, as well as other specifically appointed individuals shall have the authority to
issue violation notices.
(C) Detection Of Violations: Any individual authorized hereby to issue violation notices and who detects a violation of any section of any applicable
provision of this code, shall issue a notice of violation thereof and shall make service thereof as is hereinafter set forth.
(D) Contents Of Notice: The violation notice shall contain, but shall not be limited to, the following information:
1. The date, time, and place of the violation (date of issuance).
2. The particular vehicular standing, parking, compliance or other regulation violated.
3. Vehicle make and state registration number.
4. The fine and any penalty which may be assessed for late payment.
5. The signature and identification number of the person issuing the notice.
6. A section entitled "request for hearing" which shall clearly set forth that the registered owner or lessee may appear at the initial administrative
hearing to contest the validity of the violation notice on the date and at the time and place as specified in the violation notice by:
(a) Checking or placing a mark in a space provided and clearly identified, "request for hearing".
(b) Placing his/her name and current address in the place provided.
(c) Signing his/her name in the appropriate indicated place.
(d) Filing the violation notice, with the "request for hearing" portion fully completed, with the traffic compliance administrator postmarked within ten
(10) days of the violation notice issuance. The request shall be deemed filed upon receipt by the traffic compliance administrator.
7. The date, time and place of an administrative hearing at which the violation may be contested on its merits.
8. A section entitled, "nonresident request for hearing-nonappearance", which clearly sets forth that a nonresident registered owner or lessee may
appear at the initial administrative hearing to contest the validity of the violation notice without personally appearing by:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 378/519
(a) Checking or placing a mark in a space provided and clearly identified, "nonresident request for hearing, nonappearance".
(b) Placing his/her name and current address in the place provided.
(c) Signing his/her name in the appropriate indicated place.
(d) Filing the violation notice, with the "nonresident request for hearing" portion fully completed, with the traffic compliance administrator postmarked
within ten (10) days of the violation notice issuance. The request shall be deemed filed upon receipt by the traffic compliance administrator.
(e) Filing a notarized statement of facts specifying the grounds for challenging a violation notice which must be filed with the traffic compliance
administrator postmarked within ten (10) days of the violation notice issuance. The request shall be deemed filed, if postmarked by the due dates
specified herein.
(f) A clearly marked statement that execution of the nonresident request for hearing is a waiver of the nonresident's right to a personal appearance
and that the adjudication will be made based upon the notarized statement of facts submitted by the nonresident and the facts contained in the
violation notice.
(E) Service Of Notice: Service of the violation notice shall be made by the person issuing such notice by:
1. Affixing the original or a facsimile of the notice to an unlawfully standing or parked vehicle, or
2. Handing the notice to the registered owner, operator or lessee of the vehicle, if present.
(F) Certification Of Notice: The correctness of facts contained in the vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation notice shall be certified
by the person issuing said notice by:
1. Signing his/her name to the notice at the time of service, or
2. In the case of a notice produced by a computer device, by signing a single certificate, to be kept by the traffic compliance administrator, attesting to
the correctness of all notices produced by the device while under his/her control.
(G) Record Of Notice: The original or a facsimile of the violation notice shall be retained by the traffic compliance administrator and kept as a record in the
ordinary course of business.
(H) Prima Facie Evidence Of Correctness: Any violation notice issued, signed and served in accordance herewith, or a copy of the notice, shall be prima
facie correct and shall be prima facie evidence of the correctness of the facts shown on the notice.
(I) Admissibility: The violation notice or a copy shall be admissible in any subsequent administrative or legal proceeding. (Ord. 2440, 1-21-2003)
9-6-4: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS:
(A) To Whom Granted: An administrative hearing to adjudicate the alleged violation on its merits shall be granted to the registered owner or operator of the
"cited vehicle", pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3 or the lessee of the "cited vehicle", pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/11-1306, incorporated herein by reference.
(B) Hearing Dates: An administrative hearing to adjudicate the alleged violation on its merits shall be at the date, time, and place as is set forth in the
violation notice issued and served, or such additional notices issued in accordance with this chapter. Violators shall be given no less than three (3)
opportunities to appear, and failure to appear by the third scheduled hearing date will result in a final determination of liability as hereinafter set forth.
(C) Record: An administrative hearing to adjudicate the alleged violation on its merits shall be tape recorded.
(D) Determination: An administrative hearing to adjudicate the alleged violation on its merits shall culminate in a determination of liability or nonliability,
made by the hearing officer, who shall consider testimony and other evidence without the application of the formal or technical rules of evidence. The
hearing officer shall, upon a determination of liability, assess fines and penalties in accordance with section 9-6-9 of this chapter.
(E) Representation By Attorney: Persons appearing to contest the alleged violation on its merits may be represented by counsel at their own expense.
(F) Review: The final determination of any matter which may be decided by the hearing officer may be reviewed as is hereinafter set forth. (Ord. 2160, 9-
16-1996)
9-6-5: ADDITIONAL NOTICES:
Upon failure of the registered owner or lessee of the "cited vehicle" to appear at the administrative hearing indicated in the violation notice, or upon final
determination of violation liability, the traffic compliance administrator shall send or cause to be sent additional notices which:
(A) Shall be sent to the registered owner or lessee of the "cited vehicle" at the address as is recorded with the secretary of state.
(B) Shall be sent to the lessee of the "cited vehicle" at the address last known to the lessor of the "cited vehicle" at the time of the lease.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 379/519
(C) Shall be sent by first class mail, postage prepaid.
(D) Service of additional notices sent in accordance herewith shall be complete as of the date of deposit in the U.S. mail.
(E) The additional notices sent in accordance herewith shall be in the following sequence and contain, but not be limited to, the following information:
1. Upon the failure of the registered owner or lessee of the "cited vehicle" to appear at the hearing set forth in the violation notice, additional notice shall
be sent, as above set forth, and shall contain, but not be limited to, the following information:
(a) Date and location of violation cited in the vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation notice.
(b) Particular regulation violated.
(c) Vehicle make and state registration.
(d) Fine and any penalty that may be assessed for late payment.
(e) Notice to the registered owner or lessee of their current status, other than paid in full.
(f) Date, time and place of the administrative hearing at which the alleged violation may be contested on its merits.
(g) Statement that failure to either pay fine or failure to appear at the hearing on its merits on the date and at the time and place specified will result in
a final determination of liability for the "cited" violation in the amount of the fine indicated.
(h) Statement that upon the occurrence of a final determination of liability for the failure, and the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust, available
administrative or judicial procedures for review, any unpaid fine or penalty will constitute a debt due and owing the village. (Ord. 2440, 1-21-2003)
2. A notice of final determination shall be sent following an appearance by the violator and a determination of liability, or the failure to appear by the
violator by the second and final hearing date and upon conclusion of any administrative and/or judicial review, as is hereinafter set forth, and the
notice shall contain, but not be limited to, the following information and warning: (Ord. 2442, 2-18-2003)
(a) A statement that the unpaid fine and any penalty to be assessed is a debt due and owing the village.
(b) A warning that failure to pay the fine and any penalty due and owing the village within the time specified may result in the village's filing a
complaint in the circuit court to have the unpaid fine or penalty rendered a judgment in accordance with 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-
208.3(f), incorporated herein by reference.
(c) A warning that the vehicle owned by the person and located within the village may be impounded for failure to pay fines or penalties for three (3)
or more vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violations.
(d) A warning that the person's driver's license may be suspended for failure to pay fines or penalties for ten (10) or more vehicular standing, parking
or compliance violations under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-306.5, incorporated herein by reference.
3. A notice of impending suspension of a person's driver's license shall be sent to any person determined to be liable for the payment of any fine or
penalty that remains due and owing on ten (10) or more vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violations:
(a) The notice shall state that the failure to pay the fine or penalty owing within forty five (45) days of the date of the notice will result in the village's
notifying the secretary of state that the person is eligible for initiation of suspension proceedings under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-306.5
incorporated herein by reference.
(b) The notice of impending driver's license suspension shall be sent by first class mail, postage prepaid, to the address recorded with the secretary
of state. (Ord. 2440, 1-21-2003)
9-6-6: FINAL DETERMINATION OF LIABILITY:
A final determination of violation liability shall:
(A) Occur following the failure to pay the total assessed fine or penalty after the hearing officer's determination of liability and the exhaustion of or the
failure to exhaust any administrative review procedures hereinafter set forth, or
(B) Where a person fails to appear at a prior hearing or by the third and final administrative hearing provided to contest the alleged violation on the date
and at the time and place specified in a prior served or mailed notice, the hearing officer's determination of liability shall become final:
1. Upon denial of a timely petition to set aside that determination, or
2. Upon the expiration of the period for filing petition without a filing having been made. (Ord. 2160, 9-16-1996)
9-6-7: ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW:
A petition to set aside a determination of violation liability may be filed by a person in the manner and subject to the restrictions and grounds hereinafter
set forth:
(A) A written petition to set aside a determination of liability must be filed in the office of the traffic compliance administrator within, but not later than,
fourteen (14) days from the date the determination of liability is made.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=610 380/519
(B) The traffic compliance administrator shall act upon the petition timely filed and render a decision thereon within fourteen (14) days of the date filed.
(C) The grounds for setting aside a determination of liability shall be limited to the following:
1. The person against whom the determination of liability is made was not the owner or lessee of the "cited vehicle" on the date the vehicular standing,
parking, or compliance regulation violation notice was issued.
2. The person's having paid the fine or penalty prior to the determination of liability for the violation in question.
3. Excusable failure to appear at or request a new date for a hearing.
(D) Should the determination of liability be set aside, the traffic compliance administrator shall:
1. Notify the registered owner, or lessee, as the case may be, that the determination of liability has been set aside.
2. Notify the registered owner, or lessee, as the case may be, of a date, time and place for a hearing on the merits of the violation for which
determination of liability has been set aside.
3. Notice of setting aside of the determination of liability and the notice of the hearing date shall be by first class mail, postage prepaid to the address
set forth on the petition to set aside the determination of liability.
4. Service of the notice shall be complete on the date the notice is deposited in the U.S. mail. (Ord. 2440, 1-21-2003)
9-6-8: NONRESIDENT PROCEDURES:
Nonresidents of this village who have been served a violation notice, in accordance with this chapter, may contest the alleged violation on its merits, as
could a resident, or may contest the validity without personally appearing at an administrative hearing by:
(A) Completing, in full, the "nonresident request for hearing" section of the violation notice, served upon him/her pursuant to this chapter.
(B) Signing the nonresident request for hearing in the space specified in the violation notice, and acknowledging that his/her personal appearance is
waived and submitting to an adjudication based upon the notarized statement filed by him/her and the facts contained in the violation notice.
(C) Filing the violation notice with the "request for hearing" section fully completed with the traffic compliance administrator postmarked within ten (10)
days of the violation notice issuance. The request shall be deemed filed upon receipt by the traffic compliance administrator.
(D) Filing a notarized statement of facts specifying the grounds for challenging the violation notice which must be filed with the traffic compliance
administrator postmarked within ten (10) days of the violation notice issuance. The request shall be deemed filed upon receipt by the traffic compliance
administrator. The acceptance of a "nonresident request for hearing" after the due date or with cause, at the discretion of the traffic compliance
administrator, may be accepted for hearing consideration and decision.
(E) The hearing officer shall make an adjudication based upon the facts set forth in the notarized statement of facts filed by the nonresident as is contained
in the violation notice.
(F) Notice of the determination of the hearing officer shall be served upon the nonresident by first class mail, postage prepaid, addressed to the
nonresident at the address set forth in the statement of facts submitted.
(G) Service of the notice shall be complete on the date the notice is placed in the U.S. mail.
(H) All other provisions of this chapter shall apply equally to nonresidents of this Village. (Ord. 2160, 9-16-1996)
